vigorous action, l. a)/nemos
a keen wind, Hdt.2.96, cf.A.Ag.1180; l. h)/dh kai\ me/gas kaqiei/s swooping down like a
fresh and mighty breeze, Ar.Eq.430, cf. 760; lampro\s fanh/setai he will come
furiously forth, E.Heracl.280; l. ma/xh a
keenly contested battle, Plb.10.12.5; -o/teros ki/ndunos Id.1.45.9. Adv. -rw=s, e)pikei/menoi
vigorously, Th.7.71;
utterly, l. h(tth=sqai, l. periestoixi/sqai, Hld.4.4, 9.1. metaph. also,
clear, manifest, martu/ria A.Eu.797; tau=t' e)peidh\ lampra\ sumbai/nei S.Tr.1174; i)/xnh X.Cyn. 5.5; gegenhme/nhs th=s ni/khs l. h)/dh Th.7.55; l. fugh/
decisive, Arr.An. 2.11.3. Adv. -rw=s, kou)de\n ai)nikthri/ws A.Pr.833; lelume/nwn l. tw=n spondw=n Th.2.7; l. nika=n Arr.An.2.10.4; lamprw=s e)le/geto it was said
without concealment, Th.8.67. of persons,
well-known, illustrious by deeds, station, etc., l. e)n th=|si *)aqh/nh|si Hdt.6.125; e)n toi=si pole/moisi e)w\n -o/tatos Id.7.154; l. e)n [toi=s kindu/nois] D.19.269; -ota/tous genome/nous tw=n kaq' e(autou/s Th.1.138; e)c a)do/cwn gene/sqai l. Isoc.5.89; l. e)s ge/nos E.El.37; e)n lo/gois Id.Supp.[902]; as honorary title, -o/tatos, = Lat.
clarissimus, IG14.911, 7.91, etc.; of cities, councils, etc., h( lampra\ tw=n *milhsi/wn mhtro/polis SIG906 A 4 (iv A. D.), cf. 867.4 (Sup., Ephesus, ii A. D.); of actions, etc., e)/rgon ou)de\n a)p' au)tw=n l. gi/netai Hdt.3.72; to\n bi/on l. poiei=sqai S.OC1144; to\ l. fw=s a)posbennu\s ge/nous Trag.Adesp.9.
magnificent, munificent, l. e)n tai=s leitourgi/ais Isoc.3.56, cf. D.21.153 (Sup.); o( l. kai\ plou/sios ou(=tos ib. 174. Adv. -rw=s, xorhgei=n Antipho 2.2.12, Arist.EN1122b22.
bright, joyous, l. w(/sper o)/mmati, of the bearer of good news, S.OT 81, cf. X.HG4.5.10; lampro\n e)ce/pemya
with bright hopes, S.El.1130; l. tai=s e)lpi/sin Jul.Or.2.64b; also o)/mmati de/rkomai lampro/n, of one
clear in conscience, Pi.N.7.66. of outward appearance,
splendid, brilliant, numfi/on . . l. o)/nta Ar.Pax859; of a horse, IG22.956.87, X.Eq.11.1; in dress, Id.Cyn.2.4.5 (Sup.); of youthful bloom, w(/ra| h(liki/as l. Th.6.54; of
healthy look, Hp.
Aër.24; of property, dress, etc., ei)/ ti/ g' e)/sti l. kai\ kalo/n Ar.Pl.144, cf. E.Fr.316.5; kataskeuh/ X.Smp.1.4 (Comp.); l. ka/llos
beaming beauty, Pl. Phdr.250b, etc.: more generally l. ti poiei=n X.Cyr.5.4.15; to\ l.
splendour, Pi.N.8.34; l. gene/sqai boulo/mesqa tou\s ga/mous Euang.1.3. Adv. -w=s, opp. litw=s, Phld.Mort.30: Sup. -o/tata X.Cyr.2.4.1; later -ota/tws JHS44.26 (Ancyra, ii A. D.). of language,
brilliant, tw=n diqura/mbwn ta\ l. Ar.Av.1388; l. le/cis
ornamental diction, Arist. Po.1460b4; lo/gos Hermog.Id.1.9. Astrol., of degrees in a zodiacal sign, e(ka/stou zw|di/ou lampra\s moi/ras e)ce/qento Heph.Astr.1.1, al. for Adv. -rw=s, v. supr. 1.5 and 6, 11.2, 111.1.

lampro/ths, htos, h(,
brilliancy, splendour, l. kai\ ta/cis tou= strateu/matos X.An.1.2.18; of a horse, Id.Eq.11.9; of arms, Plb.11.9.1, Arr.An.1.14.4.
clearness, distinctness, Plu.Phil.11. metaph.,
brilliancy, splendour, Hdt.2.101; h( parauti/ka l. Th.2.64, cf. 7.69; a)po\ oi(/as lampro/thtos . . e)s oi(/an . . teleuth\n a)fi=kto Id.7.75, cf. 6.31: pl.,
distinctions, timai\ kai\ l. Id.4.62; e)/n tinos lampro/thti in
distinction for a thing, Id.6.16; l. tw=n pra/cewn D.S.16.66, cf. Arr. An.2.7.7.
munificence, D.21.158.
brilliancy of style, Plu. 2.25b; lampro/thtes tou= lo/gou, Lat.
lumina orationis, Philostr.VS 1.23.2. l. yuxh=s
magnanimity, Plb.32.8.1, D.S.4.40. as a title, h( sh\ l. your
Serenity, Serene Highness, PGrenf.1.59 (v/vi A. D.).

lampro/-tocos, on,
with radiant bow, Sch.D Il.1.37, Eust.32.45.

lampro-fa^h/s, e/s,
bright-beaming, Orph.H.78.2, Man.4.53,
Cat.Cod. Astr.1.173.

lampro-fa^nh/s, e/s,
appearing brilliant, Paul.Al.N.2, Lyd. Mag.2.16.

lampro-feggh/s, e/s,
brightly shining, PMag.Par.1.386.

lampro/fqalmos, on,
bright-eyed, Hsch.s.v. glaukw=pis.

lampro/-fwnos, on,
clear-voiced, Hp.
Aër.5, Plu.2.840a: Sup. -o/tatos D.18.313:—hence lampro-fwneu/omai, Hdn.Philet.p.436 P., Hsch. s.v. balaneu/ein; and lampro-fwni/a, Ion. -ih, h(,
clearness and loudness of voice, Hdt.6.60.

lampro/-yu_xos, on,
high-minded, Arar.15, Ptol.Tetr. 162. Adv. -xws,
munificently, e)pimelhteu/ein Klio 17.187 (i A. D.).

lampr-unth/s, ou=, o(,
bearing oneself proudly, i(/ppos Antisth. ap. D.L. 6.7.

lampr-untiko/s, h/, o/n,
making bright and clean, prosw/pou Dsc.2.135, cf. Crito ap.Gal.12.446.

lampr-u/nw, mostly in pres. and impf. (v. infr.),
make bright or
brilliant, to\n i(/ppon X.Eq.10.1, cf. App.Anth.3.158; mh\ xrw/masin （o)/mmasin codd. Stob.) to\ sw=ma l.
deck with bright colours, Antiph.264; lampru/nei th\n fwnh/n (of garlic)
makes the voice
clear, Dsc.Eup.1.87:—Med., e)lampru/nonto ta\s a)spi/das
polished their shields, X.HG7.5.20:—Pass., of a shield,
to be polished or
bright, Id.Lac.11.3; also eu(/dousa frh\n o)/mmasin lampru/netai
is lightened with eyes, A.Eu.104; lela/mpruntai ko/ras S.Fr.710; also,
to become manifest or
notorious, e)n h(mi=n o( yo/gos -u/netai E.El.1039. Med.,
make oneself splendid, pride oneself on a thing, o)/xois kai\ stolh=| -u/netai ib.966; ge/nei Onos.1.22;
distinguish oneself in or
by . . , o(/sa . . xorhgi/ais h)\ a)/llw| tw| -u/nomai Th.6.16; meiraki/wn -unome/nwn e)n a(/rmasin Ar. Eq.556; l. e)n oi(=s ou) dei= Arist.EN1122a33, etc.; peri\ ta\s eu)wxi/as Str. 14.1.20; polla\ kai\ mega/la lampruna/menos pro\s to\ qei=on Plu.Nic.26; ta\ a)/lla e)lampru/nato Id.Alex.70; e)pi/ tini Philostr.VA2.43; polla\ peri\ tw=n *mhdikw=n e)/rgwn Plu.2.870d.

la/mpr-usma, atos, to/,
ornament, Phryn.PSpp.82,124 B., Hsch.s.v. glainoi/, EM232.40.

lamp-th/r, h=ros, o(, (la/mpw)
stand or
grate for pine and other wood used
for lighting rooms, Od.18.307 sq., 343, 19.63; w)= xai=re, l. nukto/s
thou that lightest up the night, of a beacon-fire, A.Ag.22; e(/speroi lampth=res the evening
watch-fires, S.Aj.286; h(li/ou lampth=res E.Rh.60. epith. of Dionysus, Paus.7.27.3.
lantern, E. IA34 (anap.), Hp.Int.26, X.Smp.5.2, Aen.Tact.22.21, PCornell 1.85; l. a)ntipefragme/nos, of a horn-
lantern, Philist.15, cf. Emp.84.3; l. mh\ e)/xonti to\ ku/klw| de/rma Arist.HA531a5.

lamp-th/ria (sc. i(era/), ta/,
feast of Dionysus lampth/r, Paus.7.27.3.

lamp-throkle/pths, ou, o(,
lamp-stealer: metaph., of Perseus, who stole the eye of the Graeae, Lyc.846.

lamp-throuxi/a, h(,
holding of torches: pl., lampthrouxi/ai
the beacon-watches, A.Ag.890.

lamp-throfo/ros, on,
carrying lights, pai=des Socr.Rhod.1 J.

lampu^r-i/zw,
shine like a glow-worm, Thphr.Lap.58, 59, Dsc.5.84;
shine steadily, opp. spinqhrobole/w, of Venus, PMag.Par.1.2940: c. acc.,
illuminate, th\n o(/lhn oi)koume/nhn PMag.Berol.2.103, cf.
PLeid. V.3.15:—Med., abs.,
shine, PMag.Lond.121.603.

lampu^r-i/s, i/dos, h(,
glow-worm, = la/mpouris 11, Arist.PA642b34.

la/mpw, Il.13.474, etc.; Ion.Iterat. la/mpesken Emp.84.6, Theoc. (v. infr.): fut. -yw S.El.66, AP6.249 (Antip.): aor. e)/lamya Hdt.6.82 (v.l.), S.OT473 (lyr.), Ar.V.62, Pl.Ep.335d: pf. le/lampa (in pres. sense) E.Andr.1025, Tr.1295 (both lyr.):—Med., h.Hom.31.13, etc.: impf. e)lampo/mhn, Ep. lamp-, Il.6.319, E.Med.1194: fut. la/myomai （e)ll-) Hdt.1.80:—Pass., fut. lamfqh/somai （e)ll-) Plot.2.9.3: aor. e)la/mfqhn J.BJ4.10.1 (peri-): from these late forms of Pass. must be distd. the similar Ion. forms of lamba/nw:—
give light, shine, of the gleam of arms, th=le de\ xalko\s la/mf' w(/s te steroph/ Il.10.154, cf. 11.66; la/mpe de\ xalkw=|, of Hector, 12.463; fw=s la/mpesken Emp. l.c.; a)p' o)fqalmw=n de\ kako\n pu=r . . la/mpeske Theoc.24.19; of the eyes, o)fqalmw\ d' a)/ra oi( puri\ la/mpeton Il.13.474; of the sun, Sol.13.23, etc.; of fire, S.Ant.1007; a)/lsos la/mpen u(po\ deinoi=o qeou= Hes.Sc.71:—Med., ko/ruqos -ome/nhs Il.16.71; la/mpeto douro\s ai)xmh/ 6.319; dai/+dwn u(/po -omena/wn 18.492, Od. (only in this phrase) 19.48, 23.290; xalko\s e)la/mpeto Il.22.134; of a person, -o/menos puri/ 15.623; teu/xesi l. 20.46, Hes.Sc.60; o)/sse -e/sqhn Il.15.608; pedi/on . . la/mpeto xalkw=| 20.156, etc. of sound,
ring loud and clear, paia\n de\ la/mpei S.OT186 (lyr.), cf. 473 (lyr.); cf. lampro/s 1.4. metaph.,
shine forth, be famous or
conspicuous, la/mpei kle/os Pi.O.1.23; a)reta/ Id.I. 1.22, E.Andr.776 (lyr.); di/ka de\ la/mpei me\n e)n duska/pnois dw/masin A. Ag.773 (lyr.); te/knwn oi(=s a)\n la/mpwsin nea/nides h(=bai E.Ion476 (lyr.); ka/llos Pl.Phdr.250d. Astrol., of a planet,
occupy a favourable position, Ptol.Tetr.51. of persons, faidro\s la/mponti metw/pw| with
beaming face, Ar.Eq.550 (anap.);
shine, gain glory, ou)d' ei) *kle/wn g' e)/lamye Id.V.l.c.; e)n a)/llois bousi\n i)w\n la/mpesken Theoc.25.141. trans.,
cause to shine, illumine, do/lion a)ktai=s a)ste/ra la/myas E.Hel. 1131 (lyr.), cf. Ion83 (anap.), Ph.226, APl.c., Trag.Adesp.33, etc. —Found chiefly in poetry and Com., though the pres. and impf. occur in X.An.3.1.11 (Med.), Mem.4.7.7, Pl.Phdr.250d, Arist.de An.419a4, and late Prose, and the aor. in Hdt.6.82 (v.l.), Arist.Mu. 395a15, Plu.Tim.3, etc.
lampw/dhs, v. la/ph.
la^mu^r-i/s, i/dos, h(, = lwga/nion, Sch.Luc.Lex.3.

la^mu^r-o/s, a/, o/n,
full of abysses, qa/lassa EM555.57: hence,
gluttonous, greedy, ga/stris kai\ l. Epicr. 5.8 = Antiph.89.5; gastri\ xarizo/menos th=s ou) lamurw/teron ou)de\n Timo 7; o)do/ntes Theoc.25.234; ka/rhnon Nic.Th.293. metaph.,
wanton, impudent, -w/teron le/gein X.Smp.8.24; *)alkibia/dou h( a)/gan l. politei/a Plu.Comp.Alc.Cor.1; la/muro/n ti prosble/pein tini/ Id.Mar. 38; l. i(stori/h AP7.450 (Diosc.); of women,
coquettish, ib.5.161 (Asclep.); of Eros, lamuroi=s o)/mmasi pikra\ gela=| ib.179 (Mel.); lamura\s *po/qwn a)e/llas Cerc.5.10: later in good sense,
piquant, arch, like e)pi/xaris, Phryn.259;
charming, Plu.Caes.49, Eun.VSp.467 B.
bright, ta\ leuka\ tw=n o)fqalmw=n -w/tata (in pneumonia) Aret.SA2.1.
lamfqh=nai, Ion. aor.inf. Pass. of lamba/nw; cf. also la/mpw.
lamya/nh, h(, = laya/nh (q.v.).

la/myis, ews, h(,
shining, a)ste/rwn, a)strapw=n, h(li/ou, Ph.1.72, 2.187, Gp.2.5.12: metaph., of the law, LXX Ba.4.2.
la/myomai, fut.Med.of la/mpw, and also Ion. fut. of lamba/nw. la=n: o(ra=n, h)\ li/qon, Hsch. lanhqa/s: deuteri/as oi)=nos, Id.

lanqa^no/ntws, Adv. pres. part. of lanqa/nw,
secretly, Gal.12.292, Hdn.7.9.11, 8.7.3, D.C.66.5.

lanqa/nw, Pi.Fr.75.13, etc.:—also lh/qw (which is the form of the Act. generally used in compds., dia-lanqa/nw being the sole exception), Il.23.323, S.OT1325 (lyr.), X.Smp.4.48; Dor. la/qw [a_] S.El.
222 (lyr.); inf.la_qe/men Pi.O.1.64: impf. e)la/nqanon Il.13.721, etc.; e)/lhqon Od.19.151, S.El.1359; Ep. lh=qon Il.15.461; Ion. lh/qesken 24.13: fut. lh/sw Od.11.102, Ar.Ec.98, etc.; Aeol.inf. la_/shn Alc.Supp.22.8; Dor. la_sw= Theoc.14.9, al., so (in late writers) lh/somai, v. infr. c. 11: aor. 1 e)/lhsa Nic.Al.280 (but Hom. has e)p-e/lhsa, Alc. e)c-e/la_sa, in causal sense): aor. 2 e)/la^qon Il.17.676, etc. (for le/la^qon, v. infr. B): pf. le/lhqa Semon.7.9, Sol.13.27; Aeol.part.lela_/qwn Alc.Supp.26.8: plpf. e)lelh/qein, Att. -h/qh, Th.8.33, Ar.Eq.822, Nu.380, Luc.Pr.Im. 15; Ion.3sg. e)lelh/qee Hdt.6.79. causal lhqa/nw, aor. 2 le/la^qon, v. infr. B. Med. and Pass., lanqa/nomai Arist.Po.1455a25 (s.v.l.), lh/qomai Il.11.790, A.Ag.39; Dor. la/qomai [a_] Pi.O.8.72: Ep. impf. lanqano/mhn Od.12.227: fut. lh/somai 1.308; Dor. la_seu=mai Theoc.4.39, also lelh/somai E.Alc.198: aor. 1 e)lhsa/mhn or lhsa/mhn only in late Ep., Maiist.47, Mosch.3.62 (Dor. la_s-), Q.S.3.99, etc.; also e)lh/sqhn, Dor. inf. lasqh=men Theoc.2.46, cf. dialanqa/nw: aor. 2 e)la^qo/mhn, Ep. laq-, Il.13.835, E.Hipp.289: rare in Prose exc. in compds., Plu.Caes.38; also Ep. redupl. lela/qonto, etc., v. infr. c: pf. le/lhsmai S.El.342, Pl.Phdr.252a; Ep. le/lasmai, part. lelasme/nos, etc.; cf. e)pilh/qw. in most of the act. tenses,
escape notice (freq. joined with a neg.):—Constr.: c. acc. pers. only,
escape his
notice, la/qe d' *(/ektora Il.22.277; ou)de/ se lh/sei 23.326; ou) lh=qe *dio\s pukino\n no/on 15.461, cf. Od.11.102, al.; [tou=ton] ou)k e)/sti laqei=n o)/mmata fwto/s A.Ag. 796 (anap.); ou) la/qei m' o)rga/ S.El.222 (lyr.), cf. Ph.207 (lyr.); touti/ m' e)lelh/qein Ar.Nu.380; ei) lanqa/nei se perhaps you
don't know, Men. Sam.78: impers., lelhqe/nai ou) qauma/zw to\ plh=qos peri\ tou/tou it
escaped the notice of the people, X.Hier.2.5; se\ de\ le/lhqen peri\ tou=to w(s . . Pl. Lg.903c. most freq. with a part. added, in which case we usually translate the part. by a Verb, and express lanqa/nw by an Adv.,
unawares, without being observed; either, c. acc. pers., a)/llon tina\ lh/qw marna/menos I
am unseen by others while fighting, i.e. 1 fight
unseen by them, Il.13.273; pa/ntas e)la/nqane da/krua lei/bwn Od.8.93, cf. 12.17, 220, 19.88, al., Pi.O.1.64, 6.36, Hdt.8.25: freq. in Trag. and Att., mh\ la/qh| me prospesw/n lest he come on
unseen by me, S.Ph.46, cf. 156 (lyr.); o(/pws mh\ lh/sousin au)tou\s ai( nh=es . . a)formhqei=sai should put to sea
without their observing them, Th.8.10; or, without an acc., fone/a e)la/nqane bo/skwn he maintained the murderer
unawares, Hdt.1.44; le/lhqas e)xqro\s w)/n S.OT415; douleu/wn le/lhqas Ar.V. 517; sune/bh de\ u(perhme/rw| genome/nw| laqei=n D.21.89: the reflex. Pron. may be supplied and is sts. added, le/lhqen au(to\n toi=s cunou=sin w)\n baru/s S.Fr.103; e(/ws sauto\n la/qois diarragei/s Ar.Pax32, cf. Nu.242, X.An.6.3.22: sts., however, a different object must be supplied from the context, ba/llontes e)la/nqanon (not e(autou/s, but *trw=as) Il. 13.721; e)la/nqane [pa/ntas] e)/xwn Hdt.8.5; mh\ diafqarei\s la/qh| [tina\ o( bi/os] S.Ph.506; mh\ la/qh| [h(ma=s] fu/gda ba/s A.Eu.256 (lyr.), cf. Th. 4.133, etc.—In a few examples this constr. is reversed, and laqw/n is put in the part., as in our idiom, a)po\ tei/xeos a)=lto laqw/n (for e)/laqen a(lo/menos) Il.12.390; h(\ . . lh/qousa/ m' e)ce/pines S.Ant.532. rarely c. acc. et inf., mh/ se laqe/tw u(pertiqe/men
let it not
escape thee to . . , i.e.
forget not to . . , Pi.P.5.23; e)/laqen au)to\n su/nqhma dou=nai Plu.Arist. 17; sfa=s le/lhqe *qeo/dwron ei)=nai
it has been unnoticed that it was . . , Paus.9.41.1. folld. by a relat. clause, ou)de/ me lh/qeis, o(/tti qew=n ti/s s' h)=ge thou
escapest me not,
it is not
unknown to me, that some god led thee, Il.24.563; ou)de/ e( lh/qei, o(/ppws . . 23.323; e)do/kees qeou\s lh/sein oi(=a e)mhxanw= thou thought'st to
escape the gods'
notice in . . , Hdt.8.106; ou)/koun me . . oi(=a pra/tteis lanqa/nei Ar.Eq.465; ou) lanqa/neis me, o(/ti . . X.Mem.3.5.24, cf. Smp.3.6, 13; o( gei/twn l. tina\ ou) mo/non o(/ti pra/ttei, a)ll' ei) . . Pl.Tht.174b. abs.,
escape notice or
detection, S.Tr.455, Th.1.37, 69, al.; la/qe biw/sas Epicur.Fr.551; lanqa/nei to\ ou)=ron prospi=pton Hp.Coac.464. causal,
make one forget a thing, c. gen. rei, in compds. e)klhqa/nw, e)pi-lh/qw; the simple Verb only in Ep. redupl. aor. 2, o)/fra . . lela/qh| o)duna/wn that . . he
may cause him
to forget his pains, Il.15.60; po/lin lela/qoite suntuxia=n Lyr.Adesp.140.9: but in late Ep., le/laqon, = e)/laqon,
escaped notice of, e(o\n no/on, tokh=as, A.R.2.226, 3.779, cf. Orph.A.876. Med. and Pass.,
let a thing
escape one, forget,
forget simply, in pres. (abs.), su\ de\ lh/qeai Il.11.790: c. gen., *ki/rkhs me\n e)fhmosu/nhs . . lanqano/mhn Od.12.227, cf. Pi.O.8.72; ou)/ pote lh/somai au)tw=n Od.1.308; a)/lgos, ou(= pot' ou) lelh/setai E.Alc.198: mostly in aor. 2, a)lkh=s laqe/sqai A.Supp.731; no/stou te laqe/sqai Od.9.97; pw=s a)\n . . *)odush=os . . laqoi/mhn; 1.65: also in redupl. aor., ou)de\ se/qen . . qeoi\ ma/kares lela/qonto Il.4.127; mh/ ti/s moi a)peila/wn lelaqe/sqw 16.200; ou) duna/mhn lelaqe/sq' *)/aths 19.136 (but in Hes.Th.471 like the Act., o(/pws lela/qoito tekou=sa that she might bear
unknown): so in pf., tw=n de\ le/lastai Il.5.834; e)mei=o lelasme/nos 23.69; kei/nou lelh=sqai S. El.342, etc.; e(tai/rwn pa/ntwn le/lhstai Pl.Phdr.252a: with a relat. clause, lelasme/nos o(/ss' e)pepo/nqei Od.13.92: fut. Med. in pass. sense, once in S., ou)de/ pote lhso/menon oi(=on e)/fu kako/n never
will be forgotten, El.1249 (lyr.); cf. e)pilanqa/nw.
forget purposely, pass over, h)\ la/qet' h)\ ou)k e)no/hsen either he
chose to forget it . . , Il.9.537; maqou=sin au)dw=, kou) maqou=si lh/qomai A.Ag.39. in later writers fut. Med. is used like Act.,
escape notice, h(ma=s Arist.APr.66a31, cf. A.R.3.737, Luc.Sacr.14: abs., Alciphr.3.52.
lani/zei: lagga/nei, bre/xei, Hsch. lano\n kh=r: sofwta/th yuxh/, Id. lano/n: li/qon, Id. la_no/s, Dor. for lhno/s.
*la/notros, o(, name of a month at Tauromenium, IG14.427 ii 1, al.

la/c, Adv.
with the foot, l. e)n sth/qesi ba\s e)ce/spase mei/linon e)/gxos Il. 6.65, cf. 16.503; l. prosba/s 5.620, 16.863; l. podi\ kinh/sas 10.158, Od.15.45; l. e)/nqoren 17.233; l. d' e)f' o(rki/ois e)/bh Archil.Supp.2.13; so later bou=s moi e)pi\ glw/sshs kraterw=| podi\ l. e)pibai/nwn Thgn.815; l. e)pi/ba dh/mw| Id.847; l. patei=sqai (cf. la/gdhn) to be trodden
under foot, A.Eu.110, Ch.644 (lyr.); a)qe/w| podi\ l. a)ti/sai Id.Eu.542 (lyr.); l. e)porou/sas plh=ce A.R.2.106; pai/ei te l. pu/c Philem.1.6 D.: also in late Prose, Luc.Asin.31, al.:—for the form cf. gnu/c, pu/c, o)da/c.

lac-ei/a, h(,
quarrying, POxy.498.6 (ii A. D.).

la/c-euma, atos, to/,
hewn work in stone, Anon.Prog. in Rh.1.640 W.

la/c-eusis, ews, h(,
cutting of stone, Sch.Theoc.6.18.

lac-euth/rion, to/,
stone-cutter's tool, LXX Ps.73(74).7.

lac-euth/s, ou=, o(,
stone-hewer, Man.1.77.

lac-eutiko/s, h/, o/n,
of or
for a stone-cutter or
his art, diabh/ths Eust.341.28; h( l. te/xnh Anon.Prog. in Rh.1.640 W., Phot.

lac-euto/s, h/, o/n,
hewn out of the rock, LXX De.4.49, Ev.Luc.23.53.

lac-eu/w,
hew in stone, LXX Ex. 34.1, al.; also,
hew wood, ib.Is.9.10(9):—Pass., e)k li/qwn lelaceume/nwn ib.Ju.1.2, cf. J.AJ12.7.6.

lac-iko/s, h/, o/n, = laceutiko/s, POxy.498.34 (ii A. D.). lacika/, ta/,
tax on stone-cutting, PFay.44.6 (i B. C.).

la/c-imos, h, on,
hewn, PLond.3.856.30 (i A. D.).

la/cis (not la=cis), ios, h(, (laxei=n) Ion. for lh=cis (A),
that which is assigned by lot, an allotment of land, Hdt.4.21; moi/rhs l. SIG57.35 (Miletus, v B. C.); so prob. kai/ sfe teh\n e)kri/nao la/cin Call.Jov.80.
la/comai, Ion. for lh/comai, fut. of lagxa/nw.

laco/os, o(, contr. from laoco/os, prob. in Timo 25.1: in pass. sense, la/coos
hewn from stone, S.Fr.212 (lyr.).
laco/s, v. laoco/os. lacpa/thtos, v. lakpa/thtos.

la_o-bo/teira, h(,
feeder of the people, gai=a Orph.L.714.
la_o-bo/tos, on, （bo/skw） = laotro/fos, Hsch.

la_ogra^f-e/w,
enrol in the class subject to poll-tax, only in Pass., POxy.711.3 (i B. C.), etc.

la_ogra^f-i/a, h(,
enrolment, census, LXX 3 Ma.2.28;
assessment for poll-tax, kat' a)/ndra PTeb.103.1 (i B. C.), al.; later,
poll-tax, BGU1613 B ii 7 (i A. D.), etc.

la_o/gra^f-os, o(,
officer in charge of enrolments, Sammelb.4299.1 (iii A. D.).

la_o-da/ma_s [da^], antos, o(,
subduer of peoples, *)/arhs A.Th.343 (lyr.). in Hom. only as pr.n., Il.15.516; voc. -da/ma_ Od.8.141, 153.

la_o/-di^kos, on,
tried by the people, sofi/h Socr. ap. D.L.2.42.

la_o-dogma^tiko/s, h/, o/n,
suited to public opinion, popular, a)pofa/seis prob.l. in Plb.34.5.14, cf. 34.1.6, 34.12.2. Adv. -kw=s f.l. ibid.

la_o-do/kos, on,
receiving the people, dub. in IG7.53.12 (Megara) = Simon.107.10 (damodo/kwn Bgk.); in Hom. as pr. n. *lao/dokos (proparox.).
*laoi/tas, title of Zeus at Elis, Paus.5.14.4, 5.24.1.

la_o-ka^ta/ra_tos [a^r], on,
accursed by the people, Sm.Pr.11.26.

la_o-kra^te/omai, Pass.,
liveunder mob-rule: and la_o-kra^ti/a, h(,
mob-rule, Men.Rh. p.359 S.

la_o-kri/ths [i^], ou, o(,
judge in native court in Egypt, Mitteis Chr.8.12 (iii B. C.), 31 vii 3 (ii B. C.), PTeb.5.216 (ii B. C.).

la_o-me/dwn, ontos, o(,
ruler of the people, in Hom. as pr. n.
la=|on, v. la/i+on.

la_oco/os, o(, (la=as, ce/w)
sculptor, Ptol.Tetr.179, IG3.1308:—also laco/os (q.v.); laaco/s,
stone-cutter, PCair.Zen.172 (iii B. C.); laco/s, ib.176 (iii B. C.), PTeb.121.13 (i B. C.), etc.:—Adj. la_ocoi+ko/s, h/, o/n, skeu=os Hsch.s.v. o)/ruc, cf. Vett.Val.11.14.
laocourge/w, incorrect form for laceu/w, Sch.Od.14.223.

la_opa^qh/s, e/s,
suffered by the people, A.Pers.945 (lyr.).
lao/pais: bou/pais, Hsch. laopi/zein, coined as etym. of lapi/zein (q.v.), tou\s laou\s ei)s o)/pin a)/gein . . dia\ th=s a)lazonei/as, Id.

la_o-pla/nos [pla^], o(,
misleader of the people, J.AJ8.8.5 (pl.).

la_o-po/ros, on,
serving as a passage for the people, man-conveying, l. maxanai/ a bridge, A.Pers.113 (lyr.).
laorgo/s: a)no/sios (Sicel), Hsch. (cf. lewrgo/s).

la_o/s, o(, Ion. lho/s Hippon.88, Hdt.5.42 (v.l. lao/n, which is in all Mss. in 4.148), cj. in Mimn.14.9; Att. lew/s, which is also used in Hdt.1.22, 8.136, while the form lao/s is sts. used in Trag., and once or twice even in Com. (v. infr. 1.3): also in Inscrr. and Pap. (v. infr.) and in late Prose, as Foed.Byz. ap. Plb.4.52.7 (pl.), Str.14.4.3 (pl.), Plu.2.1096b, etc. (both forms in pr. nn., *lewbw/ths Hdt.7.204, *labw/tas X.HG1.2.18, etc.). in Il., lao/s （laoi/) usu. means
men, i.e. soldiers, both of the whole army and smaller divisions, krito\s e)/greto l. *)axaiw=n 7.434; lao\n a)gei/rein 16.129; polu\n w)/lesa lao/n 2.115: pl., a(/ma tw=| ge . . a)/ristoi l. e(/pont' ib.578; sti/xes a)spista/wn l. 4.91; periphr., strato\s law=n ib.76; law=n e)/qnos 13.495; mostly including both
foot and horse, as 2.809; but sts. lao/s denotes
foot, as opp. horse, 7.342; also,
a land army, opp. a fleet, 4.76, 9.424, 10.14; also,
the common men, opp. their leaders, 2.365, 13.108; but in Od., laoi/, more rarely lao/s, almost always means
men or
people; as
subjects of a prince, e.g. 3.214, 305, al. (laoi/ is sts. so used in Il., e.g. 17.226, 24.611; laoi\ a)groiw=tai country-
folk, 11.676;
work-people, 17.390); of
sailors, Od.14.248; so after Hom., nautiko\s lew/s seafaring
folk, A.Pers.383; pa=s o( xeirw=nac lew/s S.Fr.844; o( gewrgiko\s lew/s Ar.Pax920 (lyr.): in sg.,
slave, to\n *eu)rusqe/ws lew/n, of Heracles, Hecat.23 J.; and so perh. lew\s au)/toikos GDI5533e (Zeleia): more generally, me/ropes laoi/, i.e.
mankind, A.Supp.90 (lyr.); l. e)gxw/rioi the natives, ib. 517, cf. Od.6.194; esp. in Egypt, of the fellahin, PRev.Laws42.11-16 (iii B. C.), PSI4.380.5 (iii B. C.), etc.;
civil population, opp. priests and soldiers, OGI90.12 (Rosetta, ii B. C.), cf. 225.8 (Milet., iii B. C.), al.
people assembled, as in the theatre, o( polu\s law=n o)/xlos Ar.Ra.676, cf. 219 (both lyr.); esp. in the Ecclesia, ai( sti/xes tw=n law=n Id.Eq.163: hence the phrase a)kou/ete lew/| hear
O people!—the usual way of beginning proclamations at Athens, like our Oyez! Sus.1.1, Ar.Pax551, Av.448; timw=sin oi( pa/ntes lew/| ib. 1275; deu=r' i)/te, pa/ntes lew/| Arist.Fr.384; *)attiko\s lew/s A.Eu.681; o( polu\s lew/s
the multitude, Pl.R.458d, etc. in LXX, of
the
people, as opp. priests and Levites, 1 Es.5.46; in NT, of Jews, opp. Gentiles, Ev.Matt.2.6, Ev.Luc.2.10, al., cf. SIG1247 (Jewish tombstones); of Christians, opp. heathen, Act.Ap.15.14, al.
a people, i.e. all who are called by one name, first in Pi., *dwriei= law=| O.8.30; *ludw=n de\ lao\s kai\ *frugw=n A.Pers.770; cu/mpas *)axaiw=n lao/s S.Ph.1243, cf. OT144, etc.; i(ppo/tai laoi/, i.e. the Thessalians, Pi. P.4.153, cf. 9.54, N.1.17. (The resemblance between lao/s
people and la=os
stone (cf. la=as) is implied in Il.24.611 laou\s de\ li/qous poi/hse *kroni/wn (in the story of Niobe); and so Pi. explains the word from the legend of Deucalion, O.9.46, cf. Epich.122, Apollod.1.7.2; but cf. Philoch.12.) (From la_v-, as shown by the pr.names *lavopto/lemos GDI3151, vio/lavos ib.3132 (Corinth): hence prob. lh/i+ton.)

la=os, irreg. gen. of la=as. la=os, o(,
stone, v. la=as.

la_o-sebh/s, e/s,
worshipped by the people, h(/rws Pi.P.5.95.

la_o-sso/os, on, (seu/w)
rousing or
stirring the nations, epith. of the war-deities Ares, Eris, Il.17.398, 20.48; of Athena, 13.128, Od.22.210; of Apollo, Il.20.79: also of men, as Amphiaraus, Od.15.244; of Electryon, Amphitryon, Hes.Sc.3,37; laosso/oi a)gw=nes assemblies
to which the people flock, Pi.P.12.24.

la_o-te/ktwn, onos, o(,
stone-worker, AP7.380 (Crin.).

la_o-ti/naktos [i^], on,
stirred by a stone, u(/dwr ib.9.272 (Bianor).

la_o-tome/w,
hew stone, Sammelb.4279 (i A. D.).

la_o-to/mos, on,
stone-cutting, o)/rgana Men.Prot. ap. Suid.s.v. spali/wn. = lato/mos, Man.6.416, Epigr.Gr.1021 (Antinoe), AJA7.47 (Corinth), POxy.134.16 (vi A. D.); l. pe/trhs Man.4.325.

la_otro/fos, on,
nourishing or
tending the people, po/lis Pi.O.5.4; tima\ l. an office
useful to the people, ib.6.60.

la_otu/pos [u^], on,
cutting stones, smi=lai AP7.429.3 (Alc.). as Subst.,
stone-cutter, statuary, APl.4.59 (Agath.).

la_o-fqo/ros, on,
ruining the people, destructive, c.gen., sta/sis *(ellh/nwn l. Thgn.781.

la_o-fo/nos, on,
slaying the people, do/ru B.12.120; *diomh/dhs Theoc.17.53; ci/fos IG14.1294.

la_o-fo/ros and lewfo/ros, on,
bearing people, laofo/ron kaq' o(do/n on
a highway, thoroughfare, Il.15.682; laofo/rou e)pe/bhsan . . keleu/qou Theoc.25.155; u(pe\r tw=n ma/lista lewfo/rwn (v.l. laof-) pule/wn over the gates of greatest
thoroughfare, Hdt.1.187. Subst., l. (sc. o(do/s), h(,
highway, ta\s lewfo/rous mh\ badi/zein Pythag. ap. Porph.VP42, Ael.VH4.17, cf. Iamb.Protr. 21.d/, D.L.8.17; lewfo/rous pro\s e)ktropa/s E.Rh.881 (laof- codd.; lewfo/rou
from the highway, cj. Vater); tw=n e)k th=s xw/ras l. ei)s th\n po/lin . . tetame/nwn Pl.Lg.763c, cf. Ph.1.16, Paus.9.2.2, Jul.Or.6.184d, 7.225c, and v. lew/batos. lewfo/ros, h(, = po/rnh, Anacr.157. [lew- as monosyll. in E.l.c.]

la/pagma [la^], atos, to/, and la^pagmo/s, o(,
evacuation, Hsch.
la^padno/s, o/n, metri gr.for a)lapadno/s, restored by Musgrave in A. Eu.562.
la^pa/zein: e)kkenou=n, a)f' ou(= kai\ to\ o)/rugma, Hsch. (cf. lapa/ssw).

la^pa^qoeidh/s, e/s,
like a dock or
sorrel leaf, fu/lla f.l. in Ps.-Dsc.2.166.

la/pa^qon [la^], to/,
monk's rhubarb, Rumex Patientia, Epich.161, Thphr.HP7.1.2, al.; l. a)/grion
dock, Rumex conglomeratus, ib.7.6.1, Dsc.2.114:—also la/paqos, o( or h(, Thphr.HP1.6.6, al., EM57.17 (fem. in Steph.in Rh.311.32); and lapa/qh, h(, EM551.15.
pitfall for wild beasts, Phot., Suid.:—also la/paqos, o(, Democr.122 (pl.).

la^paktiko/s, h/, o/n, (lapa/ssw)
laxative, Xenocr. ap. Orib.2.58.9, Gal.6.457, 11.711.

la/pacis [la^], ews, Ion. ios, h(,
evacuation of the bowels, Arist.Ph. 197b24, Pr.935b30, Gal.19.199; [u(ste/rhs] Aret.CA2.10.

la^pa/ra_ [pa^], Ep. and Ion. la_o/-rh, h(, (laparo/s)
the soft part of the body between the ribs and hip,
flank, Il.6.64, 16.318, al. (not in Od.), Epich.90, Hdt.2.86, etc.: pl.,
flanks, Id.6.75, Diocl.Fr.193, Hp. Flat.9, etc.; sg. also,
side of the chest, Id.Loc.Hom.14, Erot.:— lapa/ra and kenew/n are distd. by Hp.Morb.2.55, Int.17, Gal.18(2).762,764.
sausage or
haggis, AP9.486 (Pall.).

la^pa^r-o/s, a/, o/n,
slack, loose, to\ l. th=s pleurh=s, = lapa/ra, Hp.Art. 50; of the bowels, Id.Prog.11; laparo\s ei)leo/s, Id.Epid.2.6.26, Orib. 8.28.5; l. gi/nesqai have the bowels
opened, Arist.Pr.935b28; i(/ppos l. w)\n a)lgei= Id.HA604b16 (nisi leg. lapa/ras a)ne/lkei); of a dislocated joint, o)/pisqen laparo/n, e)/mprosqen e)ce/xon Hp.Mochl.24;
hollow, of a cushion, me/son kata\ mh=kos poih/santa laparo/n Id.Fract.16; pleure/wn o)du/nai laparai/, perh.
slight, Id.Epid.6.3.18 (so perh. l. ei)leo/s above). Adv. -rw=s, u(poxondri/ou e)/ntasis laparw=s, i.e. without swelling, ib. 3.1.b/ (opp. met' o)/gkou acc. to Gal.ad loc.).
lewd, lecherous, Hsch.

la^pa^r-o/ths, htos, h(,
looseness, of the bowels, Hp.Epid.4.45.

la^pa/ssw, Att. la^pa^/r-ttw,
empty, dia/rroiai . . th\n gaste/ra lapa/ssousai Hp.Prog.8; ou)k e)la/pacen ou)de/n
had no
evacuations, Id.Epid.4.31; ta\ par' ou)=s lapa/ssei
causes the tumours by the ear
to discharge, Id.Coac. 201, Prorrh.1.167:—Pass., esp. in aor. e)lapa/xqhn, of the bowels,
to be emptied, Id.VM11,
Acut.(Sp.）42, Arist.Pr.935b30: abs., e)lapa/sseto
internal relief took place, Hp.Epid.6.2.19: pf.inf. lelapa/xqai Ath.8.363a.
soften, o(/kws . . ta\ sklhruno/mena lapaxqh=| Hp.Ulc. 10.
sack a town (cf. a)lapa/zw）, lapa/cein a)/stu *kadmei/wn bi/a| A. Th.47,531, dub. in Id.Ag.130.

la/ph [a^], h(,
scum which forms on the surface of wine, vinegar, or other liquids left to stand, Erot.: la/mph in Dsc.5.76, Plu.2.1073a, Gal.16.704, Orib.Syn.9.13.2:—hence lampw=des, of urine,
with a scum on it, Hp.Coac.182, Prorrh.1.92; but Erot.read lapw=des, and lappw/dhs (a)po\ tou=

la/ppein) occurs in Gal.l.c.
phlegm, Hp.Morb.2.15, Int.12; mestoi\ la/phs Diph.17.15; cf. le/mfos. metaph., a)nhli/w| la/pa| (Wieseler for la/mpa|) in sunless
filth or
damp, of the nether world, A.Eu.387 (lyr.).

la^p-i/zw, = suri/zw, S.Fr.1062;
swagger, rodomontade, Cic.Att.9.13.4, AB277, Phot.; cf. laopi/zein.
la^p-ikth/s, = lapisth/s, Id.

la^/p-isma, atos, to/,
swaggering, boasting, Cic.Att.9.13.4.
la^p-i/ssw, Att. la^/p-ttw, = lapi/zw, Phot. (-h/ttein cod.).

la^p-isth/s, ou=, o(
swaggerer, LXX Si. 20.7:—fem. la^p-i/stria, Phot.
la/pos: qh/s, dou=los, Hsch. la/ppein, lappw/dhs, v. la/ph. la/ptas: tou\s r(ofou=ntas, Id. lapth/s, f.l. for la/phs, Id.

laptiko/s, h/, o/n,
fit for emptying (v. la/ptw sub fin.), Eust.1413.3.
laptuh/r: sfodrw=s ptu/wn, Hsch.

la/ptw, fut. -yw Il.16.161, (a)po-) Ar.Nu.811: aor. e)/laya
Epic. Alex.Adesp. 1.10, LXX Jd.7.5, (e)c-) Ar.Ach.1229: pf. le/la^fa Id.Fr. 598:—Med., fut. la/yomai （e)k-) Id.Pax885: aor. e)laya/mhn Pherecr. 95:—
lap with the tongue, of wolves, la/yontes glw/ssh|sin . . me/lan u(/dwr Il.l.c., cf. LXX l.c., Plu.2.971a; pi/nei ta\ karxaro/donta la/ptonta Arist.HA595a7; th=| glw/tth| l. Ael.NA6.53; cf. ka/ptw.
drink greedily, ai(=ma le/lafas Ar.Fr.l.c., cf. Epic.Alex.Adesp.l.c.; oi)=non Ath. 10.443e:—also in Med., lepasth\n layame/nois
gulp down, Pherecr. l.c.—In Ath.8.363a lapa/ttein shd. be restored for la/ptein, unless it was an error of the writer, as in Eust.1413.3.
lapw/dhs, v. la/ph.
la/rba^son, to/, = sti/bi, Dsc.5.84.

lardhgo/s, o(,
purveyor of salted meat, OGI521.25 (Abydos, v/vi A. D.).

la/rdos, o(,
salted meat, Lyd.Mens.4.92, Hero
*Stereom.2.54,
PLond. ined.2147 (iv A. D.).
lari/eqos: flo/i+non stega/strion, Hsch.

la/rimnon, to/, Arabic name for
frankincense, Str.16.4.19:—written la/rimnan by Agatharch.101.

la_ri_no/s, h/, o/n,
fatted, fat, tau=ros Xenoph.6.2; bou=s Ar.Pax925; su/es Eratosth.20: metaph., l. e)/pos Ar.Av.465:—hence la_ri_neu/omai,
grow fat, Sophr.104.

la/ri^nos [a_], o(, a kind of
sea-fish, Opp.H.3.399 (v.l. la/rimos), Hsch.:—hence la_ri^nai=on ku/rton: oi( a(liei=s to\n e)k le<u>ke/as, h)\ me/gan, Id.:—la_ri^neuth/s, ou=, o(, = a(lieu/s, Id.

la/ric, ikos, h(,
larch, Larix europaea, Plin.HN16.43.
Venice turpentine, terebinthina veneta, Dsc.1.71, Gal.13.410, al.; =
coagulum, Gloss. [la^ri^ces, Lucan.9.920, of the trees.]
la^ri/s, i/dos, h(, = la/ros, AP7.652 (Leon.), 654 (Id.).

*la/ri_sa [a_r], h( (not *la/rissa, v. Arc.77.14, IG9(2).60.5, 525.5, al., but *larisse/ois ib.9(2).6c3), Larissa, a name of many old Greek cities, Il.2.841, etc.; Pelasgic acc. to Str.9.5.19, 13.3.2: an Ion. form *lh/risai (in Aeolis) occurs in Hdt.1.149; orig. it denoted a
citadel, such as
the Larissa of Argos, St.Byz., Sch.A.R.1.40. Adj. *la_ri_sai=os, a, on,
Larissaean, of or
from Larissa, Th.2.22, X.HG 3.1.7, etc.; Ion. *lhris- Hdt.9.1 and 58:—also *lari/sios and *larishno/s as epith. of Zeus, Str.9.5.19, 13.3.2. *la_ri_sai=oi e(<*>hth=res Larissaean pots for boiling, AP6.305 (Leon.); la_ri_sopoioi/ for larisaiopoioi/, either
makers of Larissaean pots, or
makers of Larissaean citizens, of the dhmiourgoi/ (magistrates), Gorg. ap. Arist.Pol.1275b30.

lark-a^gwgo/s, o(,
coal-basket carrier, o)/nos E.Fr.283 (troch.).
lark-i/dion, to/, Dim. of la/rkos, Ar.Ach.340:—also lark-i/on, Poll.10.111.

la/rk-os, o(,
charcoal-basket, Ar.Ach.333, Alex.208, Lys.Fr.139 S. (Dissim. fr. na/rkos, cf. narki/on.)

larkofore/w,
carry a la/rkos, D.C.52.25.
larna/kion, to/, Dim. of la/rnac, Sm.1 Ki.6.8, Sammelb.5939.3 (Cyrenaica).

larna^ko/-guios, on, epith. of Pan, apptly. from a pun on xhlh/,
hoof, and xhlo/s, = la/rnac, Theoc.Syrinx16.

larna^ko-fqo/ros, on,
killing in a box or
chest, Lyc.235.

la/rnac, a^kos, h(, (rarely o(, v. infr. 3)
coffer, box, chest, e.g. for household stores, Il.18.413, Hdt.3.123; l. daidale/a B.5.141, cf. Simon. (v. infr.).
cinerary urn or
coffin, [o)ste/a] xrusei/hn e)s la/rnaka qh=kan Il.24.795; la/rnakas kuparissi/nas a)/gousin a)/macai . . : e)/nesti de\ ta\ o)sta= ktl. Th.2.34, cf. CIG4003,4007 (Iconium), 4441 (Adana), al.; the
ark of Deucalion, Plu.2.968f, Luc.Syr.D.12, Apollod.1.7.2; of the Ark, AP1.62 (Christian); esp. an
ark in which children were exposed, Simon.37.1, A.R.1.622, D.S.5.62, etc.
drinking trough, o( l. ou(=tos IG12(1).961 (Chalce). (Dissim. fr. na/rnac, q.v.)

la^roeidh/s, e/s, (la/ros)
like a sea-mew, Tz.ad.Lyc.76.

la/ros [a^], o(, a ravenous sea-bird, perh.
sea-mew, gull, Od.5.51, Arist.HA542b17, 593b3: hence, metaph., of greedy demagogues, as Cleon, l. kexhnw\s e)pi\ pe/tras dhmhgorw=n Ar.Eq.956; *kle/wna to\n l. dw/rwn e(lo/ntes Id.Nu.591, cf. Av.567, Matro Conv.9, Timocl.4.9; also of fools, Luc.Tim.12, Sch.Ar.Pl.913.

la_ro/s, o/n, poet. Adj.
pleasant to the taste, dainty, sweet, in Hom. always of taste, laro\n para\ dei=pnon e)/qhkas Il.19.316; laro\n tetukoi/meqa do/rpon Od.12.283, 14.408; laro/n te/ oi( ai(=m' a)nqrw/pou
sweet to it [the fly] is the blood of man, Il.17.572; me/qu laro/n A.R.1.456: Ep. Sup. larw/tatos, oi)=nos Od.2.350: Comp. laro/teron as Adv., Simon. 183.10.
pleasant to the smell, a)u+tmh/ Mosch.2.92; a)/nqea lara\ fu/ois IG14.1362; laro\n o)/dwden D.P.936.
pleasant to the eye, lovely, AP9.525.12; a)/nqemal. ib.15.11 = IG12(1).783 (Lindos).
pleasant to the ear, sweet to hear, e)/pos A.R.3.933, AP7.602 (Agath.); lara\ fqe/gcato *bakxuli/dhs ib.9.571; l. xei/lea
uttering sweet sounds, APl.4.226 (Alc.). [As ^ ^ can always be substituted for la_- in Hom. and the Sup. is -w/tatos, la_ro/s is prob. contr. fr. la^a^ro/s or la^ero/s (this perh. fr. lav-, cf. a)po-lau/w).]
*la/rtios, o(, Trag. for *lae/rths (q.v.).

la/rtios, a, on, name of a hard Rhodian stone, pe/tra SIG581.98 (Hierapytna, iii/ii B.C.); li/qos IG12(1).2.7, cf. 677.7, 1033.22; sta/la (i.e. made of such stone) Supp.Epigr.3.674.9 (Rhodes, ii B.C.).
la^rugg-ia/w, = sq. 1, bragxa\ laruggio/wn AP11.382.2 (Agath.).

la^rugg-i/zw,
shout lustily, D.18.291, Phld.Rh.1.200 S., Luc.Am.36; of the raven,
croak, Anon. ap. Suid.: c. acc. cogn.,
bawl out, ta/de Ath.9.383f. trans.,
outdo in shouting, laruggiw= tou\s r(h/toras Ar.Eq. 358; acc. to others,
will cut their
throats, v. Sch.

la^rugg-iko/s, h/, o/n,
gluttonous, Pherecr.32.
la^ru/gg-ion, to/, Dim. of la/rugc, Gal.14.474.

la^rugg-ismo/s, o(,
croaking, Plu.2.129a (pl.).
la^rugg-o/s: mataiolo/gos, Hsch.

la^ruggo-tome/w,
cut open the windpipe, Gal.14.734, Paul.Aeg.6.33:
la^ruggo-tomi/a, h(, ibid.

la^ruggo/-fwnos, on,
sounding from the throat, Sopat.16.

la/rugc [a^], uggos, o(,
larynx or
upper part of the windpipe, Arist. HA493a6; used in sounding the vowels, ib.535a32: but in Poets confused with fa/rugc (gullet) (cf. Arist.HA535a29), E.Cyc.158; xwrei=n kata\ tou= l. Pherecr.108.7, cf. Crobyl.8; of gluttons, a)no/sioi la/rugges Eub.139; e)k tou= l. e)kkrema/sas tina/ Ar.Eq.1363; to\n la/rugg' a)\n e)kte/moimi/ sou Id.Ra.575: metaph., l. gluku/s
speech, LXX Si.6.4. = traxei=a a)rthri/a, Meno Iatr.8.30.
larudoi/: stu=loi oi( e)n tw=| a)ro/trw|, Hsch. laru/zei: boa=|, a)po\ tou= la/ruggos, Id.

la^ru/nw,
coo like a dove, Anon.
devoc.animal. in Stud.Ital.1.95, 3.496.

larwntidw=n: e)n toi=s a)qroi/smasin e)/legon, w(s e)pw|dw=n, Hsch. la=s, = la=as, Id.; v. lastruguli/as. la/sa: tra/peza plhresta/th, Id. *la/sa, = *la/risa, Id.: Adj. *lasai=os IG9(2).517.19. la/sagges: oi( peri\ ta\s *li/mnas xlwroi\ ba/traxoi, Hsch.

la/sa^na [la^], ta/, (cf. la/ana) always in pl.,
trivet or
stand for a pot, Ar.Pax893 (ubi v. Sch.), Diocl.Com.8.
night-stool, Hp.Fist. 9, Cratin.49 (cj. Mein. for laxa/nois), Pherecr.88, Eup.224, Ar.Fr. 462: also in sg., like Lat.
lasanum, Hp.Superf.8, AP11.74.8 (Nicarch.):—hence la^sa^nofo/ros, o(,
slave who had charge of the night-stool, Plu.2.182c, 360d:—also la^sa^ni/ths [i_] di/fros BGU1116.25 (i B.C.).

la/saron (= o)po\s drimu/s, Hsch.) or la/sar, to/, = o)po\s silfi/ou,
asafoetida, Hippiatr.3, Aët.1.306, 15.5, Alex.Trall.12: Dim. lasa/rion, to/, Aët.8.61, Gloss.
lasa/sqw: xleuaze/tw, Hsch.
la/seios, on, prob. = la/sios, delmatikh\ l. Edict.Diocl.19.30.
la_seu=mai, Dor. fut. Med. of lanqa/nw. lasqai/nein: kakologei=n, Hsch.

la/sqh, h(,
mockery, insult, = Att. xleu/h, e)pi\ ge/lwti/ te kai\ la/sqh| Hdt.6.67, cf. AP7.345.
lasqh=men, Dor. aor. inf. Pass. of lanqa/nw. la/sqon: ai)sxro/n, Hsch. la/sqw: xleuaze/tw, and la/sqwn: kakologw=n, Id.

la^si^au/xhn, enos, o(, h(, (la/sios)
with rough, shaggy neck, of the centaur, h.Merc.224, cf. lasiau/xena xai/tan Ar.Ra.822 (lyr.); of the bear, h.Hom.7.46; of the horse, S.Ant.350 (lyr.); l. bu/rsa Theoc. 25.272: also with a neut., lasiau/xenos a)/ntrou v.l. Id.Ep.5.5.
lasideu/s: qrasu/s, a)/plhstos, Hsch. lasi=nos: a)/frwn, e)pilh/smwn, Id.

la^si^o/-qric, tri^xos, o(, h(,
shaggy, Opp.H.4.369, Nonn.D.38.359, Orph.Fr.169.

la^si^o/-knhmos, on,
hairy-legged, Opp.C.2.186.

la^si^o/-kwfos, on,
deaf from hair growing in the ears, cited from Pl. (Phdr. 253e) by Synes.67d, Phot., Suid., from a false reading, found in cod. B.

la^sio/ma_lon: mh=lon to\ e)/xon xnou=n, Hsch.:—hence la^si/mhlon, to/,
peach, shd. perh. be read in Antig.Car. ap. Ath.3.82b (h( d' a)rimh/lwn codd.).

la/sion [a^], to/,
a rough cloth, Sapph.89 (pl.); la/sion e)pibeblhme/nos Theopomp.Com.36, cf. Artem. Gramm. ap. Erot.; perh. to be read for si/alon in Hp.
Acut. (Sp.）37.

la^si^o/pous, poun, gen. podos,
shaggy-footed, Aesop.238.

la/si^os [a^], a, on, later also os, on Luc.Prom.12, etc. (cf. la/seios):—
shaggy, woolly, of sheep, Il.24.125, Od.9.433; l. qh=res, of sheep and goats, opp. deer (stiktoi\ q.), S.Ph.184 (lyr.); me/lissai Theoc.22.42; ta\ -w/tata, of horses, X.Eq.2.4; in men, l. kh=r was in the heroic age a mark of strength, Il.2.851, 16.554, cf. Pl.Tht.194e; e)n . . sth/qessin lasi/oisi, of Achilles, Il.1.189; to\ sth=qos e)painei=n xrh\ tetra/gwno/n te e)o\n kai\ l. Hp.Prorrh.2.7; whereas afterwards a hairy breast was looked upon as a sign of dissoluteness or coarseness, Ar.Nu. 349; or of intrigue and cunning, *)agaqoklei=os la/siai fre/nes h)/lasan e)/cw patri/dos Alex.Aetol.5; also l. kefalh/ Pl.Ti.76c; peri\ w)=ta l. Id.Phdr.253e; l. ta\ ske/lh Luc.DDeor.4.1; l. o)fru/s Theoc.11.31; mhrw=n tri/xes AP11.326 (Autom.); to\ l.
hairiness, Luc.DMar.1.1. Adv. tw=n o)fru/wn -i/ws e)/xein Philostr.VS2.1.7. generally,
bushy, overgrown, ai)/hs la/sion me/nos Emp.27.2; xwri/on X.HG4.2.19, cf. Pl.Cra.420e; drumo/s Theoc.25.134; dru=s Id.26.3; e)k tw=n l. ta\ qhri/a e)cela=n X.Cyr.1.4.16; dia\ tw=n l. e)pigeno/menoi Id.An.6.4.26: c. dat.,
overgrown with . . , gh= u(/lais la/sios Luc.Prom.l.c.

la^si^o/-sternos, on,
hairy-breasted, parda/lies AP7.578 (Agath.).

la^si^o/-ths, htos, h(,
shagginess, Eust.1638.39.
la^si^o/-tri^xos, on, = lasio/qric, Opp.C.1.474.
lasiourgi/as: i(stourgi/as, dhmiourgi/as, Hsch. (i.e. talas-).

la^si/ofrus, u, gen. uos,
with bushy eyebrows, Hsch.s.v. mela/nofrus. la^si^oxai/ths, ou, o(,
with shaggy hair, Hdn.Epim.166.
*lasi/smata: w(s sofistou= tou= *la/sou kai\ poluplo/kou, Hsch. lasito/s: ki/naidos, h)\
lesito/s: po/rnh, Id. (cf. lai/sitos). lasixneu/ousa: planwme/nh (Sicel), Id.

la^si^-w/n, w=nos, o(, (la/sios 11)
thicket, Nic.Th.28, 489.
la^si^-w=tis, idos, fem. Adj., = lasi/a, lasiw/tidos u(/lhs Epic.Alex.Adesp.9 vi 20.
laska/zei: fluarei=, qwpeu/ei, Hsch.

la/skw, impf. e)/laskon E.El.1214 (lyr.): fut. la^kh/somai Ar.Pax381, 384: aor. 1 e)la/khsa [a^] ib.382 (dia-la_kh/sas Id.Nu.410 is prob. from diala_ke/w, Dor. for -lhke/w): aor. 2 e)/la^kon, Ep. la/kon Il.14.25, al.: aor. 1 e)/lhca Herod.8.65: pf. le/lhka Il.22.141, Arist.HA618b31, le/la_ka A.Pr.407 (lyr.), Ar.Ach.410 (paratrag.); part. fem. lela^kui=a Od.12.85:—Med., v. infr. 11:—
ring, rattle, crash: of things,
ring when struck, la/ke xalko\s nussome/nwn ci/fesi/n te kai\ e)/gxesi Il. 14.25; la/ke d' a)spi/s 20.277; also la/ke d' o)ste/a the bones
cracked, broke with a crash, 13.616; la/ke d' a)mfi\ puri\ u(/lh
crackled, Hes. Th. 694; e)/lakon a)co/nwn briqome/nwn xno/ai
creaked under the weight, A.Th. 153 (lyr.):—this sense occurs only in aor. 2 Act. of animals,
scream, of the falcon, o)cu\ lelhkw/s Il.22.141; of the nightingale in the falcon's talons, ti/ le/lhkas; Hes.Op.207; also, of dogs,
howl, bay, *sku/llh . . deino\n lelakui=a Od.l.c.; rare in Prose, ou) minuri/zei ou)de\ le/lhken, of the black eagle, Arist.l.c.:—this sense occurs only in pf., exc. in Ep. aor. Med., ku/nes lela/konto h.Merc.145. of human beings,
shout, scream, cry aloud, le/lhken h)\n kai\ mhde/n' a)nqrw/pwn o(ra=| Semon.7.15; fo/bos muxo/qen e)/lake A.Ch.35 (lyr.), cf. S.Ant. 1094, etc.; ti/ le/lakas; Ar.Ach. l. c.; mh/ nun lakh/sh|s Id.Pax382: hence of Oracles,
utter, A.Ag.1426 (lyr.), S.Tr.824 (lyr.), Ar.Pl. 39; also,
sing, pro\s au)lo/n E.Alc.346. c. acc. cogn.,
shriek forth, utter aloud, o)lolugmo/n A.Ag.596; stono/en le/lake xw/ra Id. Pr.l.c.; l. boa/n E.El.l.c., cf. Ion776 (anap.); a)ggeli/as Id.IT461 (anap.); ph=ma A.Ag.865; r(h=ma gennai=on Ar.Ra.97: c. dupl. acc., toiau=ta la/skeis tou\s . . fi/lous; E.Andr.671:—in this sense only in Trag. and (rarely) Com.
laskwrei=: diafeu/gei, Hsch. lastagei=: yofei=, Id. la/stai: po/rnai, Id. lasta/rnh: ma/stic, Id.

lastauroka/kkabon, to/,
an aphrodisiac dish, Chrysipp. ap. Ath.1.9c.

la/stauros, o(, epith. of a ki/naidos, Theopomp.Hist.217 (
a), cf. AP 12.41 (Mel.); as general term of abuse, Phryn.173: lastri/s is cited as a Dim. in EM159.30.
la|sth/rion, v. lh|sth/rion. lastruguli/as: li/qos tetrimme/nos, Hsch. (Fort. la=s （= la=as） trumali/as.)
la_sw=, Dor. fut. of lanqa/nw.

la^ta^g-ei=on, to/,
the vessel into which the la/tac
falls, Suid.

la^ta^g-e/w,
throw the la/tages, l. kotta/bous Luc.Lex.3.
la^ta^/g-h, h(, = la/tac 1, Dicaearch.Hist.34 (Sicilian); but Thess. or Rhod.acc. to Clitarch. ap.Ath.15.666c.

la/tac [a^], a^gos, h(, usu. in pl. la/tages, in the game of ko/ttabos,
the drops of wine in the bottom of the cup which were thrown into a basin with a splash, la/tages pote/ontai kuli/xnan a)pu\ *thi/+an Alc.43; a)p' a)gku/lhs . . i(/hsi la/tagas Cratin.273, cf. Hermipp.47.7 (anap.), Critias 2.2 D., Call.Fr.102: so collectively in sg., canqh\ *)afrodisi/a l. S.Fr.277 (lyr.).
a water-quadruped, perh. beaver, Arist.HA487a22, 594b32.
lata/ssw, = latage/w, ti\n ta/nde lata/ssw (Dor.) Kretschmer Griech. Vaseninschr.p.87.

*la^tia/rios, o(, = Lat. Latiaris, epith. of Jupiter, D.H.4.49: *latia/ria, ta/,
the Latin festival, in honour of
Jupiter Latiaris, D.C.47.40.
*la^ti/nh [i_], h(, Latium, Plb.3.22.13, Str.5.3.10.

*la^ti_noh/qhs, es,
following Latin customs, Eust.1658.62.

*la^ti_nos, h, on, Latin, Thphr.HP5.8.1; e(ortai\ *l., = Lat.
feriae Latinae, D.H.4.49; h( *l. fwnh/, h( *l. dia/lektos, Str.6.1.6.

*la/tion [a^], to/, = Lat.
jus Latii, Str.4.1.12, 4.2.2.
latmenei/a: doulei/a, Hsch. (cf. a)tmeni/a).
*la/tmios, a, on, Latmian, *la/tmion knw/sseis (sc. u(/pnon), i.e. like Endymion on Latmos, Herod.8.10; cj. for la/qrion in Theoc.20.39.
*la_togenh/s, e/s, Dor. for *lhtogenh/s.

la_tom-ei=on, to/,
stone-quarry, Str.12.2.8:—written la_to/mion SIG 1182.12 (Ephes., iii B.C.), Str.5.3.10, 9.1.13, CIG2032, 2043; la_to/min AEM8.224 and 225.
la_tom-eu/w, = sq., PSI4.423.27 (iii B.C.).

la_tom-e/w,
quarry, gh=n Posidon.57 J.; pe/tran IG42(1).122.25 (Epid.), cf. D.S. 5.39; li/qous PCair.Zen.499.38 (iii B.C.), Antig.Mir.161: abs., PCair.Zen.296.34 (iii B.C.), Agatharch.25, J.AJ8.2.9:—Pass., lelato/mhtai PPetr.2p.12 (iii B.C.); ta\ -ou/mena qrau/mata D.S.3.12. l. la/kkon
hew it
out, LXXEx.21.33, cf. De.6.11 (Pass.).

la_to/m-hma, atos, to/,
stone hewn from a quarry, D.S.3.13.

la_tom-hto/s, h/, o/n,
hewn out of a rock, kli=mac Str.14.5.5, al. of stones,
hewn, LXX 4 Ki.12.12(13).

la_tom-i/a, h(,
quarrying of stone, PHib.71.7 (iii B.C.), IG42(1).102.17 (Epid.); tw=| strw/mati ib.40: mostly in pl., =
quarries, Man. ap.J.Ap.1.26, Str.8.5.7, AP11.253 (Lucill.); of
the quarries at Syracuse used as a prison, Plu.2.334c; also in sg., PCair.Zen.176.215 (iii B.C.).

la_tom-iko/s, h/, o/n,
for quarrying stones, si/dhros D.S.3.12.
la_to/m-ion, v. latomei=on.

la_tom-i/s, i/dos, h(,
stone-chisel, xalkai= l. Agatharch.29.

la_/tom-os (parox.), o(, (la=as, te/mnw)
quarry-man, stonecutter, IG4.823.50 (Troezen), PCair.Zen.499.2, al. (iii B.C.), LXX 3 Ki. 5.15 (29), J.AJ11.4.1, CIG(add.) 4528b (Lebanon).

la/tos, o(,
the great Nile perch, Perca (Lates) niloticus, Archestr.Fr. 51, Str.17.1.40, 47, 2.4.

latrabia/zein: e)spoudasme/nws kai\ a)sh/mws lalei=n, Hsch.; cf. latra/zein: barbari/zein, Id. latrabo/s, = lamuro/s, and latrabi/a (latrapi/a cod.), = lamuri/a meta\ e)ruqria/sews, Id.:—also latrabw=n: a)lazoneuo/menos, and e)latra/bizon: to\ bwmoloxeu/ein kai\ panourgei=n
latrabi/zein e)/legon, Id. latra/zein, v. latrabia/zein. latrai/w, v. latrei/w. la/tray: u(eto/s, Id.

latr-ei/a, h(,
the state of a hired labourer, service, A.Pr.966; e)pi/ponon e)/xein l. S.Tr.830 (lyr.): pl., oi(/as latrei/as a)nq' o(/sou zh/lou tre/fei Id.Aj.503, cf. E.Ph.225 (lyr.), etc.: metaph.,
the business or
duties of life, Plu.2.107c. l. tou= qeou=, qew=n,
service to the gods, divine
worship, Pl.Ap.23c, Phdr.244e (pl.): abs., LXX Ex.12.25, al., Ep.Rom.9.4, etc.
la/tr-eios, v. la/trios.

latr-ei/w,
render as offering, *di/ SIG9 (Pass., Olympia, vi B.C.):—also latr-ai/w, prob. in Inscr.Olymp. 1.7. (Both Elean for latreu/w, from -hv-
yw.)

la/tr-euma, atos, to/, in pl.,
service for hire, po/nwn latreu/mata painful
service, S.Tr.357.
service paid to the gods, worship, E.IT1275 (lyr.). = la/tris,
slave, Id.Tr.1106 (lyr.).

latr-eu/s, e/ws, o(,
hired servant, Lyc.393.

la/tr-eusis, ews, h(,
servitude, Gloss.

latr-eutiko/s, h/, o/n,
servile, Ptol.Tetr. 160, Vett.Val.335.34, al.
latr-euto/s, h/, o/n, = foreg., e)/rgon LXX Ex. 12.16.

latr-eu/w, Elean latrei/w (q.v.),
work for hire or
pay, Sol. 13.48:
to be in servitude, serve, X.Cyr.3.1.36; para/ tini Apollod.2.6.3. l. tini/
to be subject or
enslaved to, S.Tr.35, etc.: c. acc. pers.,
serve, E.IT1115 (lyr.), f.l. in Id.El.131: metaph., l. pe/tra|, of Prometheus, A.Pr.968; mo/xqois latreu/wn toi=s u(perta/tois brotw=n S.OC105; l. no/mois
obey, X.Ages.7.2; l. kairw=|, = Lat.
temporibus inservire, Ps.-Phoc.121; tw=| ka/llei l.
to be devoted to . . , Isoc.10.57; l. h(donh=| Luc.Nigr.15.
serve the gods
with prayers and sacrifices, l. *foi/bw| E.Ion152 (lyr.): c. acc. cogn., po/non l. tini/
render due service, ib.129 (lyr.); po/non . . to/nd' e)la/treusa qea=| IG2.1378.

la/tr-ios, a, on,
of a servant or
service, misqo/s Pi.O.10.28; latri/an *)iaolko\n pare/dwken gave Iolcos
into slavery, Id.N.4.54 (ubi codd. latrei/an contra metrum); l. e)/rga Man.1.275.

la/tr-is, ios, o( and h(,
hired servant, and in fem.
handmaid, Thgn.302, 486, S.Tr.70, E.Supp.639, Supp.Epigr. 1.405B1 (Samos, iii A.D.); *(ermh=n . . daimo/nwn la/trin E.Ion4; h(migu/naika qeh=s la/trin o(\s . . [Simon.] 179.9; of
slaves, E.IA868 (troch.): fem., Id.Hec.609; h( qew=n l.
handmaid of the gods, Id.HF823; th\n *)apo/llwnos l., of Cassandra, Id.Tr.450 (troch.), cf. Phld.Piet.91: metaph., mi/tou poludine/a l., of the spindle, AP6.39 (Arch.); *foi/bou l., of the raven, ib.9.272 (Bianor).

la/tr-on, to/,
pay, hire (l.: o( misqo/s, Suid., EM557.35), la/trwn a)/terqen without
charge or
payment, A. Supp.1011.

latr-w/dhs, es,
servile, Vett.Val.5.26, Heph.Astr.1.1.
la/tta: mui=a (Polyrrhen.), Hsch. la<t>tai/a: paracifi/s, kai\ h( peri\ zw/nhn ma/xaira, Id.

la_tu^p-e/w,
build of stone, Lyc.523.

la_tu^/p-h, h(,
the chips of stone in hewing, IG22.244.82 (iv B.C.), Rev.Phil.50.67 (ii B.C.), Str.17.1.34.
gypsum, lime, Plu.2.954a, Poll.9.104 (cf. Sch.Pl.Tht.146a), Paul.Aeg. 4.14, Sch.Ar.Nu.260.

la_tu^p-iko/s, h/, o/n,
of or
for hewing, smi/lh Hsch. s.v. eu)smi/lwta (-h/l- cod.); h( l. te/xnh Porph.Hist.Phil.11.

la_/tu^p-os (parox.), o(,
stone-cutter, mason, Hp.Fract.31, S.Fr.530, Gal.Thras. 43, CIG(add.)3827v, al. (Cotiaeum); cf. laotu/pos.

la^tu/ssw,
clap, strike, in Med., pe/rdikes . . latusso/menoi pteru/gessi Opp.C.2.430:—Pass., Id.H.1.628.
*la_tw/, Dor. for *lhtw/.

lauka^ni/h, h(,
throat, fai/neto d' h(=| klhi+=des a)p' w)/mwn au)xe/n' e)/xousi, laukani/hn Il.22.325 (cf. 24.642: leukani/h is v.l. ibid. (cf. Ruf.Onom. 48,68) and prevails in later Ep., as Orph.L.554 (pl.); leukani/hqen Opp.H.1.755; -hnde A.R.2.192).

laukelarxe/w,
hold a priestly office, IG14.716, al. (Naples).
lau/kh: fobera/, Hsch. (Cf. lukei=on.) lau/cei: kratei=, dai/nutai, eu)frai/nei, Id. lauci/a: darh/s . . (Cret.), Id. lau=cis, = lh=cis (A), Id.

lau/ra, Ep. and Ion. la_tu^/p-rh, h(,
alley, lane, passage, Od.22.128, 137, Pi. P.8.86, Hdt.1.180, Hermesian.7.65, Herod.1.13, POxy.1449.6 (iii A.D.), etc.; h( tw=n *sami/wn l. an
alley or
bazaar at Samos, where women sold delicacies of all kinds, Clearch.22; eu)daimo/nwn l., at Alexandria, Ath.12.541a;
avenue, Theoc.Ep.4.1;
path, Plu.Crass.4. = a)/mfodon 11, POxy.242 (i A.D.).
sewer, privy, Hippon.in PSI9.1089.10: pl., Ar.Pax99, 158 (both anap.), J.AJ15.9.6.

*lau/reion, to/, promontory in the south of Attica, famous for its silver-mines, Hdt.7.144, Th.2.55, EM533.34, etc.; *lau/reon, IG22.1582.67, al.; later *lau/rion, Paus.1.1.1:—Adj. *laur-ewtiko/s or la_tu^p-eiwtiko/s, h/, o/n,
of Mt. Laurium, Ar.Av.1106, Plu.Nic.4.
lau=ros, freq. f.l. for la/bros.

laurosta/tai [a^], oi(, （lau/ra, sth=nai)
the choreutae who stood in the middle, gen erally the bad ones, Cratin.422.

lau=sai: perippeu=sai toi=s despo/tais, Hsch. lausth/r: moxqhro/s, o(/moion de\ th=| duna/mei to\ o)/noma, h)\ oi)/kou lau/ra, Id. lau/stranon: tine\s lu/kon, tine\s fre/atos a(/rpaga, Id. laufqa/zei: speu/dei, Id. laufqa/ssei: la/brws e)sqi/ei, Id. lauxa/nh: glw=ssa, Id. la/faton, = la/paqon, Gloss.

lafqi/a: h( a)spi/s, o(/plon, Hsch. la/fnh: da/fnh (Pergaean), Id. lafni/skos, =
britia (dub. sens.), Gloss. (peri\ qremma/twn). lafo/s: o( a)ristera=| xeiri\ xrw/menos, Hsch.
*lafri/a, h(, epith. of Artemis, Paus.4.31.7, etc., cf. Str.10.2.21, Ant.Lib.40.2; of Athena, Lyc.356, etc.:—so *la/frios, of Hermes, Id.835.
*la/fria, ta/, festival at Delphi, GDI2561D8; at Hyampolis, IG 9(1).90:—also *lafri/eia, ta/, Supp.Epigr.2.258.35 (Delph., iii B.C.).
*lafr-ia/dai: fratri/a e)n *delfoi=s, Hsch.
*lafr-iai=os, o(, month in Aetolia, GDI1908.
*la/fr-ios, o(, month in Phocis, ib.1719, al.; at Gytheion, IG5(1).1145.28, etc.

la/f-ugma [la^], atos, to/, （lafu/ssw)
greedy attack, lafu/gmata nou/swn IG14.1363.13 (Rome).

laf-ugmo/s, o(,
gluttony, Ar.Nu.52, Eup.148; personified, AP6.305 (Leon.).
laf-u/ein: to\ ei)s au(to\n a)sxhmonei=n, Hsch.

laf-u/kths, ou, o(,
gourmand, Arist.EE1232a16.
la/f-ucis, ews, h(, = lafugmo/s, Ath.8.362f.

la/fu_ra [la^], ta/, Arg. fa/lura SIG56.9 (v B.C.):—
spoils taken in war, A.Th.278, 479, E.HF417 (lyr.), S.Aj.93; a)reta=s l. Id.Tr.646 (lyr.), cf. X.HG5.1.24, Aen.Tact. 16.8, Marm.Par.53, LXX Ju.15.7: —also in sg. la/furon, Hellanic.143 J., Plb.2.62.12, IG12(7).386.23 (Amorgos), Plu.2.330d, Ach.Tat.4.13, al.; to\ l. e)pikhru/ttein kata/ tinwn give public authority for plundering a people, Plb.4.26.7; cf. r(u/sion, su/lh.

la^fu_ra^gwg-e/w,
carry off as booty, Str.6.3.1, J.AJ13.14.3, Plu. Galb.5 (in fut. Med.), etc.: metaph., po/lemos ou) l. a)reth/n Id.2.5f:— Pass., Sch.E.Med.256.
plunder, po/lin Apollod.2.7.7: abs., Ph.1.152.
la^fu_ra^gwg-htiko/s, h/, o/n, gloss on a)gelei/h, Sch.Lips.Il.4.128 Bekker.

la^fu_ra^gwg-i/a, h(,
carrying off booty, Heph.Astr.3.7, Sch.E.Or. 1434, Procl.in Alc.p.214 C.

la^fu_ra^gwg-o/s, o/n,
carrying off booty, Sch.D Il. 4.128, Sch.ib.10.460, prob. l. for fugag- in Polyaen.8.16.6.

la^fu_r-eu/w,
plunder, LXX Ju.15.11; la^fu_r-e/w, Aq.Is.59.15.
la^fu_ropwl-ei=on, v. lafuropw/lion.

la^fu_ropwl-e/w,
sell booty, abs., X.An. 6.6.38: c. acc., lei/an Plb.5.24.10, etc.; l. ai)xmalw/tous
sell them
as booty, D.S.17.14.

la^fu_ropw/l-hs, ou, o(,
seller of booty, one who has bought up booty to retail, X.An.7.7.56, Dionys.Com.3.16 (s.v.l.). in pl., at Sparta,
officers attached to the king's staff,
who took charge of the booty, X.Lac.13.11, HG4.1.26.

la^fu_ropw/l-ion, to/,
sale of booty, IG5(2).6.11 (Tegea, iv B.C.).
place where booty is sold, Str.14.3.2, D.H.9.56:—written la^fu_ropwl-ei=on in Plb.4.6.3.

la^fu/ssw, Att. la^fu_ropw/l-ttw, fut. lafu/cw Ael.Fr.156: aor. e)la/fuca Orph. L.120, etc.:—Med. (v. infr.), aor. inf. lafu/casqai Lyc.321:—
swallow greedily, gulp down, of the lion, ai(=ma kai\ e)/gkata pa/nta lafu/ssei Il.11.176; of dogs, Luc.Asin.27; of wild beasts, eagles, etc., Q.S.10.316, etc.; also, of bears,
tear open, o)/nuci th\n gaste/ra Ael.NA4.45: metaph., of fire,
consume, AP5.238 (Paul. Sil.); of disease, Aret.CA2.3:— Med., of men,
eat gluttonously, gorge, lafu/ssetai lafugmo/n Eup. 148, cf. Lyc. l.c.—Poet. Verb used in late Prose, as Ph.1.550 (abs.).

la^fu/stios, a, on, (lafu/ssw)
gluttonous, APl.1.15*, Lyc.215. Pass.,
devoured, Id.791. title of Zeus among the Minyae, Hdt.7.197; of Dionysus in Boeotia, EM557.51; of devotees of Dionysus, gunai=kes Lyc.1237.
la/fwnoi: li/an a)/fwnoi, Hsch.

la^xai/nw, (from laxa/n-
yw, cf. la/xanon)
dig, mega/lhn e)la/xaine . . . ta/fron Mosch.4.96, cf. Opp.H.3.121; krh=nai a(\s e)la/xhnen A.R.3.222; laxaine/men e)/rga sidh/rou
dig iron mines, Call.Fr.305; skapanh=| l. ai)=an Orph.Fr.280 (prob.).

la^xa^n-a/rion, to/, =
holerarium, Gloss.

la^xa^n-a=s, a=, o(,
greengrocer, Hdn.Gr.2.657.

la^xa^n-ei/a, h(,
culture of pot-herbs, kh=pos -ei/as a garden
of herbs, LXX De.11.10, cf. PCair.Zen.269.22 (iii B.C.), PPetr.3p.236 (iii B.C.), PTeb.60.39 (ii B.C.), al., Sch.Od.7.127 (pl.), Ptol.Tetr. 81. = laxanismo/s, J.BJ4.9.8.
la^xa^/n-euma, atos, to/, = foreg. 1, Procl.Par.Ptol.118 (pl.).

la^xa^n-eu/s, e/ws, o(, = laxanopw/lhs, Id.
Proll.ad Hes.p.5 G.
la^xa^n-euth/s, ou=, o(, = foreg., POxy.43viii 12 (iii A.D.), 1139.2 (iv A.D.).

la^xa^n-eu/w,
plant vegetables, PSI4.403.13 (iii B.C.):—Pass.,
to be planted with vegetables or
produce them, Str.5.4.3, App.Pun.117, PStrassb.122.5 (ii A.D.); ta\-o/mena
vegetables, Sor.1.87. Pass.,
to be used as pot-herbs, laxaneu/etai e(fqo/n Dsc.2.119. Med.,
gather herbs, Luc.Lex.2.

la^xa^n-hlo/gos, on,
gathering vegetables, AP 9.318 (Leon.).

la^xa^n-hro/s, a/, o/n,
of vegetable kind, to\ l. Thphr.HP7.1.1: pl., ta\ l.
vegetables, pot-herbs, ib.1.11.3, 6.1.2, CP6.9.3.

la^xa^n-hfo/ros, on,
bearing, i.e.
sowing, vegetables, Man.4.258.

la^xa^n-ia/, h(,
gardenbed, PCair.Zen.329.16 (pl., iii B.C.), Hsch. s.v. prasiai/, la^xa^n-i/dion, to/, Dim. of la/xanon, Id.s.v. kixo/ria.

la^xa^n-i/zw,
to be at grass, of horses, Hippiatr.130:—Med.,
gather vegetables, EM558.14. Lat.
lachanizare, = betizare, i.e.
languere, Suet.Aug.87. Pass.,
become green, Gal.17(1).343.

la^xa^n-iko/s, h/, o/n, = laxanhro/s, Inscr.Magn.116.42 (ii A.D.). laxaniko/n (sc. te/los), to/,
tax on market-gardeners, dub. in Ostr.787 (i A.D.), Sammelb.2085.

la^xa^/n-ion, to/, Dim. of la/xanon, D.L.2.139, Sch.Ar.Oxy.856 i (
b) 37, PHamb.23.26 (vi A.D.).

la^xa^/n-ios, a, on, = laxanhro/s, gh= l.
garden-ground, Jul. Caes.329d; to\ te/los th=s laxani/as (sc. gh=s; fort. -ia=s) tax on
marketgardens, Ostr.787 (i A.D.).

la^xa^n-ismo/s, o(,
cutting or
gathering of vegetables, e)pi\ -ismo\n e)celqei=n Th.3.111, cf. PTeb.117.73 (i B.C.).
being at grass, of horses, Hippiatr.129.

la^xa^no-eidh/s, e/s,
of the colour of vegetables, Tz. ap. Sch.Nic.Al. 570.

la^xa^no-qh/kh, h(,
dish or
pot for vegetables, Alex.Magn. ap. Ath.11.784b (s.v.l.).

la^xa^no-kopiko/s, h/, o/n,
for pounding vegetables, li/qoi POxy.1913.65 (vi A.D.).

la/xa^non [la^], to/, mostly in pl.,
garden-herbs, opp. wild plants,
vegetables, Cratin.313, Epicr.11.15, al., Pl.R.372c, Thphr.HP1.3.1, etc.; but also l. a)/gria Ar.Th.456, Pl.298: sg. is rarer, ou)de\ l. ou)de\n . . o(rw= not
a single
herb, Cratin.191; w(/ste mhde\ l. gene/sqai e)n tw=| kh/pw| D.50.61; e)n tw=| l. tou/tw|, i.e. the lettuce, Eub.14, cf. 54, Epicr.11.25. in pl. also,
the vegetable-market, Ar.Lys.557, Alex.46.8, Diph.32.22.

la^xa^no-pra/ths [pra_], ou, o(,
greengrocer, PAmh.2.148.2 (v A.D.), PLond.1.113.6 (
a）7 (vi A.D.).

la^xa^no-proba/llw,
expose vegetables for sale, PMasp.164.7 (vi A.D.).

la^xa^no/-pteros, o(,
vegetable-winged, Luc. VH1.13.

la^xa^nopwl-ei=on, to/,
greengrocer's shop, POxy.1461.22 (iii A.D.), nisi leg.

-ion. -hs, ou, o(,
greengrocer, Critias 70 D., Arr.Epict.3.3.3, al., PFay.23.13 (ii A.D.), BGU337.22 (ii/iii A.D.):—fem. la^xa^nopwl-h/tria, h(, Ar.Th.387.

la^xa^nopwl-iko/s, h/, o/n,
belonging to a greengrocer, e)rgasth/rion
POxy.1461.6 (iii A.D.).

la^xa^nopw/l-ion, to/,
vegetable-market, Sch.Ar.Lys. 556, Suid.
la^xa^no/pwl-is, idos, h(, = -h/tria, Ar.V.497, Alexand.Com.7.

laxano/-spermon, to/,
vegetable seed, PFay.89 (i A.D.), BGU454.13 (ii A.D.), etc.

laxano-fa^gi/a, Ion. -ih, h(,
vegetable diet, Hp.Int.34, Epid. 7.82.
laxano-fo/ros, = -hfo/ros, Sch.Od.7.127.

la^xa^n-w/dhs, es, = laxanhro/s, Thphr.HP1.3.4, 7.1.1, Muson.Fr. 18A p.95 H., Dsc.2.126, Gal.6.644; laxanw/dh
the vegetable kind, Arist.Pr.20tit.

la^xa^n-wnu^mi/a, h(,
naming after la/xana, Tz.H.4.558.
la/xe, laxei=n, v. lagxa/nw.

la/xeia [la^], h(, obscure word read (prob.) by Aristarch. in two passages of Od., nh=sos e)/peita la/xeia . . teta/nustai 9.116; e)/nq' a)kth/ te la/xeia kai\ a)/lsea *persefonei/hs 10.509; expld. by eu)/skafos kai\ eu)/geios, para\ to\ laxai/nesqai, o(/ e)sti ska/ptesqai puknw=s, Hsch., cf. Apollon. Lex., Eust.1619.30, 1667.13, Sch.; cf. la/xanon, laxu/floios: Zenod. read e)la/xeia, cf.h.Ap.197.
la^xeidh/s, e/s, epith. of the toad in Nic.Al.568 (perh. from same root as foreg.; but prob. corrupt).

*la/xesis [a^], ews, Ion. ios, h(, (laxei=n) Lachesis, one of the three Fates,
Disposer of lots, Hes.Th.218, Sc.258, Pi.O.7.64, etc.; as the goddess of
distribution, Plu.2.644a, cf. Arist.Mu.401b20. as Appellat.,
lot, destiny, Bacis ap. Hdt.9.43: pl., *moirw=n *laxe/sewn IG 5(1).602.8 (Sparta, iii A.D.).

la/x-h [a^], h(, = lh=cis, a)poklh/rwsis, Hsch.; ta/fwn patrw/|wn la/xai （laxai/ codd.)
ashare in their fathers' tombs, A.Th.914 (lyr.).
la/x-hsis, ews, h(, = la/xesis 11, Sch.Lyc.1141.

lax-ismo/s, o(,
casting of lots, Gloss.
laxmhth/rion, to/, （laxei=n） = la/xos, laxmo/s (A), Eust.674.24.
laxmo/s (A), o(, = la/xos, Sch.Theoc.8.30, Eust.1521.48.
laxmo/s (B), o(, = laktismo/s, Antim.54.
laxmo/s (C), o(, v.l. for la/xnos (A) in Od.9.445, cf. Eust.1638.39, Hsch.
laxn-ai=os, a, on, = laxnh/eis, AP9.439 (Crin.).

la/xn-h, h(,
soft woolly hair, down, as of the first beard, pri/n sfwi+n . . puka/sai ge/nus eu)anqe/i+ la/xnh| Od.11.320; o(/te la/xnai nin me/lan ge/neion e)/refon Pi.O.1.68; of the
thin hair on Thersites' head, yednh\ d' e)penh/noqe l. Il.2.219; of the
soft nap or
pile on cloth, ou)/lh d' e)penh/noqe l. 10.134; of the
scanty hairs on the elephant, Luc.Philops.24; of the
hair or
fur of wild beasts, la/xnh| de/rma kata/skion Hes.Op.513; of the bear's or polecat's
fur, Opp.C.3.140, Nic.Th.690; of sheep's
wool, S.Tr.690, Opp.C.2.379; of ox's
hair, A.R.1.325: in pl., of the hedgehog's
quills, Plu.2.98d, Opp.H.2.369. metaph.,
leafage, Nic.Al.410, Opp.H.4.167, 380 (pl.).

laxn-h/eis, Dor. laxn-a/eis, essa, en, contr. laxn-h=s Hdn.Gr.2.618:—
woolly, hairy, shaggy, *fh=res Il.2.743; sth/qea 18.415; ste/rna Pi.P.1.19; suo\s de/rma Il.9.548; l. o)/rofos
downy, soft thatch, 24.451.

laxno/-guios, on,
with shaggy limbs, qh=res E.Hel.378 (lyr.).

laxno/-omai, Pass.,
grow hairy or
downy, of a youth's chin, Sol.27.6, AP12.178 (Strat.).

la/xnos (A), o(, = la/xnh,
wool, Od.9.445; v.l. laxmo/s (c).

la/xnos (B), o(,
glutton, Gloss.; cf. la/gnos, li/xnos.

laxn-w/dhs, es, = laxnh/eis, laxnw=des ou)=das xlo/hs the ground
downy with grass, E.Cyc.541; gloss on v.l. e)/gxnoa in Nic.Th.762.

la/xn-wsis, ews, h(,
covering with hair, Hp.Hebd.5.21 R.

la/xos [a^], eos, to/, （la^xei=n)
allotted portion:
lot, destiny, Thgn. 592, S.Ant.1303 (so Bothe for le/xos).
appointed office, A.Ch.361 (lyr.), Eu.334 (lyr.): pl., ib.310 (anap.), 347, 386 (both lyr.).
portion obtained by lot, share, Pi.O.7.58, N.10.85, A.Eu.400, X.An. 5.3.9; e)n tw=| tri/tw| l., = to\ tri/ton or tri/tws, A.Eu.5; nukto\s tri/taton l. Mosch.2.2, cf. A.R.1.1082; h)/matos Id.3.1340.—Poet. word, used by X., and found in dialects, tw=n xrhma/twn to\ l. IG5(2).262.20 (Mantinea, v B.C.), cf. Schwyzer289.88 (Rhodian, ii B.C.).
la^xu/floios, on, ka/ruon Nic.Al.269, expld. by Sch. e)la/xiston floio\n e)/xontos, as if it were e)laxu/floios, cf. la/xeia (vv. ll. dasu/-, taxu/-, tasu/-floios).
la/y, Adv. (Tarent.), sine expl., Hdn.Gr.1.404, al. la/ya: gogguli/s (Pergaean), Hsch.

laya/nh (so PPetr.3p.152(iii B.C.)) or lamya/nh, h(, the herb
charlock, Brassica arvensis, Dsc.2.116, Gal.7.285.
laya/rwn: th=| xeiri\ poti/zwn, h)\ a(pto/menos, Hsch.

la/yis, ews, h(, (la/ptw)
lapping, opp. spa/sis and ka/yis, Arist.HA 595a10.
la/yomai, Ion. fut. of lamba/nw (q.v.).

la/w (A) [a^], = ble/pw, ou)de/ ken au)to\n ai)eto\s o)cu\ la/wn e)ske/yato h.Merc. 360; ghqh/seie la/wn is probably v.l. for g. i)dw/n in Il.13.344 (POxy. 769); cf. la/ete: skopei=te, ble/pete, Hsch., Cyr.

la/w (B) [a^],
seize, hold, ku/wn e)/xe poiki/lon e)llo/n, a)spai/ronta la/wn
gripping it as it struggled, Od.19.229; o( me\n la/e nebro\n a)pa/gxwn
gripped the fawn as he was throttling it, ib.230.—Also expld. by a)polaustikw=s e)/xwn (Aristarch.) or a)polaustikw=s e)sqi/wn (Sch., Hsch. s.v. la/wn, who refers it alternatively to la/w (A), but also has la/e: e)yo/fhsen, oi( de\ e)fqe/ggeto; cf. lah/menai: fqe/ggesqai, Cyr.).
*la/w (C), v. lw=.

la_w/dhs, es, (lao/s)
popular, Ph.1.80, Plu.Crass.3.
le/a, h(, v. laiai/.
lea/da: h( e)coxh\ tw=n petrw=n, Hsch.; cf. ledda/.

lea/zw,
to be smooth, opp. tri/xas e)/xein, Arist.PA658a21.

le/aina, h(, fem. of le/wn,
lioness, Hdt.3.108: metaph., di/pous l., of Clytaemnestra, A.Ag.1258; leai/nas mazo\n e)qh/lazen, as a symbol of ferocity, Theoc.3.15, cf.23.19. l. e)pi\ turoknh/stidos, = sxh=ma/ ti sunousi/as, Ar.Lys.231. pl.,
women dedicated to Mithras, Porph.Abst.4.16 (cf. le/wn VI); title of Hecate, ibid. name of several salves, Orib.Fr.75, Aët.7.86, Paul.Aeg.7.17.

leai/nw, also leiai/nw, Sol.4.35, Nic.Th.95, Gp.4.12.13: fut. lea^nw= Arist.PA674b21; Ep. leia^ne/w Il.15.261: aor. 1 e)le/hna Hdt.1.200, Nic.Fr.70.15, -a_na Arist.GA788b31, e)lei/ana IG12.372E11,373.174; Ep. e)lei/hna, lei/hna, Il.4.111, Od.8.260:—Med., Muson.Fr.18 B p.101 H.: Ep.aor. leihna/mhn Nic.Th.646:—Pass., Pl.Plt.270e: aor. e)lea/nqhn Dsc.3.158, S.E.P.1.130; Ion.subj. leianqe/wsi Hp.Mul.2.168; part. leianqei/s Gp.11.13.2, Philotim. ap. Orib.4.10.1: pf.inf.leleia/nqai Thphr.Fr.30.2, Ph.2.510; part. leleasme/nos Damocr. ap. Gal.13.989, Dsc.5.75, Dieuch. ap. Orib.4.6.2, Porph.Abst.4.7, leleiasme/nos Ph.1.302:—
smooth, polish, of a worker in horn or stone, pa=n d' eu)= leih/nas Il.4.111, cf. IGll.cc.; i(/ppoisi ke/leuqon pa=san leiane/w I will
smooth the way, Il.15.261; lei/hnan de\ xoro/n Od.8.260, l. ta\ traxunqe/nta Pl. Ti.66c; l. ta\ khri/a, of bees, Arist.HA625b19:—Pass., leaino/menoi ta\ sw/mata Theopomp.Hist.195.
triturate, pound in a mortar, Hdt.l.c.;
grind down (of the teeth), X.Mem.1.4.6, Arist.Ph.198b26, HA501b31, Nic.Th.95, Ph.1.63:—Med.,
grind small, Nic.Th.646:— Pass., Philotim. ap. Orib. l.c. generally,
crush, extirpate, ta\ fuo/mena Hdt.4.122.
smooth away, ta\s tw=n skutw=n r(uti/das Pl. Smp.191a, cf. Plt.l.c. (Pass.): metaph.,
smooth or
soften down, to\n *mardoni/on lo/gon Hdt.8.142; to\ e)pi/xolon l. tw=| u(/pnw| Philostr.Im.2.11;
polish style, D.H.Comp.16: metaph., also, l. th\n kata/posin
tickle the palate, Muson.l.c.; th\n a)koh/n D.H.Comp.12: abs., [o( xulo\s] leai/nei
lubricates, soothes, Thphr.CP6.2.1. intr.,
to be smooth, Arist.Pr.936a15.

le/an-sis or lei/ansis, ews, h(,
grinding down, Antyll. ap. Orib.10.23.17; trofh=s Anon.Lond.Fr.2.1, cf. Gal.14.714.
lea/n-teira, h(, fem. of leanth/r, ki/shris AP6.295 (Phan.).

lean-te/on,
one must grind down, Dsc.5.88.

lean-th/r, h=ros, o(,
grinder, i.e.
pestle, Antyll. ap. Orib.10.23.14.

lean-th/rion, to/,
polisher, PLeid.X.56.

lean-tiko/s, h/, o/n,
good for lubricating or
soothing, of sweet wine, Arist.Pr.872b34; xumo\s l. Thphr.CP6.1.3;
laxative, cj. in Aristox.Fr.Hist.ap. Gell.4.11: c. gen., l. a)rthri/as Diph.Siph. ap. Ath.2.57c. Adv. -kw=s Eust.118.9.

lebhri/s, i/dos, h(,
skin or
slough of serpents, Hp.Mul.1.78, 2.191, J. AJ3.7.2; of beans,
shell, Hsch.: prov., keno/teros lebhri/dos Stratt. 10 D.; so tuflo/teros l. Ar.Fr.35; lepto/teron to\ de/rma lebhri/dos Alciphr.3.19.
rabbit (cf. le/poris) Str.3.2.6; Massiliote word acc. to Polemarch. ap. Erot. a bird of ill-omen, Phot.

le/bhs, htos, o(,
kettle, cauldron, Il.21.362, Pi.O.1.26; tri/pous l. A. Fr.1; used for gifts and prizes, Il.23.259, al.;
brazier, Th.4.100.
coin stamped with a cauldron, GDI4979, al. (Crete). in Od., mostly the
basin in which the purifying water (xe/rniy) was handed to the guests before meals, made of silver, 1.137, al.; but in 19.386, a
pan for washing the feet; dolofo/nos l., of the
bath in which Agamemnon was slain, A.Ag.1129 (lyr.). basin used as a
cymbal or
drum, Hdt.6.58; of the
gong at Dodona, Call.Del.286.
cinerary urn, A.Ag.444 (lyr.), Ch.686, S.El.1401. generally,
casket, Id.Tr.556:
pan for colours, Luc.
Bis Acc.8.
vase of cauldron shape on the roof of the temple of Zeus at Olympia, Paus. 5.10.4.
air-vessel used like a diving-bell, Arist.Pr.960b32.
lebht-a/rion, to/, Dim. of foreg., Poll.10.66, 95, etc.

lebht-i/zw,
put into or
boil in a cauldron, sa/rkas Lyc.199.

lebh/t-ion, to/, Dim. of le/bhs, IG22.1541.16 (iv B.C.), 11(2).161 C88 (Delos, iii B.C.), Anaxipp.6.5, Men.1027, cf.Poll.6.92, 10.76;
small brazier, Antyll. ap. Orib.8.12.3.

lebhto-eidh/s, e/s,
like a kettle or
basin, a)ggei=on Eust.1298.36, etc.

lebhto-xa/rwn [a^], wnos, o(,
pot-friend, Cerc.11.
lebhtw/dhs, es, = lebhtoeidh/s, Ath.11.468e.

lebi/as, ou, o(, a kind of
fish, Ar.Fr.414 (le/bioi codd.Ath.), Ephipp. 12.4, Diph.17.9, etc.
lebi/nqioi: e)re/binqoi, Hsch.

*lebu/a [u^], h(, = *libu/h, Berl.Sitzb.1927.156 (Cyrene):—hence *lebu^a_fi^genh/s, e/s,
sprung from Libya, Ibyc.57.

legew/n, w=nos, h(, = Lat.
legio, Ev.Matt.26.53, Ev.Marc.5.9, Plu. Rom.13, 20, IGRom.3.670, al.:—freq. written legiw/n, ib.214.3, al.: —hence legiona/rios, o(, ib.913.3, al.
legiw/nh, h(, = legew/n, SIG830 (Delphi, ii A.D.).
le/gma: to\ ei)pei=n, Hsch.
le/gnh, h(, = sq., Sch.Call.Dian.12, Hsch.

le/gnon, to/,
coloured edging or
border of a garment parallel to the w)/a or selvage, Poll.7.62, Hsch. ta\ le/gna th=s u(ste/rhs
border of the womb, Hp.Mul.2.144.
le/gnos: a)/nandros, si=tos o( mh\ a(dro/s, Hsch.
legn-o/w, in aor. inf. legnw=sai: poiki=lai, Hsch.
legn-w/dhs, es, = sq., Id., Phot.

legn-wto/s, h/, o/n,
with a coloured border, xitw/n Call. Dian.12; l. r(a/bdoi Nic.Th.726.
le/gc: poio\n h)=xon a)pete/lesen, Hsch.

le/gos, h, on,
lewd, le/gai gunai=kes Archil.179.

*le/gw (A),
lay, pres. erroneously inferred from le/comai, e)/lekto, etc.; v. le/xomai.

le/gw (B),
pick up, etc.: tenses for signf. 1 and 11, fut. le/cw Od.24.224: aor. e)/leca A.Pers.292:—Med., fut. in pass. sense le/comai E. Alc.322: aor. e)leca/mhn Il.21.27 (trans.); Ep. e)le/gmhn Od.9.335; le/kto 4.451:—Pass., aor. e)le/xqhn Il.3.188: also post-Hom. in these senses, but only in compos., esp. with a)po-, e)k-, kata-, sun-; post-Hom. pf. ei)/loxa （kat-, sun-), Pass. ei)/legmai, in these senses rarely le/legmai (v. the compds.); also fut. legh/somai （sul-): aor. 2 e)le/ghn （kat-, sun-):—
gather, pick up, o)ste/a . . le/gwmen Il.23.239, cf. Od.24.
72, Pi.P.8.53; ai(masia/s te le/gwn
picking out stones for building walls, Od.18.359 (ubi v. Sch., cf. loga/s 2), cf. 24.224:—Med.,
gather for oneself, e)pi\ de\ cu/la polla\ le/gesqe Il.8.507; o)ste/a leuka\ le/gonto 24.793; fa/rmaka le/casqai A.R.3.807. Med.,
choose for oneself, pick out, le/caito . . a)/ndras a)ri/stous Od.24.108; kou/rous Il.21.27:—Pass.,
to be chosen, ei) . . legoi/meqa pa/ntes a)/ristoi 13.276.
count, tell, e)n d' h(me/as le/ge kh/tesin he
counted us among the seals, Od.4.452; and in aor. Med., Il.2.125; e)gw\ pe/mptos meta\ toi=sin e)le/gmhn I
reckoned myself . . , Od.9.335; le/kto d' a)riqmo/n he
told him over the number, 4.451:—Pass., meta\ toi=sin e)le/xqhn I
was counted among these, Il.3.188. so, but not freq., after Hom., l. pontia=n ya/fwn a)riqmo/n Pi.O.13.46, cf. A.Ag.570; kaq' e(\n e(/kaston l. Isoc.2.45; also kai\ se\ d' e)n tou/tois le/gw
count you among . . , A.Pr.973; l. tina\ ou)damou=
count him as naught, S.Ant.183; ke/rdos l., ei) . .
count it gain, that . . , ib.462:—Med., le/cato pa/ntas [nau/tas] Pi.P.4.189:—Pass., le/gesqai e)n toi=s i(ppikwta/tois X.Oec.11.20; e)ni\ prw/th|si le/gesqai Call.Del.16: fut. Med. in pass. sense, e)n toi=s ou)ke/t' ou)=si le/comai E. l.c.
recount, tell over, ou)/ ti diaprh/caimi le/gwn e)ma\ kh/dea Od.14.197; su\ de/ moi le/ge qe/skela e)/rga 11.374; ta\ e(/kasta le/gwn 12.165; o(/sa t' au)to\s . . e)mo/ghse, pa/nt' e)/leg' 23.308: so in Trag., l. tu/xas, pa/qh, mo/xqous, etc., A.Pr.633, Pers.292, Ag.555, etc.; also *)agame/mnoni . . le/g' o)nei/dea
repeated reproaches against him, Il.2.222; so perh. yeu/dea polla\ l. Hes.Th.27 (but v. infr. 111):—Med., ti/ se xrh\ tau=ta le/gesqai; why need'st thou
tell the tale thereof? Il.13.275; and so, mhke/ti tau=ta legw/meqa nhpu/tioi w(/s ib.292, cf. Od.3.240, 13.296; mhke/ti nu=n dh/q' au)=qi legw/meqa Il.2.435.
say, speak, first in Hes.Th.27 (v. supr.11.2): fut. le/cw Emp.38.1, A.Ag.859, Hdt.4.14, Th.2.48, Antipho 6.33, etc.: aor. e)/leca Anacr.45, Pl.Sph.217e, Antipho 1.15 (rare in Pl. and the Orators, common in some dialects, as Boeotian, IG7.504.2 (Tanagra), Thessalian, ib.9(2).461.21, Ionic, v.l. in Hp.
Aër. 12): pf. le/lexa Gal.16.249, le/lega and le/logas Hsch. (ei)/rhka in correct writers):—Pass., fut. lexqh/somai Th.5.86, Pl.Ti.67c, etc.: also fut. Med. in pass. sense, S.OC1186, E.Hec.906 (lyr.), etc.; and lele/comai Th.3.53 (v.l. le/cetai), Pl.R.457b: aor. e)le/xqhn (never e)le/ghn in this sense) S.OT1442, Th.6.32, etc.: pf. le/legmai Pi.N.8.20, Hdt.2.21, S.Ph.389, etc. (ei)/legmai in this sense only in compd. di-): rare in compds. (only a)ntile/gw, e)pile/gw, katale/gw, prole/gw), the pres. in most compds. being supplied by a)goreu/w, the fut. by e)rw=, the aor. by ei)=pon, the pf. by ei)/rhka:
say, speak, never in Hom., first in Hes. l.c., freq. from Hdt. and Trag. downwds.; of all kinds of
oral communications, e)ke/leue le/gein ei)/ ti qe/loi Hdt.8.58; so le/gois a)/n
speak, say on, Pl.Plt.268e, etc.; l. mu=qon A.Pers.698 (troch.); yeudh= l. Id.Ag. 625; a)lhqh= l. Pl.Phlb.12b (so in Pass., lo/gos le/lektai pa=s S.Ph.389); of oracles,
say, declare, Hdt.8.136; w(/sper tou)/noma le/gei
indicates, Pl. Prt.312c: with Preps., l. a)mfi/ tinos A.Th.1017, E.Hec.580; peri/ tinos Xenoph.34.2, Democr.165, S.Aj.151 (anap.), Th.2.48; u(pe/r tinos in his defence, S.El.555, X.HG1.7.16; kata/ tinos against him, Thgn.1240a, X.HG1.5.2; l. e)pi/ tisi eu)xa\s a)gaqa/s
express good wishes for them, A.Supp.625 (anap.); l. ta/ tinos take his part, D.8.64; l. pro/s ti in reference or in answer to . . , S.Ant.753, etc.; ei)/s ti X.Mem. 1.5.1. c. acc. et inf.,
say that . . , Pi.P.2.59, etc.: with neg. ou), Pl.R.348c, etc., but mh/ ib.346e, X.Smp.4.5 (Pass.), and usu. in later Gr., LXX Ge.38.22; l. mh\ ei)=nai a)na/stasin Ev.Matt.22.23: freq. also folld. by w(s, o(/ti (generally so in the Act. voice) when the subject of the relative clause may become the object of the principal Verb, gunai=ka le/gousin, w(s ka/qhtai . . X.Cyr.7.3.5, etc.: rarely c. part., l. *oi)di/poun o)lwlo/ta
speak of him as dead, S.OC1580; le/gousin h(ma=s w(s o)lwlo/tas A.Ag.672; le/cas' a)delfw=| s' e)nqa/d' o)/nta E.Hel.888:—Pass., le/cetai e)/xwn Id.IT1047, cf. A.Ag.170 (cj.). le/gein tina/ ti
say something
of another, esp. kaka\ l. tina/
speak ill
of him,
revile him, Hdt.8.61; a)gaqa\ l. tina/s Ar.Ec.435; ta\ e)/sxata, ta\ a)po/rrhta l. a)llh/lous, X.Mem.2.2.9, D.18.123; also eu)= or kakw=s l. tina/, A.Ag.445 (lyr.), S.El.524, cf. 1028; eu)= l. to\n eu)= le/gonta X.Mem.2.3.8.
call by name, a(\s tre/momen l. S.OC128 (lyr.): c. dupl. acc.,
call so and so, le/goim' a)\n a)/ndra to/nde tw=n staqmw=n ku/na A.Ag.896, cf. S.OC939 codd., Hdt.1.32, etc. l. tina\ poiei=n ti
tell, command one to do, A.Ch. 553, S.Ph.101, X.Cyr.4.1.22, etc.: so with tini, S.OC840, D.19.150 (no obj. expressed in A.Ag.925, S.OC856); le/ge to\n e)rwtw=nta i(/na . . ei)/ph| soi . . Astramps.Orac.p.1 H.; w(s o( no/mos le/gei D.22.20; o( le/gwn mh\ moixeu/ein Ep.Rom.2.22. l. ti
say something, i.e.
speak to the point or
purpose, bou/lh| le/gein ti, kai\ le/gwn mhde\n klu/ein; S.Ant. 757; le/gw ti;
am I right? the answer being le/geis, Id.OT1475; kinduneu/eis ti le/gein Pl.Cra.404a; i)/sws a)/n ti le/gois X.Mem.2.1.12, cf. Cyr.1.4.20; opp. ou)de\n le/gei
has no
meaning, no
authority, ou)de\n l. to\ swfro/nws trafh=nai Ar.Eq.334, cf. V.75; ou)de\n le/geis
nonsense! Id.Th.625; but ou)de\n le/gein, also,
say what is not, lie, Id.Av.66, Pl. Ap.30b; also eu)= ge le/geis, eu)= le/geis, eu)= a)\n le/gois,
good news!, that is well!, ib.24e, Grg.447b, Prt.310b; kalw=s, o)rqw=s l.,
you are right, X. Mem.3.3.4, 3.6.8; kou)/pw le/gw
and what is more, Herod.7.44; ti/ le/geis; to\n e)/popa pai= kalei=s; Ar.Av.57, cf. Ec.298 (lyr.). pleon., e)/fh le/gwn Hdt.3.156, 5.36; e)/lege fa/s Id.1.122; e)/faske le/gwn Ar.Av. 472; h)= d' o(\s le/gwn Id.V.795; w(s e)/fh le/gwn S.Aj.757; kai\ le/gwn ei)=pen ou(/tw pws D.8.74, etc. at the beginning of letters or documents, *)/amasis *polukra/tei+ w(=de le/gei . . , *mardo/nios ta/de le/gei . . , etc., Hdt.3.40, 8.140. a/, etc.; ta\ gra/mmata e)/lege ta/de Id.1.124, etc.; gra/mmasi le/gon ta/de, of an inscription, Th.6.54: in roman edicts, *ma/rkos *me/ttios *(rou=fos . . le/gei POxy.237 viii 28 (i A.D.).
wish to say, mean, ou)/toi gunai=kas a)lla\ *gorgo/nas le/gw A.Eu.48; ti/ tou=to le/gei, pro\ *pu/loio; what
does pro\ *pu/loio
mean? Ar.Eq.1059, cf. 1021, 1375, Ec.989, Pl. Phd.60e: freq. in Platonic dialogue, pw=s le/geis; how
do you mean? in what
sense do you say this? Ap.24e, al.; h)\ pw=s le/gomen; or what
do we mean to say? Grg.480b; pw=s dh\ ou)=n au)to\ le/geis; Phdr.265c; poi=o/n ti/ pote a)/ra le/gont e/s fasi . . what they can possibly
mean by saying . . , Tht.181c, al.: c. dupl. acc., toiou=to/n ti se\ le/gein to\ krei=tton Grg.489d, al.: freq. (esp. in Trag.) to explain more fully, ei)/sw komi/zou kai\ su/, *kasa/ndran le/gw you,
I mean Cassandra, A.Ag.1035; o( ma/ntis, ui(o\n *oi)kle/ous l. Id.Th.609, cf. 658 (v.l.), Pr.946; potamo/s, *)axelw=|on le/gw S.Tr.9, cf. 1220, Ph.1261, E.Ph.987; e)me\ le/gwn
meaning me, Isoc.12.215; to\ d' u(mei=s o(/tan le/gw, th\n po/lin l. D.18.88: sts., however, the word after le/gw is put in appos. with the word to be expld., *)antiklei/as . . , th=s sh=s le/gw toi mhtro/s A.Fr.175, cf. Th.658 cod. M; peri\ tw=nde . . , le/gw de\ *fwke/wn D.19.152; par' w(=n . . , tou/twn tw=n th\n *)asi/an oi)kou/ntwn le/gw Id.8.24, cf. Pl.Smp.202b: abs., mhdeno\s o)/ntos e)n [th=| xw/ra|] le/gw D.1.27. peri\ a(\s (sc. a)polau/seis） le/gomen to\n sw/frona in regard to which we
use the term 'temperate', Arist.EN1148a5, cf. Pl.Grg. 494b. w(s le/gousi as
they say, S.Ant.23, etc.; w(s l. moi Id.OC 1161:—Pass., le/getai
it is said, c.acc.et inf., X.Mem.1.2.30, al.; but also patro\s le/getai gene/sqai . . Id.Cyr.1.2.1; qanei=n e)le/xqh he
was said to have been killed, S.OT292; so lego/menon e)re/w Pi.P.5.108: to\ lego/menon abs.,
as the saying goes, Th.7.68, cf. Pl.Grg.447a, Smp. 217e, etc.; to\ l. dh\ tou=to Id.Grg.514e: o( lego/menos graw=n u(/qlos the
so-called . . , Id.Tht.176b; oi( l. au)to/nomoi ei)=nai X.HG6.3.8; oi( l. o(/ti . .
of whom it is said that . . , Id.Cyr.8.6.16. of orators,
speak (emphatically), le/gein deino/s S.OT545, X.Cyr.1.5.9, etc.; le/gein h)skhko/tes S.Fr.963, cf. Eup.95 (v. lale/w）; l. te kai\ pra/ssein dunatw/tatos Th.1.139; oi( e)n tw=| plh/qei le/gein duna/menoi Isoc.3.8, cf. D.19.286;
plead one's cause in a court of law, Id.23.78; di/kas le/gein u(pe/r tinos
speak as an advocate for . . , Din.1.111.
boast of, tell of, th\n e(autou= r(w/mhn X.Cyr.1.3.10; in Poets,
sing of, qe/lw l. *)atrei/das Anacreont.23.1.
recite what is written, labe\ to\ bibli/on kai\ le/ge Pl.Tht.143c; and freq. in Oratt., as le/ge to\n no/mon D.21.8 and 10, etc.; of lectures, a)kou/sate/ mou sxo/lia le/gontos Arr.Epict.3.21.6, cf. 15.8 (the sense of Lat.
lego, read, occurs only in the compds. a)nale/gomai, e)pile/gomai).
say or
send word by another, X.An.1.9.25, 7.4.5.
maintain as a thesis, oi( ta\s i)de/as le/gontes Arist. Ph.193b36, Metaph.1036b14.
nominate, Lat.
dicere [dictatorem], D.C.Fr.36.26 (Pass.). (Cf. Lat.
lěgo, legio, legulus ('olivegatherer').)
legwnh=sai, = pai=sai, Ar.Fr.804.
ledda/: h( e)coxh\ tw=n pternw=n, Hsch.; cf. lea/da. ledrei=tai: fronti/zei, qe/lei, bou/letai, Id. le/h: o(moi/ws, Id.

lehl-a^si/a, Ep. lehl-i/h, h(,
plundering, robbery, X.Hier.1.36, Ps.-Phoc. 46 (pl.), A.R.2.303, Plu.Eum.9 (pl.).

lehl-a^te/w, (lei/a, e)lau/nw)
drive away booty, esp.
cattle, S.Aj.343, E.Rh.293, X.HG4.4.15, al., Aen. Tact.16.8. c.acc.loci,
plunder, despoil, to\ pedi/on, th\n po/lin, th\n xw/ran, Hdt.2.152, 5.101, Hdn.3.9.3, cf. Hell.Oxy.16.5, Plu.Cam.17;
ravage, kw/mhn PMasp.2 iii 3 (vi A.D.):—Pass.,
to be plundered, ta\ e)k th=s xw/ras lehlathqe/nta Aen.Tact.16.11: metaph., th=| gastri\ lehlatei=sqai
to be a slave to . . , Plu.2.133a.
lehl-a/thsis [a^], ews, h(, = lehlasi/a, Aen.Tact.16.5.

lei/a (A), h(, (lei=os)
tool for smoothing stone, S.Fr.531. v.laiai/.

lei/a (B), Ion. lhi/+h, Dor. la/|a (Pi.O.10(11).44), h(,
booty, plunder, freq. in Hdt. (v. infr.), etc. (Hom. and Hes. always use lhi/+s); esp. of cattle, opp. a)/nqrwpoi, Pi.l.c., Th.2.94 (v. infr. 4); lei/as a)parxh\n bou=s S.Tr.761, cf. Aj.54, 145 (anap.): pl., e)fqarme/nas eu(ri/skomen lei/as a(pa/sas ib.26; rarely of persons, a)go/meqa lei/a E.Tr.614;
prey of hunters, Id.Rh.326: generally,
booty, Th.8.3, X.HG1.2.4, 1.3.2; tou\s loipou\s lhi/+hn qe/sqai give them up
as plunder, Hdt.4.202; lei/an poiei=sqai th\n xw/ran, = lehlatei=n th\n xw/ran, Th.8.41; lei/an a)/gein X.Cyr.5.3.1; e)pi\ lei/an e)kporeu/sontai Id.An.5.1.8, etc.; kata\ lhi/+hn e)kplw=sai Hdt.2.152: pl., dieskedasme/noi kata\ ta\s i)di/as lei/as X.HG1.2.5: prov., *musw=n lei/a, of anything that may be plundered with impunity, Stratt.35, D.18.72, Arist.Rh.1372b33.
plunder (as an act), zw=si a)po\ lhi/+hs kai\ pole/mou Hdt.4.103.
stolen property, th\n l. a)podou=nai PCair.Zen.145.16 (iii B.C.), cf. PSI4.438.10-13 (iii B.C.).
flocks and herds, cattle, a)pografh\ lei/as PHib.1.33.2 (iii B.C.), cf. PPetr.3p.279 (iii B.C.), BGU1012 (ii B.C.), D.S.19.21, 97; a)te/leia th=s l. OGI748.9 (Cyzic., iii B.C.). (Lit.
the people's property, cf. Lat.
populari 'plunder'.)
leiai/nw, lei/ansis, v. leai/nw, le/ansis.

lei/ac, akos, o(, (lei=os)
beardless boy, EM562.19; li/ac in Hsch.

leiau/sthros, on,
with the harshness softened, Poll.6.15.

lei/b-dhn, Adv., (lei/bw)
in drops, EM781.26.

lei/b-hqron, to/,
wet country or
place, Eup.428, e Phot. (ubi li/bhqra et sic Kock), cf. Ael.Dion.Fr.244.
channel, Phot., Lex.Rhet.ap.Eust.1235.58. *lei/bhqron, to/, mountain district of Thrace inhabited by Orpheus, Str.9.2.25, etc.; to\ *libh/qrion Paus.9.34.4: the inhabitants were proverbially dull, whence the phrases a)/|dein a)mouso/tera *leibhqri/wn Aristaenet.1.27; *leibhqri/wn a)nohto/teroi Thugen. 4: the *leibhqri/des or *leibhqri/des （-ia/des, -iai） *nu/mfai were freq. confounded with the Muses, Str.9.2.25, 10.3.17, Paus.l.c., Orph.Fr. 342.

lei/b-w, Il.1.463, etc.: aor. inf. lei=yai, part. lei/yas, 7.481, 24.285:— Med., aor. e)leiya/mhn E.Alc.1015:—Pass., Hes.Sc.390, E.(v.infr.):—
pour, pour forth, used like spe/ndw in a religious sense, oi)=non lei/bein
