comb, Ar.Eq.496, Av.1366, Arist.HA486b13, Phld.Rh.2.188 S.: metaph., r(h/mata . . o)fru=s e)/xonta kai\ lo/fous Ar.Ra.925. of men,
tuft of hair upon the crown, lo/fous kei/resqai shave so as to leave tufts, Hdt.4.175; *xi=os l. a
tonsure in the middle of the head, Eust.1462.38. of large fishes, = lofia/, Plu.2.978a.

lo/f-ouros ( lofou=ros Arist.HA501a6 Bekker), on, in neut. pl.,
pack-animals, as horse, ass, mule, Arist.HA491a1, GA755b18, IG 12(1).677.23 (Rhodes, iv/iii B.C.); also called u(pozu/gia, Arist.Pr. 895b12 (cf. 15); ta\ zuga\ tw=n l. Thphr.HP5.7.6; opp. ta\ mhruka/zonta, ib.3.10.2, cf. 2.7.4. Arist.Pr.l.c.

lofo/-wsis, ews, h(,
being crested, h( l. h( tw=n o)rne/wn their
crests, Ar.Av.291.
lofo-wso/s: e)pisth/mwn, Hsch. (fort. lofo-wto/s: e)pish/mwn).
lox-a_genei=s: h(gemo/nes, strathgoi/, tacia/rxa/i, a)/rxontes th=s e)ne/dras, oi( suna/gontes tou\s stratiw/tas, Hsch. (Perh. loxagerei=s, from a)gei/rw.)
lox-a_ge/tas, a, o(, Dor. for loxhge/ths (which is not found), = loxago/s, A.Th.42, E.Ph.[974], Supp.502.

lox-a_ge/w, Dor. (borrowed by Att.) for loxhge/w,
lead a lo/xos or
company (commonly of 100 men), X.An. 6.1.30, Mem.3.1.5, Is.9.14: c. gen., lo/xou loxhge/wn Hdt.9.53, cf. 21.
consist of loxagoi/, -gou=n zugo/n Ascl.Tact. 10.13, 11.1.

lox-a_gi/a, h(, Dor. for loxhgi/a (also used in Att., v. loxago/s)
rank or
office of loxago/s, X.An.1.4.15, 3.1.30, Arist.Pol.1322b4 (pl.).

lox-a_go/s, o( （lo/xos, a)/gw), Dor. for loxhgo/s,
leader of an armed band, S.Ant.141 (anap.), Theophil.3. esp.
commander of a company (100 men),
captain, X.An.3.1.32, Ascl.Tact.2.2, PPetr. 3p.8 (iii B.C.), etc.; cf. taci/arxos. in the Spartan army,
commander of a lo/xos, Th.5.66, X.Lac.11.4, etc.; in the Persian army,
captain of 24 men, Id.Cyr.6.3.21, etc.; = Lat.
centurio, Plu.Cam.37; also, =
curio, D.H.2.7.—The word, like kunago/s, was always used in the Dor. form by Attic authors.

lox-a/dhn [a^], Adv.
from ambush, treacherously, Nic.Th.125.
lox-a/zomai, = loxa/w, Emp.84.8, AP9.251 (Even.):—Act. in Hsch.

lox-ai=os, a, on, = lo/xios, loxai/as e)c e(/dras prob.l.in E.Alc.846, cf. Artem.5.73 (as v.l. for loxei/ous [di/frous]）; l. e)/rws
clandestine love, AP15.9 (Cyrus).
bearing down, like heavy ears of corn, l. si=tos Phot., cf. Hsch.; and so prob. in Thphr.CP3.21.5, 23.5: hence metaph.,
richly-blooming, Arat.1057.

lox-a/w, Ep.aor. subj. Med. -h/somai Od.4.670:—
lie in wait for, waylay, *thle/maxon loxo/wntes 16.369, cf. 4.847; h)= me/n min loxo/wsi 13.425; to
 de\ . . oi)/kad' i)o/nta loxw=sin 14.181; au)to
 i)o/nta loxh/somai 4.670; e)lo/xhsan ta\s gunai=kas Hdt.6.138; se . . loxw=sin . . *)erinu/es S.Ant.1075. abs.,
lie in wait, ambush, o(/qi sfi/sin ei)=ke loxh=sai Il.18.520; loxa=| e)pi\ de/ndreon a)naba/s Hdt.4.22; pro\s do/mois loxa=|s e)moi=s E.El.225; pro\s toi=si bwmoi=s Pherecr.141: but mostly in aor. part. with another Verb, o)/fra . . so
 pai=da kataktei/neie loxh/sas Od.22.53; loxh/santes th
 ne/a ei(=lon Hdt.6.87, cf. 37; loxh/sas . . pollou\s die/fqeiren Th.1.65, cf. 3.94:—Med., loxhsa/menos Od.4.388, 463; e)ggu\s o(doi=o loxhsa/menos 13.268; later also loxw/menos, leloxhme/nos,
in ambush, A.R.1.991, 3.7. c. acc. loci,
occupy with an ambuscade, e)lo/xhsan th
 e)n *phda/sw| o(do/n Hdt.5.121. metaph., oi(=on loxw=ntes th
 pro\s *(rwmai/ous fili/an
laying a trap of friendship for them, Plb.3.40.6.—Rare in good Att. (v. Th. ll. cc.), but freq. in late Prose, as Plb. l. c., D.H.2.55, al., Plu.Ant.46:—Pass., Epicur.Nat.15.22, J.BJ3.6.2:—Med. only in Ep.

lox-ei/a, h(,
child-birth, childbed, E.IT382, Call.Del.251; th\n l. ei)/lhxe she presides over
child-birth, Pl.Tht.149b: in pl., Id.Plt.268b; of flowers, e)p' eu)ka/rpoisi loxei/ais AP10.16 (Theaet.); f.l. in E.IT206 (lyr.) for lo/xiai. = lo/xeuma 1, APl.4.132 (Theodorid.). = a)rtemisi/a, Ps.-Dsc.3.113.

lox-ei=os, a, on, and os, on, = lo/xios (q.v.), loxei/ous h(me/ras days
of thanks for safe delivery, Plu.2.377c; que/twsan . . ai( ta\ l. e)kporeuo/menai kai\ zwnnu/menai Milet.1(7).204b9; loxei=a (sc. xwri/a） lipou=sa having left
the place where she bore the child, E.IT1241 (lyr.); cf. loxai=os: Subst. loxei=a, ta/, = loxei/a 1, Hp. Mul.1.29, Ruf. ap. Orib.5.3.16. *loxei/a, h(, title of Artemis, = *loxi/a, IG9(2).141, 142 (Theb. Phthiot.), Orph.H.36.3, etc.

lox-eo/s, o(, = lo/xos,
ambush, only in Hes.Th.178.

lo/x-euma, atos, to/,
that which is born, child, E.Ion 921 (anap.), Ph.816 (lyr.), BCH26.187 (Syria). in pl., = loxei/a,
child-birth, E.El.1124: metaph., ka/lukos e)n loxeu/masin in
the bursting of the bud, A.Ag.1392.

lox-eu/tria, h(,
woman in childbed, metaph. as Adj., h( tou= yeu/dous l. poi/hsis Anon. ap. Suid. s.v. *)ada/m.
midwife, Sch.D Il.16.187.

lox-eu/w, (lo/xos 11)
bring forth, bear, pai=da h.Merc.230, cf. Orph.A.184, etc.; gasth\r h(/ s' e)lo/xeuse AP9.126; of the father,
beget, Orph.A.136, cf. 13; of both parents, ib.159; metaph.,
produce, flogo\s a)/sqma Coluth.179:—Med., -ome/nhn de . . e)/ar u(/mnwn AP7.12. of the midwife,
bring to the birth, deliver, tina E.Ion 948, 1596, cf. El.1129:—hence in Pass.,
to be brought to bed, be in labour, e)/nq' e)loxeu/qhn Id.Tr.602 (lyr.); loxeuqei=s' a)straphfo/rw| puri/, of Semele, Id.Ba.3, cf. Plu.Pel.16: c. gen., loxeuqei/shs au)tou= th=s mhtro/s Id.Cic.2. of a man,
practise couvade, D.S.5.14. Med., in sense of Act., of the mother, E.Ion 921 (anap.), Arist.HA616a34, Call.Del.326; also of the birthplace, APl. 4.295. Pass., of the child,
to be born, S.OC1322; *tita=ni loxeuqei=san by the obstetric art of the Titan, E.Ion455 (lyr.). metaph., generally,
lie embedded, e)n teu/tloisi l. Ar.Pax 1014 (anap.). -h/, h(, = lo/xmh, Supp.Epigr.2.544 (Mylasa).
loxhge/w, loxhgo/s, o(, Ion. for loxag-.

lo/x-hsis, ews, h(,
waylaying, entrapping, Suid.
lox-hth/s, v. loxi/ths 11.

lox-htiko/s, h/, o/n,
lying in wait, treacherous, Adam.2.2.
lo/xia, ta/, and *loxi/a, h(, v. lo/xios.
loxia=|: krufai/a, genna=|, au)/cei, kai\ a)/rtos th=| *)arte/midi geno/menos, kai\ a(drou\s a)sta/xuas e)/xousa, Hsch. loxia/des: ai( u(=lai, Id.
loxi/dion (-in Pap.), to/, dub. sens. in POxy.1290.8 (v A.D.).

loxi/zw, = loxa/w,
lie in wait for:—Pass., loxisqe/ntes diefqa/rhsan they were cut to pieces by
falling into an ambuscade, Th.5.115, cf. D.C.41.51.
place in ambush, loxi/zei e)s o(do\n koi/lhn o(pli/tas Th. 3.107; l. e)n to/pw| D.H.2.55: c. dat. loci, Id.3.64 (nisi leg. <e)n> xwri/ois）; loxi/santos is prob. l. in Plu.Oth.7.
beset with an ambuscade, leloxisme/non xwri/on D.H.1.79.
distribute men in companies (lo/xoi), and so,
put them in order of battle, Hdt.1.103, Aen. Tact.1.5, Plu.Sull.27:—Pass.,
to be so distributed, Agatharch.Fr. Hist.17J., D.H.2.14, etc. loxi/zei: e)pibouleu/etai, Hsch.
loxiko/s, h/, o/n, = sq., l. ka/qarsis dub. in Steph. in Hp.1.201 D. (log- codd.).

lo/xios, a, on,
of or
belonging to child-birth, l. nosh/mata
childbed, E. El.656; w)di/nwn loxi/ais a)na/gkaisi Id.Ba.89 (lyr.), cf. Ion452 (lyr.); lo/xiai . . *moi=rai prob. in Id.IT206 (lyr.); loxi/hs e)k nhdu/os A.R.4.706. loxi/h, = Lat.
foeta or
puerpera, Opp.C.3.292. lo/xiai, ai(, = loxei=ai, Euph.9.11. *loxi/a, h(, epith. of Artemis, E.IT1097, Supp.958 (both lyr.), cf. SIG1219.33 (Gambreum, iii B.C.):—also *loxei/a, q.v. lo/xia, ta/,
discharge after child-birth, Hp.Nat. Puer.18, Arist.HA573a9 (h( loxi/h ka/qarsis Hp.Mul.1.29, al.).
child-birth, AP7.375 (Antiphil.), 9.311 (Phil.).

lox-ismo/s, o(,
placing in ambush, Plu.Phil.13 (pl.).

lox-i/ths [i_], ou, o(,
one of the same lo/xos or
company, fellow-soldier, comrade, A.Ag. 1650, X. Cyr.2.2.7, etc.; cu\n loxi/tais ei)/te kai\ monostibh=; with
attendants or alone ? A.Ch.768; pollou\s e)/xwn a)/ndras loxi/tas S. OT751:— fem. loxi=tis e)kklhsi/a, = Lat.
comitia centuriata, D.H.4.20, App.BC 3.30, etc.
one who lies in wait, Hsch., Suid. (leg. loxhth/s).

loxm-a/zw,
to be downy, a)/rti pareia\<n> loxma/zwn Pisand. ap. Sch.T Il. 4.147.

loxm-ai=os, a, on,
of the coppice, *mou=sa l., of the nightingale, Ar. Av.737 (lyr.).

lo/xm-h, h(, (le/xomai)
thicket, copse, esp. as the
lair of wild beasts, e)n lo/xmh| pukinh=| kate/keito me/gas su=s Od.19.439; lo/xmas u(/po kuane/as Pi.O.6.40, cf. P.4.244; e)xi=nos w(/s tis e)n lo/xmh| kei=sai pesw/n S.Ichn.121: in pl., lo/xmaisi dokeu/sais lying in wait
in the coppice, Pi. O.10(11).30; masxa/lai lo/xmhs dasu/terai Ar.Ec.61, cf. Lys.800: prov., mi/a l. du/o e)riqa/kous ou) tre/fei Sch.Ar.V.922: also in Prose, Arist.HA615a17, Ael.NA13.14, Creophyl. ap. Ath.8.361d; lo/xmh tw=n qhri/wn Jul.Mis.338c.
lo/xm-ios, on, = loxmai=os, tra/gos AP 6.32 (Agath.); ta\ lo/xmia, = lo/xmh, Ps.-Luc.Philopatr.10 (do/xmia codd.).
loxm-i/s, gloss on loxmai/a, Sch.Ar.Av.738.

loxm-w/dhs, es,
overgrown with bushes, bushy, o(do/s Th.3.107: Sup., D.C.40.2.
growing in clumps or
beds, [do/nac] Thphr.HP4.11.11 (Sup.); ta\ l., a class of water plants, as reeds, rushes, sedges, etc., ib.4.8.1.
lo/xonde, Adv., v. lo/xos 1.2.
loxo/s, h(, Hellenistic form for lexw/, Dsc.3.4 (in dat. pl. loxoi=s), Moer.p.247 P. (lo/xos codd.); cf. loxw/.

lo/xos, o(, (le/xomai):
ambush, i.e.
place for lying in wait, ei)ga\r nu=n para\ nhusi\ legoi/meqa pa/ntes a)/ristoi e)s l. Il.13.277; e)k l. a)mph/dhse 11.379; koi=los l., of the wooden horse, Od.4.277, 8.515; cesto\s l. E. Tr.534 (lyr.); w)di/nwn l. Lyc.342; cu/linos l., of the enemy's ships, Orac. ap.Hdt.3.57.
ambuscade, e)si/zesqai lo/xon a)ndrw=n take up one's post in
ambush, Il.13.285; lo/xon ei(=sai place
an ambush, 4.392, Od.4.531; ei(=se de/ min kru/yasa lo/xw| Hes.Th.174; lo/xon a)rtu/nein Od.14.469; lo/xond' i)e/nai Il.1.227; o(po/te kri/noimi lo/xonde a)/ndras a)risth=as Od.14.217; fu/teue/ oi( qa/naton e)k lo/xou Pi.N.4.60; deinoi=s kruptome/na lo/xois *)erinu/s S.El.490 (lyr.); to\n eu)/agron teleiw=sai\ l. Id.OC1089 (lyr.). b. c. gen. objecti, lo/xos qei/oio ge/rontos
the way to ambush him, Od.4.395.
the men that form the ambush, mh\ l. ei)se/lqh|si po/lin Il.8.522, cf. E.Andr.1114, etc.
any armed band, body of troops (of foot, rarely of horse, Arr.Alan.20), Od.20.49; also in Trag., A.Th.56, 460, S.OC1371, etc.: metaph., parqe/nwn i(ke/sios l. A.Th.111 (lyr.); qaumasto\s l. gunaikw=n, of the Furies, Id.Eu.46, cf. 1026; e)la/fwn kerao\s l. AP9.244 (Apollonid.); e)mw=n progo/nwn l. OGI383.48 (Nemrud Dagh, i B.C.). in historical writers, mostly,
a company, reckoned at 24 men in X.Cyr.6.3.21, but at 100 in Id.An.3.4.21, 4.8.15; in the Spartan army,
the fourth or
fifth part of a mo/ra (q.v.), Hdt.9.53,57, cf. Th.5.68, Arist.Fr.541, etc.; o( *pitana/ths l. Th.1.20; o( i(ero\s l. the sacred
company at Thebes, Din.1.73, Plu.Pel.18; also at Carthage, D.S.16.80, 20.10; later l., = 16 men, Ascl.Tact.2.7, Ael.Tact.4.3, Arr.Tact.5.5; but of light-armed, 8 men, Ascl.l.c., Arr.Tact.14.2.
any body of people united for civil purposes, X.Hier.9.5, Arist. Pol.1309a12; ai( e)n lo/xois sunte/leiai (where lo/xoi seems to represent summori/ai) Catal. ap. D.18.106. = Lat.
centuria, D.H.4.16, App. BC1.59, etc. = Lat.
curia, D.H.2.7.
child-birth, A.Ag. 137 (lyr.): pl., Id.Supp.677 (lyr.). dub. sens. in SIG1002.8 (Milet., v/iv B.C.).
loxw/, h(, = lexw/, Sammelb.6652.3 (where loxou=s is used as nom. sg.); so perh. loxw/ is to be read rather than lo/xw| ib.6227: nom. sg. loxw/s is v.l. in LXX Ep.Je.28; cf. loxo/s.
lu/a_, v. lu/h. lua/zei: fluarei=, mwrologei=, stasia/zei, Hsch.

*lu^ai=os, a, o(, h(, (lu/w)
loosener or
deliverer, epith. of the Great Mother, kakw=n luai/a Tim.Pers.132; of Dionysus (cf. Lat.
Lyaeus), Anacreont.11.9, al., IG5(2).287 (Mantinea, i/ii A.D.).
lu^a/w, (lu/h) = stasia/zw, a)llh/lois d' e)lu/hsan Call.Aet.Oxy.2080.76, cf. Choerob. in Theod.2.162 H.:—Med., lua=tai Hsch.
luba/zein: loidorei=n, Hsch.

lu/bernos, o(, = liburno/s,
war-galley, BGU709.2 (ii A.D.).
lu/gaia: ta\ peri\ tai=s xersi\ ye/llia, Hsch.

lu_gai=os, a, on, (lu/gh)
shadowy, murky, gloomy, ne/fos S.Fr.525, E. Heracl.855; nukto\s o)/mma lugai/as Id.IT110, cf. A.R.2.1120; e)sqh/s Lyc.973; ei(rkth/ Id.351; qa/lamos IG12(8).92.10 (Imbros, ii/i B.C.). Adv. -ai/ws Eust.1756.28, Hsch. (-gaw=s cod.).
lu/gaos, f.l. for lu/gdos, Hsch.
luggano/menon: lu/zonta e)n tw=| klai/ein, Hsch.; cf. lugkai/nw.

lu/ggios, a, on,
of a lynx, de/rma Edict.Diocl.in IG5(1).1115 Aii65 (Geronthrae).

luggou/rion, to/ (derived by the ancients from lu/gc, ou)=ron, and supposed to be the coagulated urine of the lynx, Dsc.2.81, Plu.2.962f, S.E.P.1.119), a kind of
amber (glossed by h)/lektron, Hsch., cf. Str. 4.6.2), Thphr.Lap.28, IG11(2).161 B49 (Delos, iii B.C.), al., 22.1534.100, Str.4.5.3 (pl.):—also written lugkou/rion, ligkou/rion, and liggou/rion in codd.; loggou/rion Aët.2.35.

luggw/dhs, es,
attended with hiccup, puretoi/ Hp.Fract.11, cf.
Acut. (Sp.)30.

lu/gdh, = leu/kh,
white poplar, Hsch.

lu/gdhn, Adv., (lu/zw)
with sobs, kla/ein S.OC1621, cf. AP15.28.
lugd-i/neos [i^], a, on, = sq. 2, deirh/ AP5.47 (Rufin.).

lu/gd-i^nos, h, on,
of white marble, bwmo/s Africa Italiana 1.325 (Cyrene, i B.C.), cf. AP6.209 (Antip. Thess.), Babr.30.1; lugdi/nh li/qos Philostr.Im. Prooem.
marble-white, l. kw/nia mastw=n AP5.12 (Phld.); tra/xhlos Anacreont.15.27.

lu/gd-os, h(,
white marble, Peripl.M.Rubr.24; lu/gdou leio/teron AP5.27 (Rufin.); oi(=a/ te lu/gdou glupth/n ib.193 (Posidipp. or Asclep.); h( *pari/a l. D.S.2.52, cf. Mart.6.13,42.
lu^ge/a, h(, = lu/gos, Eust.834.37.
lu/geios, = lugai=os, Tz.H.5.725.

lu/gh [u_], h(,
twilight, App.Ill.25, cf. Suid., Eust.689.18.

lu_gi/zomai, Pass., (lu/gh)
to be hidden, lugi/sasqai: krubh=nai, Theog- nost.Can.22.

lu^g-i/zw, Dor. fut. inf. lugicei=n Theoc.1.97: (lu/gos):—
bend or
twist as one does a withe, pleura\n lugi/santos u(po\ r(w/mhs, of a dancer, Ar.V.1487; neu=ra lelugisme/na
twisted, Hp.Mochl.4; ta\ lugisqe/nta tw=n a)/rqrwn
twisted joints, Gal.Protr.11; lugi/zein a)llh/lous, of wrestlers, Luc.Anach.1, cf. Philostr.Im.2.32: metaph., l. me/los Ael.NA2.11; cf. lu/gisma, lugismo/s.
throw, master, *)/erwta Theoc.l.c.:— Pass.,
to be thrown or
mastered, Id.1.98; ou)d' e)lugi/xqh ta\n yuxa/n Id.23.54. Pass.,
bend or
twist oneself like a withe, bend aside, so as to avoid a blow, lugi/zetai kai\ sustre/fei to\n au) xe/na Eup.339, cf. Pl. R.405c; stre/fou lugi/zou te mu/qois S.Ichn.362 (lyr.); e)lugi/sqhsan kata\ troxw=n Phalar.Ep.147.3; also of dancers, Luc.Salt.77, etc.; u(p' o)rxhsmw=n lelugisme/non i)/xnos AP6.33 (Maec.): metaph., in pf. part. lelugisme/nos,
effeminate, Anon. ap. Suid. s.v. a(bro/s; e)pe/wn ko/smos lel. AP11.20 (Antip. Thess.).
turn, play, as a joint in the socket, a)/rqron h(=| lugi/zetai S.Tr.779.

lu^/g-i^nos, h, on,
of agnus castus, ste/fanos l. Heph. ap. Ath.15.673e; cf. lu/gos.

lu^/g-ion, to/,
switch, Sch.D.T. p.195 H.
lu^/g-ios, a, on, = diwlu/gios, l. ti a)nakwku/sasa v. l. in Hld. 6.5.

lu^/g-isma, atos, to/,
sprain, Dsc.5.117; lugi/smasi: sugka/mmasi, Hsch.

lu^g-ismo/s, o(,
a bending, twisting, like the willow, hence of wrestlers, Luc.Anach.24, cj. in Philostr.Im.2.6 (log- codd.); of dancers, -ismou\s o)rxei=sqai Id.VA4.21; gona/twn-ismoi/ PMich.in Class.Phil.22.10: metaph., of
the windings and twistings of a sophist, Ar. Ra.775 (pl.).

lu^g-istiko/s, h/, o/n,
readily twisting, supple, of dancers, Poll.4.97.

lugkai/nw,
sob, Suid. s.v. a)nalu/zousa. lugkasth/sei: au)/cei paraplhsi/ws, h)\ lugka/sai, r(eu=sai, Hsch. (fort. . . h)\ lu/gkas a)greu=sai).

lu/gkeios, a, on, (*lugkeu/s)
of Lynceus, ble/mma App.Anth.3.79 (Posidipp.).
lugkeu/s, e/ws, o(, an eye-salve, Gal.12.778, Paul.Aeg.7.16.
lugki/on, to/, Dim. of lu/gc (A), Callix.2.
lugkou/rion, v. luggou/rion.
lugm-o/s, o(, （lu/zw） = lu/gc (B), Hp.Aph.5.3, Arist.Pr.961b9,963a38 (pl.), Nic.Th.434 (pl.), J.BJ6.2.2. = o)lolugmo/s, Suid.; = qrh=nos, Hsch.
lugm-w/dhs, es, = luggw/dhs, Hp.Art.86.

lu/gc (A), o(, h(, gen. lugko/s （lu/gga in E.Fr.863 is perh. f.l. for lu/gka, but cf. lu/ggios):—
lynx, Felis lynx, h.Hom.19.24; baliai\ lu/gkes E.Alc.579 (lyr.), cf. Arist.HA500b15, Thphr.Fr.175, etc.
caracal, Felis caracal, Ael.NA14.6, Opp.C.3.85, etc. (cf. luggou/rion). (OHG.
luhs, Germ.
luchs, Lith.
lúšis.）

lu/gc (B), h(, gen. luggo/s, （lu/zw)
hiccup, Hp.Aph.5.58, al., Pl.Smp. 185d; l. kenh/ an ineffectual
retching, Th.2.49, cf. Aret CA2.4: masc. in pl., toi=s lugci/ Gal.1.356, but fem. in Id.15.846. lu/gga qhrathri/an dub. l. in S.Fr.474.1.

lu^go/-desmos, h, on,
bound with willow-twigs, epith. of Artemis, Paus.3.16.11.

lu^go-eidh/s, e/s,
like agnus castus, Dsc.4.144.

lu^go-plo/kos, on,
viminarius, Gloss.

lu/gos [u^], h(, also o(, Longus 3.27 codd.:— = a)/gnos,
agnus castus, Vitex Agnus-castus, withy: in pl.,
its twigs or
withes, tou\s [the rams] sune/ergon e)u+strefe/essi lu/goisi Od.9.427, cf. 10.166, E.Cyc.225, etc.; in di/dh mo/sxoisi lu/goisi Il.11.105, lu/goisi is the specific word added to the generic mo/sxoisi (cf. su=s ka/pros, i)/rhc ki/rkos, etc.): in late Prose, Arr.Fr.153 J.; used for wreaths, stefanou=tai lu/gw| Anacr.41; cf. lu/ginos. lugw=s (sic cod., fort. lugo/s)
screw-press used by carpenters, Hsch. (but perh. lugw=<de>s).

lu^goteuxh/s, e/s,
made of withes, ku/rtos AP9.562 (Crin.).

lu^go/w,
tie fast, i(ma/nti kat' au)xe/nos a(/mma AP9.150 (Antip.); a)luktope/dh|si lugwqei/s APl.1.15.
bend, overpower, *dana/as e)lu/gwsen o(/de fre/na AP5.216 (Paul. Sil.).

lugropa^qh/s, e/s,
suffering mournfully, bi/otos IG12(8).38.15 (Lemnos).

lugro/s, a/, o/n,
baneful, mournful, o)/leqros, gh=ras, Il.10.174, Od.24.
250, etc.; a)/lgea Il.13.346; a)ndroktasi/hs u(/po lugrh=s 23.86; l. de/os Archil.74.4; o)ni/an . . lu/gran (gen.pl.) Sapph.Supp.1.10; nei=kos Pi.N.8.25; ma/xai B.10.68; pe/nqos A.Ch.17; o)rga/ ib.835 (lyr.); po/noi, no/sos, S.OT184 (lyr.), Ph.1424, etc.; lugra/
bane, misery, Il.24.531, Od.14.226;
ruin, 3.303; e)/coxa lugra\ i)dui=a versed above all
in banes, 11.432, cf. Hes.Th.313; lugra\ noeu=ntes Id.Op.261. with an act. force, sh/mata l. Il.6.168; fa/rmaka lugra/, opp. e)sqla/,
baneful drugs, Od.4.230, 10.236; gasth\r lugrh/ the stomach
that cause of bane, 17.473. l. ei(/mata
sorry garments, 16.457. of persons,
baneful, mischievous, 9.454: more freq.,
sorry, i.e.
weak, cowardly, Il.13.119, 237, Od.18.107, A.Fr.361, S.Ant.823 (Sup., lyr.). Adv. -rw=s
sorely, lugrw=s peplhgui=a Il.5.763. [u^ by nature, Pi.N.8.25, Mosch.4.73, etc.]

lu^gw/dhs, es, (lu/gos)
like a willow, r(a/bdoi Dsc.4.80; futa/ Eust.834.32.

*lu_di/a, Ion. -ih, h(, Lydia, Hdt.1.79, etc.:—hence *lu_diaka/, ta/,
a history of Lydia, by Xanthus, Ath.12.515e: *lu_dikh\ a)rxh/ Lydian empire, Hdt.1.72.

*lu_di/zw,
speak Lydian, Hippon. in PSI9.1089.1.
play the Lydian, of Magnes, in reference to his play called *ludoi/, Ar.Eq.523; *ludi/zein th\n stolh/n Philostr.VA5.32:—in Phot. and Suid. also *ludia/zw.

*lu/dios [u_], a, on,
of Lydia, Lydian, au)loi/ Pi.O.5.19; su/kina PCair.Zen.33.12 (iii B.C.); also os, on Luc.VH1.8, Harm.1: prov., para\ to\ *lu/dion a(/rma qe/ein
to be left far behind, Diogenian.6.28, Greg.Cypr.2.99, cf. Pi.Fr.206: *ludi/a li/qos, h(, a siliceous stone used to assay gold, and first discovered in Lydia, elsewhere ba/sanos, *ludi/a ga\r li/qos manu/ei xruso/n B.Fr.10; also *l. pe/trh Theoc.12.36; and h( *l. Anon. in An.Ox.3.216; *l. li/qos, of the magnet, S.Fr.800: *lu/dion, to/, a kind of vase, *l. me/zw AJA31.349.

*lu_disti/ [i^], Adv.
after the Lydian fashion, Cratin. 256; in Music,
in the Lydian mode, Pl.La.188d; h( *l. a(rmoni/a Id.R.398e, cf. Arist. Pol.1342b32, Plu.2.1134b.

lu_di/wn, wnos, o(, Lat.
ludio, ludius, D.H.2.71; cf. *ludo/s 111.

*lu_dopa^qh/s, e/s,
voluptuous as a Lydian, Anacr.155.

*lu_do/s, o(,
a Lydian, Alc.Supp.22.1, Sapph.Supp.5.19, Pi.O.1.24, Hdt.1.10, etc.: also as Adj. for *lu/dios, *lu/daisin e)mpre/petai gunai/kessin Sapph.Supp.25.6; *ludh\ kerki/s, *l. phkti/s, S.Fr.45, 412. = ludi/wn, App.Pun.66. f.l. for au)lo/s, D.H.1.33.

lu/zw, aor. e)/lugca Gal.15.846:—
to have the hiccup, Hp.Morb.3.10.
sob violently, from fear or cold, oi( fobou/menoi kai\ oi( r(igou=ntes lu/zousin Arist.Pr.962b33; l. kai\ dakru/ei Ar.Ach.690; goero\n lu/zwn AP7.218.12 (Antip. Sid.). (Cf. Ir.
slucim, Welsh
llyncu, MHG.
slucken 'swallow'.)

lu/h [u^], h(, （lu/w)
dissolution, separation: hence,
faction, sedition, = sta/sis, Hdn.Gr.1.306; Aeol., Dor. lu/a, Alc.Supp.23.10, 5.11 (pl.), Pi.N.9.14.
luqa/zw, gloss on lu/zw, Hsch. lu/qios: h)qmo/s (Heraclea), Id.

lu/qr-on, to/, or lu/qr-os, o(,
defilement from blood, gore, Hom., only in dat., lu/qrw| . . pala/sseto xei=ras Il.11.169, 20.503; ai(/mati kai\ lu/qrw| pepalagme/nos 6.268, Od.22.402: masc. lu/qros AP9.323 (Antip.), Ph. ap.Gal.13.268, Poll.1.46, M.Ant.3.3, Jul.Or.2.71a: the neut. lu/qron only in APl.4.112: in Medic., of
the impure blood in a woman's womb, Plu.2.496b, 997a: pl., e)k mhtrw/|wn lu/qrwn Hp.Ep.17; of
blood in general, M.Ant.2.2; of the
venom of the hydra, Euph.50.2. [u^ by nature, APl.l.c., Epigr.Gr.314 (Smyrna).]

luqr-o/w, misspelling of lutro/w,
redeem a pledge, CPR12.17 (i A. D., Pass.).

luqr-w/dhs, es,
defiled with gore, LXX Wi.11.6, AP9.258 (Antiphan. Megalop.).

lu^ka/bas [ka^], antos, o(,
year, tou=d' au)tou= luka/bantos e)leu/setai e)nqa/d' *)odusseu/s within this very
year, Od.14.161, 19.306 (but 'this very
month' acc. to D.Chr.7.84; perh.
day, if Od.14.161-2 are spurious); ei)=ar . . o(/lw| l. parei/h Bion Fr.15.15; au)=qi me/nwn luka/banta
for a year, A.R.1.198; but acc. luka/ban IG12(2).129 (Mytilene, late):—the word is freq. in metr. epitaphs, ib.4.622 (Argos), Epigr.Gr.231 (Chios), 228 (Ephesus): hence lu^ka^banti/des w(=rai, ai(, the hours
that make up the year, AP5.12 (Phld.). (Arc. word, = e)niauto/s, acc. to AB1095.)
lu^ka/gxh, h(, （lu/kos） = kuna/gxh, Cael.Aur.CP3.1.
*lu/kaia, ta/, v. *lukai=os 111.

lu/kaina [u^], h(, fem. of lu/kos,
she-wolf, Arist.HA580a18, Babr.16.8, Plu.Rom.2; of Artemis in Mithraism, Porph.Abst.4.16:—Dim. lukai/nion, to/, of a woman, Poll.4.150.

lu^kaino/morfos, on,
she-wolf-shaped, Lyc.481.

*lu^kaioni/khs [ni_], ou, o(,
victor at the *lu/kaia, IG5(2).549.

*lu^kai=os, a, on,
Lycaean, Arcadian, epith. of Zeus, Pi.O.9.96, Hdt. 4.203, etc.; to\ tou= *l. *dio\s i(ero\n kata\ to\ *l. o)/ros Str.8.8.2. *lu/kaion, to/,
his temple, Plu.2.300a; *l. sh/kwma E.El.1274.
Mons Lycaeus in Arcadia, Pi.Fr.100, Theoc.1.123. *lu/kaia (sc. i(era/), ta/,
festival of Lycaean Zeus, ta\ *l. qu=sai X.An.1.2.10, cf. IG22.993, SIG82 (iv B.C.), etc.; also, = Lat. Lupercalia (from lu/kos, Lat.
lupus), D.H.1.80, Plu.Ant.12.
lu^kaixli/as: o( luko/brotos, Hsch. (fort. luko/brwtos, cf. ai)=klon).
*lu^kambi\s a)rxh/, phrase used of the Polemarch by Cratin.130.

lu^ka/nqrwp-os, o( and h(,
were-wolf or
man-wolf, Marc.Sid. (cf. Suid. s. h. v.) ap.Gal.19.719, Aët.6.11, Paul.Aeg.3.16:—hence lu^kanqrwp-i/a, h(, a kind of madness,
in which the patient had the ravenous appetite and other qualities of a wolf, Gal. l. c., Orib.Syn.8.9.

*lu^ka_oni/a, h(, district in the S. of Asia Minor, X.An.1.2.19, etc.:— the people were *luka/ones, oi(, ib.3.2.23, Arist.Fr.151. Adv. lu^kanqrwp-isti/,
in Lycaonian, Act.Ap.14.11.

lu^kaugh/s, e/s, (*lu/kh)
of or
at the grey-twilight, Heraclit.All.7; to\ l.
early dawn, Luc.VH2.12, Agath.4.20, etc.

lu/kayos [u^], o(,
viper's herb, Echium italicum, Nic.Th.840; lukayo/s in Dsc.4.26 (with vv. ll.), Paul.Aeg.7.3:—also lukoyi/s, i/dos, h(, Gal.11.811.
lu^k-a/wn, onos, o(, = luka/nqrwpos, Paul.Aeg.3.16.

lu^k-e/h (sc. dora/), h(,
wolf's-skin, Il.10.459, Hsch.:—contr. lukh= App.Hisp.48, Poll.5.16.

lu^k-ei/a, h(,
helmet of wolf-skin, Plb.6.22.3.
lu^k-ei=on: fobero/n, Hsch.

*lu/keion [u^], to/,
the Lyceum, a gymnasium at Athens, named after the neighbouring temple of Apollo *lu/keios, Ar.Pax356, X.HG1.1.33: a resort of Socrates, Pl.Euthphr.2a, Euthd.271a; here Aristotle used to discourse, whence his disciples were called *lu/keioi *peripathtikoi/, Elias in Cat.112.31. lu/keion, v. lu/kion 1.2.

lu/keios [u^], on, S.El.7, E.Rh.208 (but lukei/a (q. v.) as Subst. in Plb.):—
of or
belonging to a wolf, dora/ E.l.c., etc. *lu/keios (written *lu/khos Milet.1(7) No.282 (i B.C.)), epith. of Apollo, either as lukokto/nos (q. v.), or as
the Lycian god (v. *lukhgenh/s, *lu/kios), or (fr. *lu/kh) as
the god of light: *lu/kei' *)/apollon A.Ag.1257; eu)menh\s d' o( *l. e)/stw Id.Supp.686 (lyr.); in Id.Th.145 (lyr.) there is a play upon the doubtful meanings, *lu/kei' a)/nac, lu/keios genou= stratw=| dai/+w|, Lycean lord, be
a very wolf to the enemy; so tou= lukokto/nou qeou= a)gora\ *lu/keios (this a)gora/ being
an open place in Argos near the temple of Apollo *lu/keios) S.l.c.; cf. *lu/keion. epith. of Pan, IG5(2).93 (Tegea). *lu/keios, o( (sc. mh/n), a month at Epidaurus Limera, ib.(1).932; *lu/keos, at Lamia (Thess.), ib.9(2).75.18, etc.
lu^kh=, h(, contr. for luke/h.

*lu/kh [u^], h(,
morning twilight, only in Macr.Sat.1.17.37, as etym. of luko/fws, a)mfilu/kh; cf. lukaugh/s, lukoeidh/s 11, a)mfilu/kh.

*lu^khgenh/s, e/s, epith. of Apollo, commonly expld.
Lycian-born, i.e. at Patara, Il.4.101, 119, cf. Heraclit.All.7, and v. lu/keios.

lu^k-hdo/n, Adv., (lu/kos)
wolf-like, A.Fr.39.

lu^k-hqmo/s, o(,
a wolf's howl, formed like mukhqmo/s, Anon. ap. Suid.
lukhla/tous: ta\s e)nxelei/s, Hsch.

*lu^ki-a/rxhs, ou, o(,
president of the koino/n
of Lycians, Str.14.3.3, OGI 495.14 (Cibyra), 568 (Tlos, iii A. D.):—hence *lu^ki-arxe/w, ib.556 (ibid.), etc.; and *lu^ki-arxi/a, h(, TAM2(1).190.5 (Sidyma), etc.
*lu^ki-a/rxissa, h(, fem. of *lukia/rxhs, ib.189a2 (ibid.).

lu^ki^deu/s, e/ws, o(,
wolf's cub, Sol. ap. Plu.Sol.23, Theoc.5.38.

*lu^kioergh/s, contr. *lu^ki-ourgh/s, e/s,
of Lycian workmanship, probo/lous *lukioerge/as （lukoerge/as and lukerge/as codd.) Hdt.7.76 (quoted by Ath.11.486d); *lukiourgei=s fia/lai D.49.31, cf. Poll.6.97: called batia/kai
*lukiourgoi/ in Epist.Alex. ap. Ath.11.784b (-ourgei=s corr. Schw.).

lu/kion, to/,
dyer's buckthorn, Rhamnus petiolaris, found in Cappadocia and Lycia, Dsc.1.100, Plin.HN12.30, 24.125, Gal.12.63. l. i)ndiko/n, = logxi=tis, Dsc. l. c., Gal.12.216; also lu/keion Apollon. ap. Gal.12.616.
a decoction from l. 1.1, used medicinally, ib. 63, IG14.2406.2,4.
lu/kios: koloiou= ei)=dos, Hsch.; cf. lu/kos 11.

*lu/kios [u^], a, on, Lycian: *lu/kioi, oi(,
the Lycians, Il.2.876, etc.:— also *lu^kiako/s, h/, o/n, Luc.Nav.8; *lu^kiaka/, ta/,
history of Lycia, Ath. 8.333d. epith. of Apollo (cf. *lu/keios), Pi.P.1.39, E.Fr.700, D.S.5.56, Paus.2.19.3: expld. a)po\ tou= leukai/nesqai pa/nta fwti/zontos h(li/ou Antip.Stoic.3.249.
*lu^kiourgh/s, e/s, contr. for *lukioergh/s (q. v.).
luki/skos: h( mh\ e)/xousa a)coni/skon troxali/a, trh=ma de\ mo/non, h)\ a)/nodos do/matos, Hsch. lu^koba^ti/as drumo/s: e)n w(=| oi( lu/koi diatri/bousi, Id. (post lukaixli/as).

lu^ko/-brwtos, on,
eaten by wolves, pro/bata Arist.HA596b7, Plu.2.642b, Orib.Eup.4.88.11; perh. to be read in Hsch. s.v. lukaixli/as; cf. luko/w.

lu^ko-di/wktos [i^], on,
wolf-chased, da/malis A.Supp.351 (lyr., restored by Herm. for leuko/diktos).

lu^ko-eidh/s, e/s,
wolf-like, Eust. 856.51. = lukaugh/s, Poet. ap. Hsch.
lu^ko-ergh/s, e/s, f.l. for *lukio- in Hdt.7.76.
lu^ko-e/ria: e)k lukei/ou de/rmatos peponhme/na, Hsch. (fort. -erge/a).

lu^ko-qarsh/s, e/s,
not fearing wolves, AP7.703 (Myrin.); lu^ko-qra^sh/s in Hsch.
lu^ko-kari/s: qermo\n a)p' a)lfi/tou piei=n, Id.

lu^ko-ktone/w,
slay wolves, Sch.Ar.Av.368.

lu^ko-kto/nos, on,
wolf-slaying, epith. of Apollo, S.El.6, Plu.2.966a, Porph.Abst.1.22, and v. *lu/keios; l. fare/trh AP13.22 (Phaedim.). lukokto/non, to/,
wolf's-bane, aconitum, Gal.11.820.

lu^/ko-lugc, lugkos, o(,
wolf-lynx, Pap. in Sitzb.Heidelb.Akad.1923(2).14,23.

lu^ko/-morfos, on,
wolf-shaped, Tz. ad Lyc.481.

lu^ko-pa/nqhros, o(,
wolf-panther, synon. of qw/s in Hdn. Epim.60, cf. Eust.856.51.

lu^ko-pe/rsion, to/, an Egyptian plant, with a strong-smelling, yellowish juice,
Hyoscyamus muticus, Gal.11.682.

*lu^ko/podes, oi(, f.l. for leuko/podes, either
barefoot, or
wearing white shoes, in Ar.Lys.665 (lyr.); expld. by Arist.Fr.394 (ap.Sch.ad loc.) as oi( tw=n tura/nnwn dorufo/roi (either from wearing wolf-skin footgear or from the device of a wolf on their shields).

lu^korrai/sths, ou, o(,
wolf-worrier, ku/nes AP7.44 (Ion), cf. 6.106 (Zon.).

lu/kos [u^], o(,
wolf, Il.16.156, 352; polio/s
grisly, 10.334; kraterw/nuxes Od.10.218; o)re/steroi ib.212; w)mofa/goi Il.16.156; koiloga/stores A.Th.1041; the small Egyptian wolves mentioned by Hdt. 2.67 were perh.
jackals: various kinds distd. by Opp.C.3.293 sqq.: prov. lu/kon i)dei=n to see
a wolf, i. e.
to be struck dumb, as was vulgarly believed of any one at whom a wolf got the first look (Pl.R.336d), Theoc.14.22; lu/kou ptera/, of things that are not, 'pigeon's milk', Suid.; w(s l. xanw/n, of vain expectation, Eub.15.11, cf. Ar.Fr.337,
Euphro 1.31; l. kexhnw/s Ar.Lys.629; pri/n ken l. oi)=n u(menaioi=, of an impossibility, Id.Pax1076, 1112, cf. Il.22.263; w(s lu/koi a)/rn' a)gapw=sin, of treacherous or unnatural love, Poet. ap. Pl.Phdr.241d; lu/kou bi/on zh=n, i. e. live by rapine, Prov. ap. Plb.16.24.4; e)k lu/kou sto/matos, of getting a thing
praeter spem, Zen.3.48; tw=n w)/twn e)/xein to\n lu/kon 'catch a Tartar', Apollod.Car.18, cf. Plb.30.20.8; l. a)eto\n feu/gei, of the inescapable, Diogenian.6.19; l. peri\ fre/ar xoreu/ei, of those engaged in vain pursuits, ib.21. a kind of
daw, Arist.HA 617b17; cf. lu/kios.
a fish, = kalliw/numos, Hices. ap. Ath.7.282d, Gp.18.14.1. a kind of
spider, Arist.HA623a2, Nic.Th. 734, Plin.HN30.52.
anything shaped like a hook:
a jagged bit for hard-mouthed horses, Lat.
lupus, Plu.2.641f; cf. lukospa/s.
hook or
knocker on a door, Hsch.
flesh-hook, Poll. 10.98. nickname of paiderastai/, AP12.250 (Strat.), cf. Pl.Phdr. 241d.
the flower of the iris, Philin. ap. Ath.15.682a. a kind of
noose, Gal.UP7.14, Heraclas ap.Orib.48.7, Hippiatr.74.
a pastille used in dysentery, Aët.9.49 (Latin version). = o)roba/gxh, v.l. in marg. of Dsc.2.142. an engine of war for defending gates, Procop.Goth.1.21. (Cf. Skt.
vŕ[null ]kas, Lith.
vi[ltilde]kas, Slav.
vl[ucaron]k[ucaron], Goth.
wulfs.）
lu^ko/-skordon, to/, = a)mpelo/prason, Ps.-Dsc.2.150.
lu^ko-sku^ta/lion [a^], to/, = shsamoeide\s to\ me/ga, ib.4.149.

lu^ko-spa/s, a/dos, o(, h(,
torn by wolves, epith. of bees, Nic.Th.742 (because generated from corpses of oxen torn by wolves, Sch. adloc.). of horses, *)atra/kion dh)/peita lukospa/da pw=lon e)lau/nei Call.Fr.474, where it may mean
drawn by the bit (lu/kos v.1), cf. Plu.2.641f, or a)pospasqeisan a)po\ lu/kou as expld. by Choerob. in Theod.1.287, cf. Plu. l. c. (where horses bitten by wolves are said to become speedier); but oi( l. were
a breed of horses in lower Italy, = i(/ppoi ai( *)eneti/des, Phot., cf. Hsch., Ael.NA16.24.
lu^ko/-spastos, on, = foreg. 1, Hsch. s.v. lelukwme/na.

lu^ko/-stomos, o(,
wolf-mouth, a kind of
anchovy, = e)/ggraulis, Ael.NA8.18, Gp.20.46.1.

*lu^kou/rgeia, h(, the
trilogy of Aeschylus
on the story of Lycurgus king of Thrace, Ar.Th.135 (*lukourgi/a codd.).
luko/fanon: to\n e)xino/poda (Messen.), Hsch.; cf. luko/fwn.

lu^k-o/fqalmos, h(,
wolf-eye, a precious stone, Plin.HN37.187.

lu^ko-fi^li/a, h(,
wolf's (i. e.
false) friendship, Pl.Ep.318e, M.Ant.11.15.

lu^ko-fi/lios [fi^], on,
like wolf's friendship, diallagai/ Men.833. Adv. -i/ws Ael.Dion.Fr.251.

lu^ko-fo/ros, on,
branded with the mark of a wolf, name of a swift breed of Venetian horses (cf. lukospa/s 11), Str.5.1.9.

lu^ko/frus, uos, h(, name for the plant a)rtemisi/a, cj. for lusi/kopon in Poet.
de herb.28; but leuko/frus, Ps.-Dsc.3.113.

lu^ko/frwn, onos, o(, h(,
wolf-minded, = deino/frwn, Hsch.; a)/ndres luko/frones quoted as poet. by Plu.2.988d:—in Hom. only as pr. n.
luko/fwn, wnos, o(, a plant, Plu.Lyc.16, Id.2.237b:—in both places lukofa/nous ( = e)xino/podas, v. luko/fanon) should prob. be read (luko/fonas, lukofa/nas codd.).

lu^ko/fws, wtos, to/,
twilight, both of morning and evening,
gloaming (cf. a)mfilu/kh nu/c), Ael.NA10.26, Sch.Il.7.433, Hsch. s.v. lukoeide/os, Eust.689.21, Sch.Ar.Ra.1385. (Variously expld. ll. cc.)

lu^ko/xroos, on, contr. lu^ko/-xrous, oun,
wolf-coloured, bafh/ Eust.689.20.
lu^koyi/a, h(, （o)/yis） = luko/fws, Lyc.1432.
lu/koyis, and lu/koyos, vv. ll. for lukayo/s in Dsc.4.26.

lu^ko/w, (lu/kos)
tear like a wolf:—Pass.,
to be torn by wolves, pro/bata lelukwme/na X.Cyr.8.3.41.
lukta/: ou)k a)nekta/, Hsch.
lu^k-w/, ou=s, h(, = lu/kaina, epith. of the Moon, PMag.Par.1.2276.

lu^k-w/dhs, es,
wolf-like, tw=| xrw/mati Arist.HA579b15.

lu=ma (A), atos, to/, mostly in pl. (sg. in Berl.Sitzb.1927.159 (Cyrene)),
water used in washing, or
dirt removed by washing, offscourings, oi( d' a)pelumai/nonto kai\ ei)s a(/la lu/mata ba/llon Il.1.314; a)mbrosi/h| me\n prw=ton a)po\ xroo\s . . lu/mata pa/nta ka/qhren 14.171; e)/kluzen potamw=| lu/mata Call.Aet.3.1.25; of catarrhal discharges,
purgations, Hp.Gland.12; lu/maq' a(gni/sas e)ma/, of the blood on his hands, S.Aj.655; to/koio lu/mata, = ta\ lo/xia, Call.Jov.17: generally,
offscourings, refuse, gh=s Id.Ap.109; do/mwn e)k lu/mat' e)/neikan A.R.4.710; of ordure, Call.Fr.216; e)/kbola l. daito/s Id.Cer.116; e)kklu/zein ta\ l. th=s po/lews ei)s to\n *ti/berin Str.5.3.8, cf. Plu.2.518b.
moral filth, defilement, in sg., lu=ma tw=| gh/ra| tre/fh|; S.OC805. = lu/mh,
ruin, A.Pr.692 (pl., lyr.): in sg., of a person, su/ t', w)= lu=m' *)axaiw=n, i. e. Hector, E.Tr.591 (lyr.).
lu=ma (B), atos, to/, （lu/w） = e)ne/xuron, Suid. (pl.).

lu_mai/nomai (A), (lu=ma A)
cleanse from dirt, of fullers, Hp.Vict.1.14; v. a)polumai/nomai.

lu_m-ai/nomai (B), fut. lu_ma^nou=mai Isoc.11.49, D.24.1, etc.: aor. e)lu_mhna/mhn Hp.VM20 (v.l. -ai/neto), Hdt.8.28, E.Andr.719, Isoc.20.12, etc.: also with pass. forms, part. lumanqe/n A.Ch.290: pf. lelu/masmai (3sg. lelu/mantai D.9.36, 21.173); part. -asme/nos X.HG7.5.18, D.45.27; inf. leluma/nqai Id.20.142, PPetr.3p.57 (iii B. C.): cf. dialumai/nomai: some of these forms are also used in pass. sense, v. infr. 11: (lu/mh):—
outrage, maltreat, esp. of personal injuries, scourging, binding, etc. (cf. D.23.33), but also in moral sense:—Constr.: c. acc.,
outrage, maltreat, o(/ti to\n cei=non . . dh/sas lumai/noito Hdt.5.33; th\n i(/ppon e)lumh/nanto a)nhke/stws Id.8.28; o)rgh=| xa/rin dou/s, h(/ s' a)ei\ lumai/netai S.OC855; l. le/xh
dishonour . . , E.Ba.354: c. acc. cogn. added, toiau=ta . . *sofokle/hs lumai/netai . . e)me\ to\n *thre/a Ar.Av.100; lu/mhs h(/n m' e)lumh/nw pa/ros E.Hel.1099; also in Att. Prose, l. no/mous Lys.30. 26, cf. D.18.312; ta\s r(h/seis a(\s e)lumai/nou the speeches you
used to murder (as an actor), ib.267; later simply,
harm, injure, blasfhmei=n kai\ -esqai to\n sofo/n Phld.Lib.p.10 O., cf. Ir.p.33 W.; of things,
spoil, ruin, nou=sos l. to\ sw=ma Hp.Morb.Sacr.11, cf. VM6; ta\ -o/mena gaste/ras kai\ kefala\s kai\ yuxa/s X.Mem.1.3.6; o)yopoii/+a l. ta\ o)/ya ib.3.14.5; l. th\n oi)ki/an Is.6.18; tou\s xulou/s Thphr.CP6.17.5; ta\ paro/nta Epicur. Sent.Vat.35; qli/bei kai\ l. to\ maka/rion Arist.EN1100b28; l. tou= a)raxni/ou
spoil part of it, Id.HA623a20. c. dat.,
inflict indignities or
outrages upon, nekrw=| Hdt.1.214,9.79; meiraki/ois Ar.Nu. 928 (anap.); h( u(/bris toi=s o(/lois pra/gmasi l. Isoc.20.9; h( kaki/a l. toi=s o(/lois D.18.303; l. th=| katasta/sei X.HG2.3.26; th=| e(autou= do/ch| ib.7.5.18; ponhroi\ . . au(toi=s -ai/nontai Epicur.Sent.Vat.53; toi=s . . proh|rhme/nois POxy.1409.21 (iii A. D.).—The constr. with dat. is considered strictly Att., Sch.Ar.Nu.925; but X. almost always uses the acc., which is freq. also in the Oratt.; Pl. does not use the word at all. abs.,
cause ruin, o(/sa met' e)lpi/dwn lumai/netai Th.5.103; pa=n to\ lumaino/meno/n e)stin e)/ndoqen Men.540.3;
cause damage, IG5(2).6.16 (Tegea, iv B. C.); also,
inflict punishment, ib. 5 (1). 1390.26 (Andania, i B. C.). c. dat. modi, lumai/nesqai [tina] lu/mh|si a)nhke/stoisi
treat with the worst
ill-treatment, Hdt.6.12; glw=ttan h(donai=s l.
defile it, Ar.Eq.1284. c. neut. Adj., ta)=lla pa/nta lumai/nesqai
inflict all possible
indignities, Hdt.3.16; au)tw=| ta/d' a)/lla *ba/kxios l. E.Ba.632 (troch.), cf. Ar.Av.100 (supr.1.1). Act. lumai/nw, only late, Lib. Decl.13.6; but lumai/nomai is sts. Pass., dedeme/nos kai\ -o/menos Antipho 5.63; u(po\ toiou/twn a)ndrw=n lumai/nesqe Lys.28.14; pla/stiggi lumanqe\n de/mas A.Ch.290; leluma/nqai D.20.142; lelumasme/nos Paus.7.5.4, 10.15.4; e)lelu/manto D.C.39.11; cf. dialumai/nomai 11.

lu_m-anth/r, h=ros, o(,
spoiler, destroyer, fili/as X.Hier.3.3.

lu_m-anth/rios, a, on,
injurious, destructive, desma/ A.Pr.991: c. gen.,
destroying, ruining, gunaiko\s th=sde Id.Ag.1438; tw=nde oi)/kwn Id.Ch.764.
lu_m-anth/s, ou=, o(, = foreg., ga/mos l. bi/ou S.Tr.793: also lu_m-antiko/s, h/, o/n, Muson.Fr.8p.34H., Epict.Gnom.9: c. gen., do/gmata l. oi)/kwn Arr.Epict.3.7.20; fuome/nwn （karpw=n) Ph.2.429.
lu_m-a/ntwr, oros, o(, = lumanth/r, Timo 65.
lu=mac, pl. lu/makes: pe/trai, Hsch. (cf. katalumako/omai).
lu=mar, to/, poet. for lu=ma, lu/mh, Max.238.
lu/masis, f.l. in A.Supp.877.
luma/xh: h( ei)s diafqora\n lu/ph, Hsch.

lu_m-ew/n, w=nos, o(, (lu/mh)
destroyer, corrupter, l. e)mo/s S.Aj.573; gunaikw=n E.Hipp.1068; swth=res a)lla\ mh\ lumew=nes [tw=n *(ellh/nwn] Isoc. 8.141, cf. 4.80; lumew=ni sw/matos qala/ssa| Tim.Pers.81; o(douroi\ l., of robbers, E.Fr.260, cf. J.BJ4.3.9; fo/bos tw=n h(de/wn l. X.Hier.6.6; koino\s l. th=s po/lews SIG799.23 (Cyzic., i A.D.); th=s te/xnhs, of bad physicians, Gal.9.916; sku/lakas . . l. tw=n poimni/wn Jul.Or.2.87a; o)/fin l. a)nqrwpi/nhs gene/sews Id.Gal.93d.

lu_m-ewneu/omai,
play or
act the lumew/n, Plb.5.5.8.

lu_/m-h, h(,
outrage, maltreatment, esp. by maiming, e)pi\ lu/mh| for the sake of
insult, Hdt.2.121. d/; do/mwn e)pi\ lu/mh| A.Th. 880 (lyr.); u(p' a)/froni lu/ma| Id.Eu.377 (lyr.); a)/ndra ou(/tw ai)sxrw=s lu/mh| diakei/menon Hdt.2.162; w(=n diafqeirome/nwn ou)k a)\n gi/gnoito mega/lh l. th=| po/lei Pl.Lg.919c; l. karpw=n kai\ proba/twn X.Oec.5.6; xwri\s th=s a)/llhs lu/mhs besides the
mischief done, Hp.Fract.3: freq. in pl.,
outrages, indignities, lumai/nesqai lu/mh|si Hdt.6.12; xersi\ kai\ lu/maisi kai\ pa=sin kakoi=s S.El.1196, cf. 1195; fqei/rein lu/mais e)xqi/stais Ar.Av. 1068; tai=sd' a)damantode/toisi lu/mais A.Pr.148 (lyr.), cf. 427 (lyr.); e)pi\ tai=s e)reqizou/sais to\n nouqetou/menon lu/mais Phld.Lib.p.8 O.
corruption, kaqa/per sidh/rw| me\n i)o/s, cu/lois de\ qri=pes . . sumfuei=s ei)si lu=mai Plb.6.10.3.
damage in financial sense, pro\s lu/mhn tw=n basilikw=n fo/rwn PMasp.2 iii 18 (vi A. D.), cf. 4.16 (vi A. D.);
injury from disease, Ruf.Fr.64.
lu/mhn, v. lu/w. lumno/s: gumno/s, Hsch. lu/mprwsxos: to\ luxni/on, Id. lu/c: lu/tron, Id. lupa/h, corrupt word in Luc. Pseudol.16. lu/peia: lipara/, Hsch.

lu_p-e/w, (lu/ph)
grieve, vex, whether in body or mind, tina Hes. Op.401, Sapph.Supp.2.4, etc.; opp. eu)frai/nein, E.Alc.239 (anap.); [o( qw/rac] lupei=
distresses by its weight, X.Mem.3.10.15: c.neut. Adj., lupei=n mhde\n au(to/n E.Cyc.338, cf. Hdt.8.144, X.Cyr.3.3.50; tau)ta\ tau=ta lupou=ntes, a(/per e)gw\ u(ma=s e)lu/poun Pl.Ap.41e: c. part., e)lu/pei au)to\n h( xw/ra porqoume/nh X.An.7.7.12; ou) skopei=s o(/ ti mh\ luph/seis tou\s a)/llous poiw=n D.21.135: folld. by interrog., kai/ m' h)=mar . . lupei=, ti/ pra/ssei S.OT74, cf. El.59; ou)de\n e)lu/phsen [au)to/], w(/ste mh/ . .
does no
harm . . , Pl.Cra.393e; ou)de/na luph/sas or -asa, as formula in epitaphs, IG14.1857, 2.1868. abs.,
cause pain or
grief, a)/gan ge lupei=s S.Aj.589, Ant.573, cf. OT1231; to\ lupou=n Antiph.107, Men.410. in histor. writers, of cavalry and light troops,
harass, annoy an army by constant attacks, Hdt.9.40, cf. 61, Th.6.66, X.HG6.3.14, An.2.3.23, etc.; lh|stai\ . . th\n *lakwnikh\n h(=sson e)lu/poun Th.4.53, cf. Ar.Av. 1427. Pass. with fut. Med. (E.Med.474, etc.),
to be grieved, distressed, lupei=sqai fre/na Thgn.593 codd.; tw=| mh/te xai/rein mh/te lupei=sqai brotou/s A.Fr.266, cf. S.Aj.555, etc.; mh/te lupe/o mh/te . .
be not
distressed, Hdt.8.100; u(po\ qerapai/nhs e)pi/thdes l. Lys.1.11: c. acc. cogn., ta\s e)sxa/tas l. lu/pas Pl.Grg.494a, cf. Phd.85a; also diplh=| tini lu/ph| l. Id.Phlb.36a: also c. acc. rei,
grieve about a thing, S.Aj.1086; pro\s ta\s cumfora/s Th.2.64; dia/ ti Pl.Phlb.52b; e)pi/ tini X.Mem.3.9.8: c. part., luph=| . . e)sterhme/nh E.Med.286; tau=t' e)lupei=q' o(rw=n D.18.217: abs.,
feel pain, E.Ion632, etc.; to\ -ou/menon th=s yuxh=s Pl.Lg.689b; to\ -ei=sqai Id.Prt.354d.

lu_/p-h, h(,
pain of body, opp. h(donh/, Id.Phlb. 31c, etc.; also,
sad plight or
condition, Hdt.7.152.
pain of mind, grief, ib.16.a/; dh=gma de\ lu/phs ou)de\n e)f' h(=par prosiknei=tai A.Ag.791 (anap.); ti/ ga\r kalo\n zh=n bi/oton, o(\s lu/pas fe/rei; Id.Fr.177, cf. S.OC 1217 (lyr.), etc.; e)rwtikh\ l. Th.6.59; lu/pas prosba/llein Antipho 2.
2.2; l. fe/rein tini/ And.2.8; opp. xara/, X.HG7.1.32.

lu_/p-hma, atos, to/,
pain, Antipho Soph.49 (pl.), D.C.55.17, f.l. in S.Tr.554.

lu_p-hro/s, a/, o/n, of things,
painful, distressing, Hdt.5.106, S.El.553; ti/ soi tou=t' e)sti\ l. klu/ein; Id.OC1176; ta)n do/moisi l. E.Ion623, etc.; a)zhmi/ous me/n, l. de\ a)xqhdo/nas
causing pain, Th.2.37; ta\ l. X.Hier. 1.8, cf. Men.555.3; bi/os -o/teros Pl.Lg.733b; to\ l. Id.R.585a; opp. to\ h(du/, Antipho Soph.49. of persons,
causing sorrow, luphro\s h(mi=n tou/sd' a)\n e)kli/poi do/mous E.Hipp.796.
causing pain, troublesome, l. klu/ein S.El.557; l. ou)k h)=n ou)d' e)pi/fqonos po/lei E. Supp.893, cf. Ar.Ach.456, Th.1.76, etc.; of those who are
objects of jealousy and envy, Id.6.16, cf. 2.64. of persons,
sad, = a)/qumos, Hsch., cf. LXX Pr.17.22. Adv. -rw=s
painfully, so as to cause pain, S.Ph.912; l. d' e)/xei, ei) . . it is
painful that . . , Id.El.767, cf. E.Ba.1263.
with pain, so as to feel or
show pain, l. fe/rein ti Isoc.9.54, cf. Arist.EN1110b12.

lu_p-hsi/logos [i^], on,
giving pain by talking, Cratin.343.

lu_p-hte/on,
one must feel pain, X.Ap. 27.

lu_p-htiko/s, h/, o/n,
feeling pain, e)pi/ tini Arist.MM1192b22. to\ l. the
capacity for feeling pain, Plu.2.657a.

lu_poto/kos, on,
pain-producing, e)kto\s e)w\n dakru/wn kai\ lupoto/kwn o)duna/wn BCH4.406 (Halic.).

lupro/-bi^os, on,
leading a wretched life, Str.7.5.12.

lupro-ge/ws, wn,
with poor soil, Ph.2.294, App.Hisp.59 (-geion codd., -gaion Suid.).

lupr-o/s, a/, o/n, (lupe/w, cf. luphro/s)
distressful, wretched, poor, esp. of land, gai=a Od.13.243, cf. Hdt.9.122, Arist.HA556a4; of plants, Thphr.CP2.4.5; l. trofai/ ib.6; of base coin, dub. l. in Id.Char.4.11; misqa/rion D.L.10.4. = luphro/s, of persons,
causing pain, offensive, e)moi/ ge lupro/s A.Eu.174 (lyr.); l. fanh=| E.Med.301. of states and conditions,
painful, distressing, A.Pers.1034 (lyr.), E.Alc. 370, etc.; to\ tou/twn l. Id.Supp.38; f.l. in A.Ch.835 (lyr.). Adv. -rw=s, e)/feren
aegre ferebat, E.Supp.898; l. pra/ttein Plu.Dio58; also lupra\ pra/ttein Id.Cim.1.

lupr-o/ths, htos, h(,
wretchedness, poverty, of land, Str.2.5.32, al.
lupro/xwros, on, = lupro/gews, Str.9.4.11.
lupta/: e(tai/ra, po/rnh, Hsch.

lu/ra [u^], h(,
lyre, a stringed instrument with a sounding-board formed of the shell of a tortoise (not in Il. or Od.), h.Merc.423, Margites 1, Pi.O.10(11).93, N.10.21, etc.; ke/lados e(ptato/nou lu/ras E.IT 1129 (lyr.); to\n a)/neu lu/ras qrh=non (since the dirge was accompanied by the flute) A.Ag.990 (lyr.); l. kai\ kiqa/ra (q. v.) Pl.R.399d, cf. Aristid. Quint.2.16: prov. o)/nos lu/ras (sc. a)kou/wn), v. o)/nos; a)nh\r de\ feu/gwn ou) me/nei lu/ras ktu/pon Ar.Fr.11 D.
lyric poetry and
music, Pl.Lg.809c, 809e. the constellation Lyra, Anacr.99, Arat. 269; *mousw=n l., of the Pleiades, Pythag. ap. Arist.Fr.196. a sea-fish, perh.
Trigla lyra, Arist.HA535b17.
*lu^rai=os, o(, epith. of Hermes as e)/foros mousikh=s, Procl. in Alc. p.195 C.

lu^r-a^oido/s (or rather lura/oidos Hdn.Gr.1.229), o(, h(,
one who sings to the lyre, AP7.612 (Agath.), APl.4.279:—contr. lu^rw|do/s, AP6.118 (Antip.), Plu.Sull.33: Adj. -w|do\s a(rmoni/a Callistr.Stat.7.

lu^r-i/zw,
play the lyre, Chrysipp.Stoic.3.140, Anacreont.42.12, Teucer in
Cat. Cod.Astr.7.202. trans.,
play on the lyre, poih/mata Phalar.Ep. 67.1.

lu^r-iko/s, h/, o/n,
of or
for the lyre, lyric, mou=sa Anacreont.2 B 2; te/xnh Plu.2.13b; ta\ kwmika\ kai\ tragika\ kai\ l. Phld.Po.2.35. as Subst. l., o(,
lyrist, AP11.78 (Lucill.), Plu.Num.4; or,
lyric poet, Cic.Orat.55.183, Plu.2.1142b.
lu^/r-ion, to/, Dim. of lu/ra Ar.Ra. 1304, IG22.1388.80:—also lu^r-i/s, i/dos, h(, Hdn.Gr.1.86.

lu^r-ismo/s, o(,
playing on the lyre, Sch.Ar.Pl.242.

lu^r-isth/s, ou=, o(,
player on the lyre, Plin.Ep.9.17.3, Artem.4.72; un-Att. acc. to Hellad. ap. Phot. Bibl.p.529 B.:—fem. lu^r-i/stria, h(, Sch.Juv.11.162.
luri/ths: zw=|o/n ti tai=s drusi\n e)nti/kton, Hsch. (fort. drui/+ths).

lu^ro-ghqh/s, e/s,
delighting in the lyre, AP9.525.12, An.Par.4.350.

lu^ro/-dmhtos, on,
lyre-built, epith. of Thebes, Nonn.D.25.415, al.

lu^ro/-eis, essa, en,
like the lyre, skindayo/s Theopomp.Coloph. ap. Ath. 4.183b.
fitted for the lyre, lyric, AP7.30 (Antip. Sid., prob. for luro/qen).

lu^ro-ergo/s, o/n,
playing on the lyre, Orph.A.7.

lu^ro-qelgh/s, e/s,
charmed by the lyre, AP9.250 (Honest.).

lu^ro-ktu^pi/a, h(,
a striking of the lyre, ib.6.54.10 (Paul. Sil.), APl.4.277 (Id.).

lu^ro/-ktu^pos, on,
striking the lyre, IG14.2134.6, Epigr.Gr.1023.2 (Nubia).
twanging like a lyre, of a bow-string, Lyc.918.
lu/ron, to/, = a)/lisma, Dsc.3.152.

lu^ropoi-htiko/s, h/, o/n,
skilled at making lyres, Poll.7.153; also -kh/, h(, and Adv. -kw=s ibid.

lu^ropoi-i/+a, h(,
manufacture of lyres, ibid.

lu^ropoi-iko/s, h/, o/n, = luropoihtiko/s: h( -kh/ (sc. te/xnh)
the art or
craft of lyremaking, Pl.Euthd.289c.

lu^ropoi-o/s, o(,
lyre-maker, And.1.146, Pl.Euthd. 289b, 289d, Cra.390b, Anacr.30 (codd. Heph., muro- Bgk. from Poll.7.177).

lu^rofoi=nic, i_kos, o(, kind of
lyre, Juba 73:—Dim. lu^ropoi-foini/kion, to/, Poll.4.59.
lurto/s, o(, Epirote word for sku/fos, Seleuc. ap. Ath.11.500b.

lu^r-w|de/w,
play the lyre, Tz.H.10.410.
lu^r-w/dhs, es, = luro/eis, me/lh Epigr. ap. Eus.PE11.6.

lu^r-w|di/a, h(,
song to be sung to the lyre, Poll.4.58, Aristid.Or.37(2).21, Callistr.Stat.7.
lu^r-w|do/s, v. luraoido/s.

lu^r-wni/a, h(, (w)ne/omai)
buying of lyres, Ar.Fr.240.

*lu_sa/ndria (better lu^/r-eia as Hsch., Phot.), ta/,
festival in honour of Lysander, Plu.Lys.18.

lu_s-a^ni/as, ou, o(, (lu/w, a)ni/a)
ending sorrow, l. kakw=n Ar.Nu.1162 (lyr.), cf. Hsch.; dub. cj. in Theopomp.Com.30.4.

lu_s-e/rws, wtos, o(,
deliverer from love, Sch.Verg.Aen.4.520.

lu_s-h/nwr, oros, o(, h(,
relaxing men, oi)=nos Tryph.449.

lu_si/-ga^mos [i^], on,
dissolving marriage, a)ggeli/ai AP5.301.14 (Agath.).

lu_si-gui=a, h(,
relaxation of the limbs, Hp.Loc.Hom.14.

lu_s-i/drws, wtos, o(, h(,
freeing from perspiration, Choerob. in Theod. 1.252.

lu_si^-e/qeira, h(,
with loose, dishevelled hair, Nonn.D.19.331.

lu_si^/-zwnos, on, of a soldier,
unequipped, ungirded, unarmed, Polyaen.8.24.3.
loosing the zone, i.e. ceasing to be a maid, Hsch., Suid.: hence as epith. of Eileithyia and Artemis, who
assisted women in travail, Theoc.17.60, Corn.ND34, Orph.H.2.7, 36.5, etc.

lu_/si^-qric, tri^xos, o(, h(,
with loose hair, Gp.12.8.5.

lu_si^/-ka^kos, on,
ending evil, u(/pnos Thgn.476.
lu_si^/-komos, on, = lusi/qric, Philostr.Ep.16, Nonn.D.19.331.

lu_si^/-kopos, on,
freeing from fatigue, Poet.
de herb.28 cod.
lu_si^-lai/+des, = qe/rmoi (Lacon.), Polem.Hist.91.

lu_si^-ma/xeios [a^], a, on,
of Lysimachus, xrusou=s IG11(2).287 B 46 (Delos, iii B. C.), written -eos. Subst. lu_si^-ma/xeios, o(,
loosestrife, Lysimachia vulgaris, Dsc.4.3, Gal. 12.64; also lusima/xeion, to/, Paul.Aeg.7.3. (Freq. written -ion in codd.)

lu_si^/-ma^xos, -on,
ending strife, freq. as pr. n.; used with a play on the meaning, AP5.70 (Rufin. or Pall.), 11.210 (Lucill.):— fem. lu_si^ma/xh, Ar.Pax992 (anap.), Lys.554 (pl.). -maxos, h(, a gem, Plin.HN37.172.
lu_si^/-mbrotos, on, prob. = lush/nwr, Pi.Pae.Oxy. 1791.18.

lu_si^-melh/s, e/s,
limb-relaxing, epith. of sleep, Od.20.57, 23.343, Mosch.2.4, etc.; of love, Hes.Th.911, Archil.85, Sapph.40, etc.; of thirst, Thgn.838; of death, E.Supp.47 (lyr.); of wine, sickness, etc., AP11.414 (Hedyl.); of the Furies. Orph.H.70.9.

lu_si^-me/rimnos, on,
driving care away, of Dionysus, AP9.524.12; of Hermes, Orph. H.28.6; of Artemis, ib.36.5; of Sleep, ib.85.5, etc.

lu/simos [u^], on,
able to loose or
relieve, me/lh A.Supp.811 (lyr.). Pass.,
that can be redeemed, redeemable, e)ne/xura Pl.Lg.820e.
that can be solved, refutable, sullogismo/s Arist.APr.70a31. ta\ l. tw=n no/mwn the legal texts read by fourth-year students (lu/tai), AP 5.291 tit. (Agath.).
that can be melted, khro/s Jul.Ep.193.

lu/sios [u_], a, on, （lu/sis)
releasing, delivering, lu/sioi qeoi/ the gods
who deliver from curse or
sin, Pl.R.366a; esp. *lu/sios, as epith. of Dionysus, Plu.2.613c, Corn.ND30, Orph.H.50.2, cf. Paus.9.16.6; lu/sioi teletai/, of Dionysus *lu/sios, Phot. s. h. v.; also *lu/seios, Orph. H.42.4; voc. *luseu=, ib.52.2 (*kisseu= Lobeck).

lu^si^-pai/gmwn, on, gen. onos,
letting loose, i.e.
giving, play or
sport, Anacreont.48.9. (As all other Adjs. (exc. sq.) compd. with lusi- have u_, Herm. suggested luropai/gmwn.)

lu^si^-ph/mwn, on, gen. onos,
ending sorrow or
pain, Orph.H.2.11, 59.20 codd. (laqiph/mwn Herm., cf. foreg.).
lusipnei=: fobei=tai, Hsch.

lu_si/-poqos [i^], on,
delivering from love, a)ggeli/ai AP5.268 (Agath.).

lu_si-po/lemos, o(, name of a
war-engine invented by Dorion, Pap.in
Abh. Berl.Akad.1904(2).9 (ii B. C.).

lu_si-po/nion, to/,
a medicinal unguent, Gal.12.771, Alex.Trall.1.16: also lu_si/-ponon, to/,
an eye-salve, CIL13.10021.174, cf. 52,63.

lu_si/-ponos, on,
releasing from toil, labour-lightening, qera/pontes Pi.P.4.41; l. teleuta/ death
that frees from care, Id.Fr.131.1.

lu/sis [u^], ews, Ion. ios, h(, (lu/w)
loosing, releasing, ransoming, nekroi=o Il.24.655; sw/matos Lys.4.13; h( l. th=s ai)sqh/sews e)grh/gorsis Arist.Somn.Vig.454b27: c. gen. objecti, qana/tou l.
deliverance from death, Od.9.421, Thgn.1010; l. e)/ridos Hes.Th.637; xree/wn Id.Op. 404; peni/hs Thgn.180; lu/sin ai)thso/menoi tw=n pareo/ntwn kakw=n Hdt. 6.139; penqe/wn Pi.N.10.76; mo/xqwn tw=n e)festw/twn S.Tr.1171; tw=n deima/twn Th.2.102; tw=n desmw=n Pl.R.515c; a)po\ tw=n desmw=n ib.532b; e)k xalepw=n Thgn.1385; blasfhmi/as D.Ep.3.39; ma/xhs PLips.40 ii 16 (iv/v A. D.). abs., ou) ga\r l. a)/llh stratw=| pro\s oi)=kon no other
means of letting the host
loose from port for home, S.El.573.
deliverance from guilt by expiatory rites, o(/pws l. tin' h(mi\n eu)agh= po/rh|s may'st grant us
a deliverance such as may purify us, Id.OT921; ou)d' e)/xei lu/sin [ta\ ph/mata] admit not of
atonement, Id.Ant.598 (lyr.); lu/seis te kai\ kaqarmoi\ a)dikhma/twn Pl.R.364e; th=| [th=s filosofi/as] lu/sei kai\ kaqarmw=|
by her
offer to release them, Id.Phd.82d; ai( nomizo/menai l., in cases of homicide, Arist.Pol.1262a32; l. a(marthma/twn
blotting out of sins, Ph.2.151.
redemption of mortgage or pledge, [xwri/on] peprame/non e)pi\ lu/sei IG2.1103, al., cf. 12(7).55.14 (Amorgos), 12(8).18 (Lemnos).
release, discharge from a financial obligation, lu/sin poih/sasqai th=s sugxwrh/sews BGU1115.46 (i B. C.), etc. for w)mh\ lu/sis, v. w)mh/lusis.
loosing, parting, l. kai\ xwrismo\s yuxh=s a)po\ sw/matos Pl.Phd.67d; simply, h( tou= sw/matos l. Id.Ax.371a;
dissolution, politei/as Id.Lg.945c; no/mwn h)\ politei/as Arist.Pol.1268b30; bi/ou lu/sin e)/sxe IG14.140 (Syracuse); l. komh/tou Phlp.in Mete.86.25; tw=n sfragi/dwn ai( l.
breaking them, Luc.Alex. 20.
emptying, evacuation, pei/nh me/n pou l. kai\ lu/ph; Pl.Phlb.31e; h( l. tw=n koiliw=n, koili/as, Arist.Pr.947b29, Dsc.1.64 (v.l.);
emission of semen, Alex.Aphr.Pr.1.125 (pl.). l. puretou=
remission of fever, Gal.11.28; l., opp. kri/sis, Id.9.732;
cure, Anon.Lond.3.20; ta\ pa/qh defined as sustolai\ kai\ lu/seis (v.l. xu/seis）th=s yuxh=s, opp. kri/seis, Zeno Stoic.3.113 = 1.51. as a technical term,
solution of a difficulty, h( l. th=s a)pori/as its
solution, Arist.EN1146b7, al.; e)/xei tina\ l. pro\s tau/thn th\n a)pori/an, o(/ti . . Id.de An.422b28; ou) sumbai/nei h( l. Id.EN1153b5; o(/tan to\ qa/mbos . . mh\ du/nhtai th\n l. lamba/nein Epicur.Ep.1p.29U.; eu(rei=n l. tou= problh/matos Plb.30.19.5; l. eu(re/sqai Phld.Rh.1.267 S.; also,
interpretation, shmei/wn tera/twn te lu/seis Orph.A.37.
refutation of an argument, Arist.SE179a27, Rh. 1402b23, al.
unravelling of the plot of a tragedy, opp. de/sis, Id.Po.1454a37 (pl.), 1455b24.
softening of a strong expression, Longin.38.5.
resolution of one vowel into two, as in h(/lios, h)e/lios,
like diai/resis, Demetr.Eloc.70.
looseness of structure in writing, esp. asyndeton, ib.192, al. in metric,
resolution of _ into ^^, Heph.6.
divorce, 1 Ep.Cor.7.27; l. ga/mou Just.Nov.140 Prooem., cf. 117 tit. = do/rpou l.,
place for banqueting (cf. kata/lusis 11), Pi.O.10(11).47.

lu_si^swma^te/w,
to be relaxed in body, Hp.Epid.5.82.

lu_si^te/l-eia, h(,
advantage, profit, Thphr. ap. D.L.5.54, D.S.1.36, LXX 2 Ma.2.27, J.AJ16.9.1; l. peri\ to\n xro/non
economy in respect of time, i.e. by postponement of payments until they fell due, Plb.31.27.11; dia\ lusite/leian for the sake of
economy, Dsc.5.8.—Rejected by the Atticists, Poll.5.136, Moer.p.248 P., Phot.

lu_si^tel-e/w, prop.
indemnify for expenses incurred, or
pay what is due, and then '
pay', i.e.
profit, avail (cf. lu/w v. 2), c. dat., with subject expressed, ou)/ fhm' a)\n lusitelei=n sfw=|n [tou=to] Ar.Pl.509; lusitelei= h(mi=n h( dikaiosu/nh Pl. Prt.327b; dou=los toiou=tos oi(=os mhdeni\ despo/th| lusitelei=n X.Mem.2.1.15. mostly impers., lusitelei= moi
it profits me,
is better for me, c. part., oi(=s ou)d' a(/pac e)lusite/lhse peiqome/nois Lys.25.27; polloi=s dh\ e)lusite/lhsen a)dikh/sasi Pl.Alc.1.113d: c. inf., l. proi+e/nai Id.Tht. 181b; teqna/nai nomi/sasa lusitelei=n h)\ zh=n thinking it
better to be dead than alive, And.1.125, cf. Pl.R.407a, X.Cyr.2.4.12 (v.l.), PHamb.27.17 (iii B. C.), etc.: c. dat. pers.,
it profits one to do so and so, ou) ga/r oi( lusitele/ein . . dika/zein Hdt.1.97; o(/ti moi lusiteloi= w(/sper e)/xw e)/xein Pl. Ap.22e, cf. X.Hier.7.13: sts. c. acc. pers.,
it is good that . . , lusitelei= to\n me/llonta kakw=s i)htreu/esqai a)mfo/tera katagh=nai ta\ ske/lea Hp. Fract.19, cf. Pl.R.406d: abs., e)lusite/lei ga/r Axionic.6.6. in bad sense,
conspire, as gloss on e)s to\ kako\n a)llh/loisi suntimwrei= (Hp. Acut.17), Gal.15.494 (v.l. suntelei=). neut. part. as Subst., to\ lusitelou=n
profit, gain, advantage, Th.6.85, Pl.R.336d, D.2.28; a wrong etym. is given in Pl.Cra.417c.

lu_si^tel-h/s, e/s, (lu/w v. 2, te/los) prop.
paying for expenses incurred: hence,
useful, profitable, advantageous, to\ pra=gma/ moi l. Axionic.6.8; ou)de/pot' . . -e/steron a)diki/a dikaiosu/nhs Pl.R.354a, cf. 364a; e)mporeu/mata -e/stera X.Hier.9.11; -esta/thn zwh\n zh=n Pl.R.344e; lusitelh=
advantages, Plb.4.38.8; to\ -e/staton pro\s a)rgu/rion
what was most profitable in point of money, D. 20.13; ta\ l. kai\ a)lusitelh= pro/s ti Phld.Mus.p.93 K.; kth/seis -e/sterai Id.Oec.p.68 J.
cheap, X.Vect.4.30, D.H.7.37. rarely of persons,
profitable, advantageous, Pl.Phdr.239c. Adv. -lw=s D.S.14.102: Sup. -e/stata Hdn.3.5.1.
cheaply, tou= de/ontos pri/asqai -e/steron Ael.NA10.50.

lu_si^tel-ou/ntws, Adv.
usefully, profitably, X.Oec.20.21, Pl.Alc.2.146b; e(autoi=s D.C.56.40.

lu_si^-to/kos, on,
loosing the pains of child-birth, qe/aina Nonn.D.41.166. Pass. lu_si/tokos,
set free by birth, qa/lamoi l., i.e. eggs that have been laid, Opp.C.3.128.

lu_si^-fa/rma^kon, to/,
remedy against spells, PMag.Osl.1.178.

lu_si^-flebh/s, e/s,
opening the veins, AP6.94 (Phil.).

lu_si^/-frwn, onos, o(, h(,
releasing from care, Anacreont.47.2.

lu_si^-xi/twn [xi^], wnos, o(, h(,
with loose tunic, Nonn.D.5.407.

lu_si^w|do/s, o(,
one who played women's characters in male attire, Aristox.Fr.Hist.57, Posidon.4 J., Phld.Ind.Sto.7, Plu.Sull.36: so called from *lu=sis, who wrote songs for such actors, Str.14.1.41: distd. from magw|do/s, ibid., but identified with m. by Aristocl.Hist. 7: fem. h( lusiw|do/s Ath.Naucr. (FGrH 166) 1 J. as Adj., l. au)loi/ flutes
that accompanied such songs, Ephor.3 J. (nisi leg. lusiw|d<ik>w=n).
luska/zei: perifeu/gei, Hsch.

lu/ss-a^, Att. lu/tta^, h(,
rage, fury, in Hom. always of
martial rage, kraterh\ de/ e( l. de/duken Il.9.239; l. e)/xwn o)loh/n ib.305; l. de/ oi( kh=r ai)e\n e)/xe kraterh/ 21.542. after Hom.,
raging madness, frenzy, such as was caused by the gods, as that of 10, lu/sshs pneu/mati ma/rgw| A.Pr.883 (anap.); of Orestes, Id.Ch.287, E.Or.254, etc.; of the Proetides, B.10.102; of Bacchic frenzy, e)lafra\ l. E. Ba.851; qoai\ *lu/ssas ku/nes, of the Furies, ib.977 (lyr.); lu/ssh| para/kopos Ar.Th.680: strengthd., l. mania/s S.Fr.941.4; lu/tta e)rwtikh/ Pl.Lg.839a; l. alone, of
raging love, Theoc.3.47; simply,
rage, Phld.Ir.p.77 W.;
fanaticism, peri\ ta\s ai(re/seis Gal.8.148 (pl.). personified, *lu/ssa
the goddess of madness, E.HF823.
rabies, in dogs, X.An.5.7.26, Arist.HA604a5, Gal.1.296; in horses, Porph. Abst.3.7.
the worm under the tongue
of dogs, removed from the belief that it produces rabies, Plin.HN29.100.

luss-ai/nw,
rave, tini against one, S.Ant.633.

luss-a^le/os, a, on,
raging mad, ku/nes A.R.4.1393; also l. mani/h Man.4.539.

luss-a/s, a/dos, h(,
raging mad, Tim.Fr.3, APl.4.289; l. moi/ra| E.HF1024 (lyr.).

luss-a/w, Att. lutta/w, Ep. part. lussw/wn Man.1.244, AP5.265 (Paul. Sil.):—
to be raging in battle, Hdt.9.71; cf. lu/ssa init.
rave, be mad, S.OT1258, Ant.492, Pl.R.329c, Epicur.Sent.Vat.11, Man., APll.cc., etc.; l. pro\s mei=cin Ps.-Phoc.214; e)/rwtes luttw=ntes Pl.R.586c: c. inf.,
desire madly to do, Hld.2.20. of dogs,
suffer from rabies, Ar.Lys. 298, Arist.HA604a6; of wolves, Theoc.4.11; of horses, Arist.HA 604b13. causal,
make mad, ka)\n lelussh/kh| tina/ (sc. ta\ dh/gmata) Damocr. ap. Gal.13.821. (Hsch. has lu/ssetai: mai/netai.)

luss-hdo/n, Adv.
furiously, madly, Opp.H.2.573.
luss-h/eis: maniw/dhs, Hsch.

lu/ss-hma, atos, to/,
fit of madness: in pl.,
ravings, ei)/ m' e)kfoboi=en mania/sin lussh/masin E.Or.270.
luss-h/rhs, es, = lussale/os, Orph.H.69.6, Man.6.560.

luss-hth/r, h=ros, o(,
one that is raging or
raving mad, ku/wn Il.8.299; i)o\s kuno/s AP5.265 (Paul. Sil.).
luss-hth/s, ou=, o(, = foreg., App.Anth.5.47; Dor. luss-a_ta/s AP7.473 (Aristodic.).

luss-htiko/s, h/, o/n,
driving mad, pro\s ta)frodi/sia Ael.NA12.10.

lusso/-dhktos, on,
bitten by a mad dog, Dsc.1.100 (interpol.), Gp.12.17.14, Herasap.Gal.13.431, M.Ant.6.57, Damocr. ap. Aët.15.14.

lusso-di/wktos [i^], on,
pursued by madness, Orac. ap. X.Eph.1. 6.

lusso-ma^ne/w,
rage, rave, Man.4.216.

lusso-ma^nh/s, e/s,
raving mad, AP11.232 (Call. Arg.); plo/kamoi ib.6.219 (Antip.).

lusso-ma^ni/a, h(,
paroxysm of madness, Jul.Ep.114.

luss-o/w,
enrage, madden:—Pass.,
to be or
grow furious, Ps.-Phoc. 122.

luss-w/dhs, es,
like one raging, frantic, of martial rage, Il.13.53.
of madness, l. no/sos S.Aj.452; of Dionysus, E.Ba.981 (lyr.); to\ l. tw=n h(donw=n Plu.Fr.18.12.

luss-w=pis, idos, h(,
with frantic glance, Orph.A.979.

lu/tai [u^], oi(,
law-students who were in their fourth year of study, Just.
Const.omnem 5; cf. prolu/tai.
*lu^tai=os, title of Poseidon in Thessaly, B.17.21, cf. St.Byz. s.v. *lutai/: *lutai/h, name for Thessaly, Hsch.
lutari/s: mh/kwnos ei)=dos, Hsch. lutaw=s: skoteinw=s, Id.
lu/t-eira [u^], fem. of luth/r, Orph.H.10.17, 32.13.

lut-e/on,
one must refute, Pl.Grg.480e;
one must open, fle/bas Herod.Med. in Rh.Mus.58.89. Adj. lute/os
that must be repealed, no/mos D.24.78.

lut-h/r, h=ros, o(, (lu/w)
one who looses, deliverer, po/nwn E.El.136 (lyr.); po/ron . . ga/mou luth=ra (as Pauw for kai\ luth/ria) A.Supp.807 (lyr.).
arbitrator, decider, neike/wn Id.Th.940 (lyr.).
lut-hria/s, a/dos, h(, = lu/teira, Orph.H.14.8, 36.7.

lut-h/rios, on,
loosing, delivering, dai/mones A.Th.175 (lyr.); l. a)/kh, mhxanh/, Id.Supp.268, Eu.646; plou=ton dwma/twn luth/rion Id.Ch.820 (lyr.); l. shmei=on a symptom
of healing, Hp.Prog.24: c. gen., o(/pws ge/noito tw=nd' e)moi\ l. my
deliverer from . . , A.Eu.298; luthri/ous eu)xa\s deima/twn S.El.635; to/d' a)\n kakw=n mo/non ge/noito . . l. ib.1490, cf. 447; to\ mequ/ein phmonh=s l. Id.Fr.758; also l. e)k qana/tou E.Alc.224 (lyr.); luth/rion lw/fhma is prob. in S.Tr.554 (l. lu/phma codd.). Subst. luth/rion, to/, = lu/tron, to\ l. dapana=n the
atonement or
reward for all costs, Pi.P.5.106; fo/noio
expiatory offering, A.R.4.704.

lut-iko/s, h/, o/n,
able to loose, laxative, th=s koili/as Mnesith. ap. Ath.3.92c, cf. 91b; l. fa/rmaka Arist.Pr.949a5. l. fa/rmakon
antidote to a poison, Thphr.HP 9.16.5. fa/rmakon flegmonh=s l.
dispersive of inflammation, Gal. 11.751, cf. 10.637.
able to refute, confutative, of arguments, Arist.Rh.1403a25.

lut-o/s, h/, o/n,
that may be untied, Pl.Ti.41b, al.
that may be dissolved, soluble, u(f' u(/datos ib.60d, cf. Arist. Mete.383b13. Adv. -tw=s
solubly, Id.PA649a32. of arguments and problems,
refutable, soluble, Id.Rh.1357b13.

lu/tr-on, to/, (lu/w)
price of release:
ransom, mostly in pl. (later sg., D.S.20.84, Plu.2.295c, etc.), tw=n l. th\n deka/thn the tithe
of the ransom-money, Hdt.5.77; *(/ektoros lu/tra, title of Il.24 and of play by Aeschylus; lu/tra labei=n tinos receive
as ransom for . . , Th.6.5; th=s qugatro\s lu/tra fe/rwn Pl.R.393d; lu/tra a)podido/nai, kataqei=nai, pay
ransom, D.53.11, 13; ei)senegkei=n ei)s lu/tra contribute towards
it, ib.7; a)fie/nai a)/neu lu/trwn release without
ransom, X.HG7.2.16, cf. Aeschin.2.100, D.19.169, etc.; dw/sousin e(/kastos lu/tra th=s yuxh=s au)tou= *kuri/w| a
ransom of his soul, LXX Ex.30.12; sg. in NT, l. a)nti\ pollw=n Ev.Matt.20.28, Ev.Marc.10.45; l. u(pe\r game/tou IG14.607f (Carales); pl.,
sum paid for manumission of a slave, POxy.48.6 (i A. D.), etc.
sum paid for redemption of a pledge, in pl., PBad.3.4 (ii B. C.), etc.
atonement, ti/ ga\r l. peso/ntos ai(/matos; (so Canter for lugro/n) A.Ch.48; of blood-money, LXX Ex.21.30, al. generally,
recompense, lu/tron kama/twn for toil, Pi.I.8(7).1; sumfora=s Id.O.7.77. a plant, = lusima/xeios, Ps.-Dsc.4.3.

lutr-o/w,
release on receipt of a ransom, hold to ransom, tina\ xrhma/twn o(/swn dokei=
for such a sum as is agreed on, Pl.Tht.165e;
redeem a pledge, l. ta\ i(ma/tia POxy.530.14 (ii A. D.), etc.:—Med.,
release by payment of ransom, redeem, para\ tw=n *ai)twlw=n IG12(5).36 (Naxos, iii B. C.), cf. LXX Ex.13.15, al.; th\n xw/ran xrhma/twn ou)k o)li/gwn Plb.18.16.1; h(ma=s a)po\ pa/shs a)nomi/as Ep.Tit.2.14:—Pass.,
to be ransomed, e)k tw=n i)di/wn lelutrw=sqai D.19.170, cf. Arist.EN1164b34; ai(/mati 1 Ep.Pet.1.18. Pass.,
to be released from an obligation, PEleph.19.8 (iii B. C.). mistranslation of Hebr. '
rp 'break the neck', LXX Ex.13.13. -w/n, w=nos, o(, = a)po/patos 2, ib.4 Ki.10.27, AB433.

lutr-w/simos, h, on,
redeemable, Suid. s.v. lu/mata, Phot. s.v. lu/sima.

lu/tr-wsis, ews, h(,
ransoming, ai)xmalw/twn Plu.Arat.11, cf. LXX Le.25.29, Ev.Luc.1.68, Ep.Hebr.9.12;
redemption of a pledge, PTeb.120.41 (i A. D.).
release, discharge from an obligation, POxy.1130.20 (v A. D.). l. u(/datos, =
spring of water, LXX Jd.1.15.

lutr-wte/on,
one must ransom, Arist. EN1165a1.

lutr-wth/s, ou=, o(,
ransomer, redeemer, LXX Ps.18(19).15, Act.Ap.7.35.

lutr-wto/s, h/, o/n,
redeemable, LXX Le.25.31.
lu/tta, lutta/w, lutthtiko/s, etc., v. luss-.
luttei=: polla\ lalei=, Hsch. lu/ttos, Cret. word for u(yhlo/s, St.Byz. s.v. *lu/ktos; luttoi/ (sic): oi( u(yhloi\ to/poi, Hsch.
lu/twr, oros, o(, = luth/r, f.l. for r(u/twr in AP9.351 (Leon. Alex.). [u_ is incorrect.]

luxn-ai=os, a, on,
of a lamp, fw=s Procl.Sacr.p.149 B. luxnai=os kai\
luxneu/s: o( diaugh\s li/qos, Hsch.

luxn-apte/omai,
light lamps, Roehl Sched.Epigr.27 (= CIG3062).
luxn-a/pths, ou, o(, gloss on da|dou=xos, Hsch.: pl. misspelt luxna/ptoi, POxy.1453.4, 8 (i B. C.).

luxn-a/ption, to/,
meeting-place of the luxna/ptai, Sammelb.1934 (Memphis).
luxn-a/ptria, h(, fem. of luxna/pths, IG3.162.
luxn-a/rion, to/, Dim. of luxni/a, PLond.5.1657.3 (iv/v A. D.).
luxn-ayi/a, h(, acc. to Ath. 15.701b less common form for luxnokauti/a, Cephisod.11, cf. PAmh.2.70.10 (ii A. D.), IGRom.4.1176 (Aegae), etc.
luxn-e/a and luxn-ei/a, h(, forms of luxni/a, PHamb.10.34 (ii A. D.), PTeb.406.12 (iii A. D.).

luxn-e/laion, to/,
lamp-oil, Alex.Trall.1.1.

luxn-eu/s,
e/ws, o(, = luxni/ths, Callix. 1, cf. Ath. 15.699d, Hsch. s.v. luxnai=os.

luxn-ew/n, w=nos, o(,
place to keep lamps in, Luc.VH1.29.

luxn-i/a, h(,
lampstand, SIG1106.118 (Cos, iv/iii B. C.), IG11(2).161C66,68 (Delos, iii B. C.), LXX Ex.25.30(31), al., PGrenf.1.14.6 (ii B. C.), Ev.Matt.5.15, Plu.Dio9, Luc.Asin.40, etc.: condemned by Phryn. 289.

luxn-iai=os, a, on,
belonging to a lamp, fw=s S.E.P.1.119, cf. Gal. 17(2).413, Olymp.in Mete.18.12, al.
luxn-i/dion, to/, v. luxnei=on.

luxn-i/on or lu/xn-ion, to/, = luxnei=on, Antiph.55.2, Theoc.21.36, Luc.Symp.46, IG5(2).514.16 (Lycosura, ii B. C.).
lamp, PTeb.406.12 (iii A. D.).

luxn-i/s, i/dos, h(,
rose campion, Lychnis coronaria, used for garlands, Thphr.HP6.8.3, AP 4.1.23 (Mel.), Dsc.3.100. l. a)gri/a
corn cockle, Agrostemma Githago, ib.101, cf. Nic.Th.899 (ubi v. Sch.). = a)nti/rrinon, Dsc. 4.130, Plin.HN25.129. a precious stone
that emits light, prob.
ruby, Luc.Syr.D.32, cf. Dercyl.11:—also lu/xnis, o(, D.P. 329, Orph.L.271.
luxn-i/skos, o(, Dim. of lu/xnos 11, Luc.VH2.30.

luxn-i/ths [i_], ou, o(,
a precious stone of a red colour, Pl.Erx.400d, Str.17.3.11, Plin.HN37.104 (v.l.), Eust.ad D.P.327. l. li/qos a name for Parian marble, which was quarried by lamplight, Varro ap.Plin.HN36.14.

luxn-i=tis, idos, h(,
candlewick, Verbascum mallophorum, the leaves of which served as lampwicks, Plin.HN25.121, BGU485.10 (ii A. D.); = flomi/s, Dsc.4.103.

luxno/-bi^os, on,
living by lamplight, Senec.Ep.122.

luxno-eidh/s, e/s,
lamplike, fw=s Iamb.Protr.21.kd'.

luxno-ka^i/+a, Ion. luxno-i/+h, h(,
lighting of lamps, illumination, Cratin.227 (but cf. Cratin.9 D.), D.C.79.16; a
Feast of Lanterns at Sais, Hdt.2.62, J.Ap.2.9 (pl.).
luxno-kauste/w, = sq., Cratin.9 D.

luxno-kaute/w,
light lamps, th=s po/lews -ou/shs D.C.63.20: a pecul. form luxnokw=sa, = luxnokautou=sa, in Telecl.60.
luxno-kauti/a, h(, = luxnokai/+a, luxnayi/a, Ath.15.701a.

luxno-mantei/a, h(,
divination by means of a lamp, PMag.Lond.121.540,556 (-ti/a Pap.), PMag.Par. 1.952 (-ti/a).
lu/xnon, to/, = lu/xnos, Hippon. 22 Diehl, BGU338.1, al. (ii/iii A. D.).

luxno-poie/w,
make lamps and lanterns, And.Fr.5(6):
luxno-poii/a, h(, f. l. for -kai/+an, Them.Or.4.49a:

luxno-poio/s, o(,
maker of lamps or
lanterns, Ar.Pax690, Philetaer.4, Cat.Cod.Astr.8(4).215.

luxno/-polis, ews, h(,
city of lamps, Luc.VH1.29.

luxno-pwle/w,
deal in lamps or
lanterns, Sch.Luc.Tim.30.

luxno-pw/lhs, ou, o(,
dealer in lamps or
lanterns, Ar. Eq.739.

lu/xnos, o(, pl. lu/xnoi Batr.180, Ar.Eq.1315, Antiph.70,152, PPetr.2p.72 (iii B. C.): freq. also lu/xna, Hdt.2.62,133, E.Cyc.514 (lyr.), Call.Hec.1.4.11, etc., prob. in Alc.41.1. (Fr. luk-
sno-, cf. *lu/kh):—
portable light, lamp, xru/seos l. Od.19.34; lu/xna kai/ein, a)na/ptein, light
lamps, Hdt. ll. cc.; a(/pte, pai=, l. Ar.Nu.18; lu/xnous a(/ptein
to have an illumination, Arr.Epict.2.17.37; lu/xnous a)posbe/sai Ar.Pl.668; l. a)pesbh/kei had been put out, Pl.Smp.218b; peri\ lu/xnwn a(fa/s about
lamp-lighting time, i. e. towards nightfall, Hdt.7.215, D.S.19.31; pa/nnuxos l. parakai/etai
lamps are kept burning all night, Hdt.2.130; kau/seis lu/xnwn Sammelb.1161.14 (i B. C.); e)/laion h(mi=n ou)k e)/nest' e)n tw=| lu/xnw| Ar.Nu.56; cf. kera/tinos. in pl., oi( lu/xnoi or ta\ lu/xna
the lamp-market, ou(k tw=n l. ib.1065. a fish, Str. 17.2.4, Hsch.; cf. Lat.
lucerna, Plin.HN9.82.

luxnou=xos, o(, (e)/xw)
lampstand, kai\ to
 l. e)/kfer' e)nqei\s to
 lu/xnon Pherecr.40; diasti/lbonq' o(rw=men w(/sper e)n kainw=| l. Ar.Fr.8; e)celw
 e)k tou= luxnou/xou to
 lu/xnon Alex.102, cf. Lys.Fr.83.

luxno-fore/w,
carry a lamp, luxnofori/ontes (Lacon.) Ar.Lys.1003.

luxno-fo/ros, on,
carrying a lamp, Posidon. 36 J., Plu.Pomp.52, J.Ap.2.9.

luxn-w/dhs, es,
like a lamp, opp. purw/dhs, Heph.Astr.1.23.
lu/xn-wma, atos, to/, = o)qo/nion, Sch.Ar.Ach.1175; cf. lampa/dion 11.1.

lu/w, poet. imper. lu=qi Pi.Fr.85: fut. lu/sw [u_] Il.1.29, etc.: aor. e)/lu_sa 18.244, etc.: pf. le/lu^ka Th.7.18, Ar.V.992 (a)po-), etc.:— Pass., pf. le/lu^mai Il.8.103, etc.: plpf. e)lelu/mhn [u^] Od.22.186, etc.: aor. e)lu/qhn, Ep. lu/qhn [u^] 8.360, E.Hel.860, Th.2.103, etc.: fut. lu^qh/somai Pl.Ti.41b, Isoc.12.116, etc., also lelu/somai [u_] D.14.2, X. Cyr.6.2.37 (a)po-): Ep. aor. Pass. lu/mhn [u^] Il.21.80; lu/to [u^] ib.114, but lu=to 24.1 (at beginning of line, v.l. lu/to); lu/nto 7.16: also 3sg. opt. pf. lelu=to Od.18.238:—Med., fut. lu/somai Il.1.13, etc.: aor. e)lusa/mhn 14.214: pf. Pass. le/lu=mai in med. sense, D.36.45, Arist.Rh. 1400a22 (cf. dia-, kata-lu/w): fut. lu/somai in pass. sense, (dia-) Th.2.12, (e)pi-) Lys.25.33 codd. (katalu/sesqai edd.), (kata-) X.Cyr.1.6.9.—Homer uses all tenses exc. pf. Act., pres. and fut. Pass. [In pres. and impf. u_ always in Att., u^ mostly in Ep., though Hom. has u_ twice, e)/lu_en Il.23.513, lu_ei Od.7.74; also in compds., a)llu_esken 2.105, a)llu_ousan ib.109: in fut. and aor. 1 u_ always: in other tenses u^ always, exc. in the forms lelu=to, lu=to (v. supr.).] (Cf. Lat.
luo (pay),
re-luo, solvo (for
se-luo), solūtus, etc.):—
loosen: of things,
unbind, unfasten, esp. clothes and armour, lu=se de/ oi( zwsth=|ra, qw/rhka, Il.4.215, 16.804; l. parqeni/hn zw/nhn
loose the maiden-girdle, of the husband after marriage, Od. 11.245; of the wife, lu/oi xalino\n u(f' h(/rwi+ parqeni/as Pi.I.8(7).48; e)/nqa parqe/nei' e)/lus' e)gw\ koreu/mata E.Alc.177; so e)/lusas . . a(/gneuma so/n Id.Tr.501; freq. of the tackling of ships, l. prumnh/sia, i(sti/a, lai=fos, etc., Od.2.418, 15.496, 552, h.Ap.406, etc. (never in Il.); l. pru/mnas, new=n po/da, E.Hec.539,1020, etc.: abs., lu/ein, of ships,
set sail, lu=e, kubernh/ta APl.1.6*.9 (Panteleus); a)sko\n l.
untie a skin (used as a bag), Od.10.47: freq. in Trag., l. stola/s, pe/plon, S.OC1597, Tr.924; l. h(ni/an
slacken the rein, Id.El.743; klh/|qrwn luqe/ntwn when the gates have been
opened, A.Th.396; l. gra/mmata, de/lton,
open a letter, E.IA38 (anap.), 307; l. pe/das, desma/, A.Eu. 645 (Pass.), E.HF1123; a)rbu/las A.Ag.945; a)rta/nas . . de/rhs e)/lusan
loosed it from my neck, ib.876, cf. E.Hipp.781:—Med., a)po\ sth/qesfin e)lu/sato kesto\n i(ma/nta
undid her belt, Il.14.214; but lu/onto teu/xea they
undid the armour
for themselves, i.e. stripped it off (others), 17.318; later lusame/na plokami=das
unbinding her hair, Bion 1.20, etc. in various phrases, sto/ma l.
open the mouth, E.Hipp.1060, Isoc.12.96; glw/ssas l. ei)s ai)sxrou\s mu/qous Critias 6.9 D.; l. blefa/rwn e(/dran wake up, E.Rh.8 (anap.); l. o)fru/n
unfold the brow, Id.Hipp.290; l. a)/xos a)p' o)mma/twn S.Aj.706 (lyr.), etc. of living beings, of horses, etc.,
unyoke, unharness, opp. zeu/gnumi, Od.4.35; e)c o)xe/wn, u(pe\c o)xe/wn, Il.5.369,8.504; u(f' a(/rmasin 18.244; u(po\ zugou= Od.4.39: u(po\ zugo/fin Il.24.576; u(p' a)ph/nhs Od.7.6 (also in Med., mh\ . . u(p' o)/xesfi luw/meqa mw/nuxas i(/ppous
unyoke our horses, Il. 23.7; bo/e lu=sai Hes.Op.608); lu/e mw/nuxas i(/ppous
loosed them, Il.10.498; l. ku/na
let him
loose, X.Cyn.6.13, etc. of men,
release, deliver, esp. from bonds or prison, and so, generally, from difficulty or danger, Il.15.22, Od.8.345, 12.53, D.24.206, etc.; o( lu/swn
he that shall deliver, A.Pr.771,785: c. gen. rei, to\n . . qeoi\ kako/thtos e)/lusan Od.5.397, cf. Pi.P.3.50, etc.; l. tina\ desmw=n A.Pr.1006; o)/knou S. Tr.181; tw\ . . e)k desmoi=o lu/qen Od.8.360, cf. Pi.O.4.23, A.Pr.873, E.Hipp.1244, Pl.R.360c; also l. do/mous a(bro/tatos
rob the house of . . , Pi.P.11.34; l. tina\ th=s a)rxh=s
depose him from . . , D.S.13.92:—Med., prop.
get one
loosed or
set free, lu/sasqai/ tina dusfrosuna/wn Hes.Th.528; o(/sper *)iw\ phmona=s e)lu/sato A.Supp.1065 (lyr.):—Pass., luqh=nai ta\s pe/das D.S.17.116; le/lutai ga\r lao\s e)leu/qera ba/zein, w(s e)lu/qh zugo\n a)lka=s
has been let loose to speak, since the yoke
was loosed, A.Pers.592 (lyr.). of prisoners,
release on receipt of ransom, admit to ransom, release, Il.1.29, 24.137,555, etc.; l. tina/ tini 1.20, 24.561, Od.10.298; *sarphdo/nos e)/ntea kala\ lu/seian
would give them
up, Il.17.163; in full, l. tina\ a)poi/nwn 11.106; xrhma/twn mega/lwn Hdt.2.135 (Pass.); a)nh\r a)nt' a)ndro\s luqei/s Th.5.3:—Med.,
release by payment of ransom, get a person
released, redeem, Il.1.13, 24.118, al., Od.10.284,385, Pl.Mx.243c, D.19.229; lu/sasqai/ tinas e)k polemi/wn Lys.12.20; i(/ppon X.An.7.8.6; o(/sous au)to\s e)lusa/mhn tw=n ai)xmalw/twn D.19.169; l. tini\ to\ xwri/on Id.50.28; e(autou\s l.
pay their own
ransom, Id.19.169;
buy from a pimp, Ar.V.1353. lelu/sqai tw=n no/mwn, = Lat.
legibus solvi, D.C.53.18.
give up, [qro/non] lu=son a)/mmin Pi.P.4.155.
resolve a whole into its parts, dissolve, break up, l. a)gorh/n
dissolve the assembly, Il.1.305; a)gora\s h)me\n lu/ei h)de\ kaqi/zei Od.2.69, etc.:—Pass., lu=to d' a)gw/n Il.24.1; mh\ luqei/h h( stratia/ X.Cyr.6.1.2; pri\n <a)\n> . . h( a)gora\ (
market) luqh=| Id.Oec. 12.1; luqei/shs th=s sunousi/as Plb.5.15.3. of concrete objects, spa/rta le/luntai, i. e.
have rotted, Il.2.135; r(afai\ d' e)le/lunto i(ma/ntwn Od.22.186; l. th\n sxedi/hn
break it
up, Hdt.4.97; [th\n ge/furan] X. An.2.4.17; th\n a)po/fracin ib.4.2.25. esp. of physical strength,
loosen, i. e.
weaken, relax, lu=se de\ gui=a
made his limbs
slack or
loose, i. e. killed him, Il.4.469, al.; o(/s toi gou/nat' e)/lusa 22.335; pollw=n te kai\ e)sqlw=n gou/nat' e)/lusen 5.176, etc.; a)lla/ oi( au)=qi lu=se me/nos 16.332; pe/lekus lu=sen . . boo\s me/nos Od.3.450, cf. Il.17.29; but oi(/ moi kama/tw| . . gou/nat' e)/lusan
made my knees
weak with toil, Od.20.118:—Pass., lu/nto de\ gui=a, etc., as the effect of death, sleep, weariness, fear, Il. 7.16, etc.; kama/tw| fi/la gui=a le/lunto 13.85, cf. Od.8.233; au)tou= lu/to gou/nata kai\ fi/lon h)=tor Il.21.114,425; lu/qh yuxh/ te me/nos te 5.296, etc.; lu/qen de/ oi( a(/yea pa/nta Od.4.794, 18.189; le/lutai gui/wn r(w/mh A.Pers.913 (anap.); lu/etai de/ mou me/lh E.Hec.438; le/lumai mele/wn su/ndesma Id.Hipp.199 (anap.). lu/ei ble/fara
closes her eyes
in sleep, S.Ant.1302. metaph., l. th\n e)n tai=s yuxai=s pro\s ma/xhn paraskeuh/n X.HG7.5.22.
undo, bring to naught, destroy, poli/wn ka/rhna Il.9.25; *troi/hs krh/demna 16.100, Od.13.388, cf. B.Fr.16.7: generally,
put an end to, nei/kea Il.14.205; meledh/mata 23.62; e)/rin E.Ph.81, AP9.316.12 (Leon.); po/lemon Th.5.31; e)pimomfa/n Pi.O.10(11).9; me/myin Democr.271; fo/bon A.Th.270; fo/bon kai\ th\n u(poyi/an Polystr.p.7 W., cf. Epicur.Sent.12; moxqh/mata S.OC1616; a)na/gkas E.Supp.39; bi/on, i.e. die, Id.IT692; ai)w=n' e)/luse, i.e. died, B.1.43; l. to\ te/los bi/on S.OC1720 (lyr.); maxas Ar. Pax991 (anap.); nosh/mata Diocl.Fr.35 (Pass.), cf. Gal.6.476; ko/pous Dsc.Eup.1.220;
forgive, a(marth/mata LXXJb.42.9. in Prose, l. no/mous
repeal or
annul laws, Hdt.3.82, D.3.10, Arist.Pol.1269a15; ou)qe\n tw=n peri\ th\n politei/an ib.1298b31; l. yh/fw| to\ para/nomon Aeschin. 3.197 (Pass.), etc.; e)pei\ e)kei=noi e)/lusan ta\s sponda\s lelu/sqai moi dokei= h( e)kei/nwn u(/bris kai\ h( h(mete/ra u(poyi/a X.An.3.1.21;
rescind a vote, yh=fon lu/ei o( no/mos D.24.2;
revoke a will, diaqh/khn Is.6.33, etc. (but in Pass.,
to be opened, of a will, POxy.715.19 (ii A. D.), etc.);
unbind a spell, Iamb.Myst.3.27:—Pass., le/lutai pa/nta all
ties are broken, all
is in confusion, D.25.25. as a technical term,
solve a difficulty, a problem, a question, lu/etai h( a)pori/a Pl.Prt.324e, al.; l. zh/thma Gal.6.436.
refute an argument, Pl.Grg.509a, Arist.Rh.1402b24,al.; cf. lu/sis 11.4b, lutiko/s 11.
unravel the plot of a tragedy, opp. ple/kein, Id.Po.1456a10. l. th\n fa/sin, of the Moon,
pass out of, Vett. Val.134.1, cf. 2.
break a legal agreement or obligation, to\n no/mon Hdt.6.106; ta\s sponda/s Th.1.23, 78, cf. 4.23, al.; ta\ sugkei/mena Lys.6.41; si/s ke ta\s vrh/tas ta/sde lu/sh whoso
breaks this agreement, Inscr.Cypr.135.29 H. in physical sense,
dissolve, lu/qen, opp. pa/gen, Emp.15.4; to\ qermo\n lu/ei, opp. ph/gnusi, Arist.Mete.384b11, cf. 382b33 (Pass.); a)mmwniako\n o)/cei lu/sas Gal.11.106;
melt, pagei/sas xio/nas Hdn.8.4.2; ti puri\ l. Hippiatr.52. of medicines, l. th\n koili/an Arist.Pr.863b29, cf. Hp.
Acut.(Sp.)38, Diocl.Fr.140; so of the effects of terror, Arist.Pr.877a32 (Pass.).
resolve _ into ^^, in Pass., Heph.8, 10, Aristid. Quint.1.28.
solve, fulfil, accomplish, ta\ tou= qeou= mantei=a S.OT407; o(/rkon Plb.6.58.4.
atone for, make up for, ta\s pro/teron a(marti/as Ar.Ra.
691; lu/swn o(/s' e)ch/marton S.Ph.1224; l. fo/non fo/nw| Id.OT101, E. Or.511; ai( pro/sodoi lu/ousi ta)nalw/mata Diph.32.5:—Med., tw=n pa/lai pepragme/nwn lu/sasq' ai(=ma . . di/kais A.Ch.804 (lyr.). misqo\n lu/ein
pay wages
in full, quit oneself of them, used only in cases of obligation, X.Ages.2.31. te/lh lu/ein, = lusitelei=n,
pay, profit. avail, e)/nqa mh\ te/lh lu/ei fronou=nti where
it boots not to be wise, S.OT 316: but more freq. lu/ei without te/lh, construed like lusitelei=, abs., lu/ei d' a)/lgos E.Med.1362, cf. PSI4.400.16: c. dat. pers., fhmi\ toiou/tous ga/mous lu/ein brotoi=sin E.Alc.628, cf.Hipp.441: c. inf., pw=s ou)=n lu/ei . . e)piba/llein; Id.Med.1112 (anap.); e)moi/ telu/eitoi=sime/llousin te/knois ta\ zw=nt' o)nh=sai
it is good for me to benefit my living children by means of those to come, ib.566; lu/ei a)pelqei=n UPZ77i12 (ii B.C.): c. acc. et inf., lu/ei ga\r h(ma=s ou)de/n, ou)d' e)pwfelei=, . . qanei=n
it is not
expedient that we should die (ou)d' e)pwfelei= being parenthetic), S.El. 1005; ou) ga/r me lu/ei . . kakorroqei=sqai E.Sthen.Prol.35; cf. lusitele/w.

lw=, Dor. Verb, = qe/lw: 1sg. indic., lw= ti musi/cai ne/on Ar.Lys.981; 2sg., ai) lh=|s, = ei) qe/leis, Epich.170.7, 172.4, Ar.Ach.766, cf. 776; o(/ ti tu\ lh=|s Epich.171.10; o(/ ti lh=|s Ar.Lys.95; kai) tu\ lh=|s Crates Com.41 (cj.); h(/ntina lh=|s Call.Dian.19; lh=|s . . th=de kaqi/cas . . suri/sden; Theoc. 1.12; 3sg., lh=| . . labei=n; Epich.170.8: 1pl., a(me/s ge lw=mes ai)/ tis . . lh=| tou=t' a)podo/men Ar.Lys.1162; 3pl., e)pile/gw toi=s qeoi=s, o(/ti lw=nti Epich. 35.12, cf. Theoc.4.14: subj., kai)/ ka/ tis . . lh=| th/nw| le/gein Epich.35.5, cf. GDI4982.2, Leg.Gort.3.18, al.; ai)/ ka lh=|s Theoc.5.21; ka)\n lh=te Ar. Lys.1105; lei/wnti Leg.Gort.2.35, al.; but ai)/ ka lw=nti Inscr.Olymp. 22 (Selinus): opt. 1sg. le/w|mi Hsch.; 3sg. lei/oi Leg.Gort.8.13, al., GDI5011.6, le/oi ib.5072b6, lw/|h Epich.[285]; 3pl. lei/oien GDI4984.12; Elean 3dual leoi/tan (or lhoi/tan) Inscr.Olymp.16.3: inf., ai) me\n lh=n Foed.Lacon. ap. Th.5.77 (Ahrens, for e)menlh=n etc.): part. le/wn Abh.Berl.Akad.1925(5).21 (Cyrene), lei/ontos Leg.Gort.8.22, lei/onta BCH27.221 (Lato), etc.; e)ce/stw kai\ a)/llw| tw=| lw=nti IG9(1).694.118 (Corc.); sundeipne/wn tw=| lw=nti . . , kai\ tw=| ga mhde\ lw=nti Epich.35.1,2 (Ahrens for gamhliw=nti; mh\ lei/onti Brause); lw=sa Hsch.:—Med., 3pl. pres. subj. lw=ntai IG12(7).67.11 (Amorgos, Dor. dial.); 3sg. la/htai: bou/lhtai, Hsch.:—
wish, desire, ll. cc. (Cf. lh=-ma, lh=sis (B), perh. also leli/hmai: the dialects seem to point to lei/w (fr. lei/-yw) as the original form, but the forms with lw- cannot have resulted from contr. of leio-: a stem lao- is doubtful, la/htai （bou/lhtai) Hsch. being perh. corrupt.)
lwb-a/zw, = sq., f.l. for lwba=sqai, Hp.Ep.17.

lwb-a/omai, Ion. lwb-e/omai Id.Art.35 (as v.l.), lwb-eu=mai Herod.3.69; Dor. impf. e)lwbh=to Sophr.21: fut. -h/somai Pl.Cri.47d: aor. e)lwbhsa/mhn Hdt.3.154, cf. Theoc.5.109, etc.: for pf. and aor. Pass., v. infr.: (lw/bh):—
outrage, maltreat, c. acc. pers., also with cogn. acc. added, lw/bhn lwba=sqai/ tina
do one
despite, Il.13.623; esp.
maim, mutilate, tina Hdt. l. c.; e(wuto\n lwba=tai lw/bhn a)nh/keston ibid.; a)rta/naisi lwba=tai bi/on
brings her life
to a shameful end by the halter, S.Ant.54; a)ndrw=n eu)/nidas l.
dishonouring them, E.Or.929; l. tou\s ne/ous
harm their pupils, Pl.Prt.318d; of the effect of drudging work, ta\ sw/mata lwbw=ntai Arist.Pol.1258b37; also l. po/lin Lys.26.9; [a)/stea] kat' a)/kras Theoc. 16.89;
pillage, po/lin Plb.4.54.2;
